PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 5 December.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember that when we adjourned this debate last Thursday I was making some comments which I do not resile from. I was asking questions about how to reconcile the notion of being an independent in a chamber which is no longer operating as a states house. I wanted to pose the question: what would happen if all non‐government senators came into this place and said, `Well, my vote is contingent upon my getting the best deal I can for the state I represent or the region within the state I represent'?

SPEECH.PARA: Constitutionally the Senate is a states house, but it has not operated as a states house for an awfully long time. I do not know whether it is a good thing or a bad thing, but the fact of the matter is that party politics has dominated this place. That leads to questions about the national interest versus parochial interests, sectional interests or geographical interests. When I was negotiating with the government on the workplace relations bill I certainly never had in my mind asking for $500 million for Queensland or $350 million for compensation for Victorians who had to live under Jeff Kennett's regime for all those years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—That might have been a reasonable thing to ask for, but the starting point for us was the national interest, the interests of all workers and employers and the fact that we had some starting points in common. If the agreements that have been entered into by Senators Colston and Harradine are to continue, I was making the prediction that we would see an American style gridlock, pork‐barrelling kind of politics that I do not believe Australians approve of.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of Americans have contacted me since I made those comments. In America before the election campaign newspapers published things like `Senator X got $500,000 for us. Senator Y only got $250,000. The better pork‐barreller is Senator X. Senator X deserves your consideration for voting.' That is not the way we have done things in this country. Maybe we are to do things that way in the future. We ought to look at what doing regional, parochial deals means.

If the government wants to look down the track, it might find that every piece of legislation, no matter what the principle involved, will now have a big price tag on it. Is that the price you want to pay? Is that the future you want for Australian politics? I have said many times and I will say it again, nobody minds losing a debate in a contest of ideas—debates on principle—but people do mind losing debates which have huge national interest implications. They do mind losing those debates on two votes where there are huge question marks about the rationale behind those votes.

That is the only point I want to make. I want to come back to this and say to Senator Harradine that the reason why people have fought so hard against the one‐third sale of Telstra is that the history of privatisation in this country shows that the minute you sell one little bit of it, the rest is gone. There is no guarantee what the balance of power equation will be in future Senates. There is absolutely no guarantee that, if it is a Liberal/coalition government, it will not be lining up as soon as possible to sell the rest of it.

Those of us who are really concerned about that have looked at AIDC and the Commonwealth Bank and that is why we feel so passionately about what only seems a little bit—one‐third. I go back to the lack of accountability and the identity crisis that comes with something which is a little bit privatised and I use the example of AIDC. When something is just a little privatised, there are the competing interests of two different sets of board members. There are those who are there representing the interests of the one‐third private shareholders. Obviously we know what their main focus is and it is a totally legitimate focus. Then we have the board members who are there representing the majority shareholders, the government.

Obviously, when we get into questions, I will pursue what this government minister will do when there is a conflict to resolve between the wishes of the one-third board members and the wishes of the two-thirds board members, particularly with respect to salary increases for board members. The history of privatisation throughout the world has shown that one of the first things that happens is that board members vote themselves huge salary increases. I remember Senator Gibson and me asking Senator Peter Cook when he was the responsible minister: why did the government not use its majority shareholding position to have some influence on the decisions relating to executive salaries with respect to AIDC?

One-third may sound a little bit, but it is the beginning of the end. No matter what assurances Senator Alston might want to give us, we know the history of privatisation. It is never going to be any different. The next argument becomes: `Sorry, there is a huge conflict between being a private one-third and a public two-thirds. It needs to be worked out. We need to make it 50:50.' Then the next argument is: `It is 50 per cent private and 50 per cent public, we might as well go the whole hog and sell the rest of it.'

I say to Senator Colston and Senator Harradine, who left one little tiny question mark in their speeches during the second reading debate: there is no way you can guarantee that the rest of Telstra will not be sold. There is no way any of us can predict what the balance of power equation will be in any future Senate. It is such a risk to say, `It is only a third and the government will have to claim a mandate for the rest.'

We all know what happens in election campaigns. As I recall, there were 55 policies in 35 days—some, of course, more prominent than others. I readily concede that the Telstra‐environment fund link was a major issue in the election campaign. I also reassert that, in every opinion poll that was taken—and I will get back to that when we get into the questioning—the majority of Australians said that they did not support the sale of one-third of Telstra; they did not support the link between the sale and the environment fund; and over two-thirds said they supported the right of the Senate to vote against the sale of Telstra.

You can see what is going to happen in a future election campaign. No matter what all the other issues are, if a coalition government is returned, it is going to claim that that is a mandate for the sale of the rest of Telstra. That is why those of us who believe it is the wrong thing to do have fought so passionately over a third, have not been consoled by it being only a third—what harm can a third do?—and have been at pains to point out that the money for the environment heritage trust fund could come from a whole lot of other sources.

That is why I have asked both those senators to think again about the loss of accountability that comes with a one-third private and two-thirds public board. The loss of accountability is something that we in the Senate should take very seriously. The government is still the majority shareholder. In whose interests are the decisions by that board going to be made? We should be looking at ministerial control.

We should be asking questions about these jobs in Tasmania and in Queensland. I do not deny that they are important—every Australian deserves the right to work—but we must not overlook the 25,000 jobs that are going to be lost. What guarantees are there that these jobs that have been secured exist beyond the next two or three years?

How do you weigh up and trade off the national interest on the future profit stream forgone against the interests of a couple of hundred jobs elsewhere in the country? I think they are very important and difficult questions, which I intend to return to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —This government's major slogan in the election campaign was `For all of us'. It should change that now to say `For all of us if you have political leverage', because that is exactly what it has done in getting this Telstra bill through. Unless you have political leverage, certain areas of Australia will get a disproportionate response to others; it does not treat all Australians the same.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the essence of the arrangements made and announced by Senator Alston. His release on Friday clearly demonstrated it. There was no trying to hide it. There was a bit of dressing up here and there saying that there were specific needs in particular areas of Australia. Nevertheless, there was not much hiding the cynicism in what Senator Alston was putting out.

This government, which has been critical of political correctness, now has a new definition of `politically correct'. You are politically correct if you live in a regional area or you are concerned with Tasmanian environmental things—that is the new politically correct group—but you are not so politically correct if you live in other parts of Australia.

Who speaks for the workers of Clayton and Concord in this country, who have been ignored in this particular deal? Are they to be disadvantaged because they did not elect an Independent at the last election or because I did not leave the Labor Party and cut a deal over this particular matter? Are they to be disadvantaged because I would not do things like that? They are being disadvantaged by this particular deal. We are not treating all Australians the same; we are being very selective.

There has been a lot of critical comment in the press over the weekend about the actions of two senators. As much as I might be cynical about them and as much as I might disparage the fact that they see their role as a senator as entirely different to mine, nevertheless, that is their attitude. They believe in being parochial. They believe in the politics of the pork barrel. I do not.

I never regarded myself as simply representing the electors of Victoria when I was elected to the national parliament. You must represent all Australians here. We are no longer a states house; we are a house that should be interested in the national interest.

So it is not so much those who demand who create the sin; it is those who give who create the sin. No greater sinners are present here in regard to this matter than Senator Alston and Senator Hill, because they are the ones who are playing the politics of reward. They are the ones who are offering the reward. I have nothing more to say on those who receive it. It is about those who offer it. Maybe that partly explains the lack of joy that was there on Thursday. They knew deep in their own hearts that they were being most unfair to a lot of Australians and being very fair to some other Australians.

So what we now have is not for all of us but for all of those who can screw a deal out of this particular government from the bottomless pit of the one-third sale of Telstra. If you are a telephone operator in Toowoomba, you may have a good future. If you are a telephone operator in Sunshine, Victoria—bad luck. I can tell you that, at the end of the day, if Telstra reduces its number of employees, it will reduce them by exactly the same amount whether this bill goes through or not.

What we are talking about is the point spread. Where will the job loss come from? It will not come from those who have political leverage; it will come from those who do not have political leverage. Therefore, what we have seen here is jobs in Burnie, Toowoomba and elsewhere traded for jobs in the other capital cities and other regional centres. All you have done is redistribute the pain. Again, the fault is not that of those who ask. The fault is in those who give. The fault is with Senator Alston and Senator Hill, who cut this particular deal.

Another point I want to mention is the great committee that we are going to have. I have not seen a logical exposition of what committee we are going to use. I re-read the Hansard this morning. Senator Harradine in his first contribution talked about a select committee. We have four select committees at the moment—about to come down to three—none of which has really been set up by the Labor Party, so it is our turn next select committee. Senator Alston in his contribution made no reference to the actual committee—none whatsoever—in his speeches. I do not know whether he has by way of press release.

Finally, in a second or third round contribution, Senator Harradine says, `Well, it should go to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee.' I ask: why should it go there? It is not part of legislation. We are going to have the third reading of this bill before the committee would have an inquiry. It is going to have no influence on legislation. Why should it go to the economics committee?

TALK.START.PARA: —It should have gone there in the first place.

—Senator Panizza intervened just when I wanted him to, because what a double-standard senator he would prove to be if he votes for this. I do not care which committee it goes to. You are the ones who made the great song and dance about whether this specific subject goes to a references committee or a legislation committee in all your plaintive speeches here early in May this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, if it were just being done on merit, it would go to the references committee. I do not care which committee it goes to, but it should go to the references committee. That might be a bit of a problem, because the committee system you imposed on us in 1994 leaves it with a Labor majority. So let's send it off to the legislation committee where at least there is a government majority.

Why send the redeemable preference shares issue off to a committee? I have not had one letter on that particular issue. It is being done as a sop to Senator Harradine. Fair enough. You refer it off to a committee. You really expect our people on the committee to put in three months intensive work. The moment the report comes down, everyone knows what is going to happen to it. You will hear the clunk in Senator Alston's rubbish bin from this chamber. Because he knows exactly what he is going to do with it. He is going to chuck it away.

So the question of whether the bill is proclaimed in May to accommodate this ersatz fake committee means absolutely nothing. The issue has been treated with contempt by this government from the start to the finish. From the moment Senator Harradine raised it, from Mr Costello's comments, it has been treated with absolute contempt. We now face the position that as a let‐out, as a rat hole in the back of the whole deal, this has to go to a committee which has to work hard for three months to bring down a report. No matter what it says, it is going to hit the bin. Why bother? Get rid of the sham right now. Why put the Senate Economics Legislation Committee—which probably has a meaningful workload—through this sham inquiry, which is going to lead to absolutely no conclusions.

Let's say the committee does get set up in the next two or three days. Let's say it can advertise before Christmas. That will be good. Let's have the first meeting on 6 January and see this minister come here and give evidence. You come along, Senator Alston, if you are serious about this. You give up your aardvark world tour and come along and give evidence to the committee all the way through January, and I will at least say that you are serious. But I bet you don't. I bet you don't treat the Economics Legislation Committee with any seriousness whatsoever. You would just go off on your world jaunt and expect everyone else to take part in a sham committee, to bring down a sham report that is going to hit your rubbish bin within five minutes of the ink drying.

So why do it? Why expend that amount of money on what is an absolute farce? Why not come out and directly say that this bill is going through on a cynical political deal and wear the consequences? The one thing we do not want you doing is going back and running all these platitudes before the electorate that you rule for everyone. You do not. `For all of us' is now `For all of us with political leverage'.

The other interesting development in all of this is that Senator Alston has spent the last six months talking down Telstra. In answer to question after question at question time we have heard Senator Alston talk this organisation down, saying it was inefficient, saying it was not world competitive—saying all these things. The tune changed as of last Friday. Now it is a great institution because you are trying to get the price of it up from $8 billion to $10 billion. I hope you do get it up to $10 billion. I do not want to see Telstra undersold. I do not want to see it undervalued. You have spent six months talking down the price of Telstra. You are going to have to do a lot of hard work to talk that particular price up.

The question has been raised, of course, as to whether this is the end of the sale or not. If this government had just come forward and said, `Look, we're going to sell a third of Telstra,' at least you could have regarded it as an honest approach. But, no, in a cynical electoral ploy, they had to link the sale of Telstra to the environment fund, to the natural heritage fund.

Why link it to that? You could have linked it to any number of expenditures if you wanted to. You could have linked it to defence expenditure or expenditure on legal aid. Why the environment? What was the magic about that—apart from political opportunism? Absolutely nothing. The very principle of governments tying either the sale or the revenue raising to a specific expenditure item is one that has to be regarded with great distrust. I know how much it is distrusted in Treasury and Finance. It should not be established as a principle of government that you tie a particular disposal to particular recurrent spending such as spending on the environment. Nevertheless, we have it here. At this particular stage of the debate, there is a need for rigorous examination of precisely what the details of the deal made are and whether they be can sustained.

People say that this government has a mandate. I also campaigned in the last election saying that, in government or in opposition, I would not support the sale of Telstra. So a mandate—as was proved again last Thursday—is a majority of one or two in this particular chamber, nothing more and nothing less. I am disappointed; I am disappointed because of the differential treatment that is being meted out. I am frustrated because people I represent cannot have their jobs protected or their environment enhanced simply because I did not have any political leverage in this particular matter. Because I did not have that leverage, they have to go out there looking for a job. While Senator Alston is enjoying his way around the world in January, some of my constituents will be walking the streets looking for a job that they might otherwise have had.

BREAK.PARA: It will not worry this minister's conscience, because he has shown no conscience on this issue. If ever I have seen a cynical exercise, it has been this particular one by the minister. He must bear responsibility for it. It is no use the newspapers trying to shift blame to Senators Harradine, Colston or anyone else. It is the minister in charge and the government he represents that must be held responsible for these particular arrangements. If these particular arrangements say that if you happen to live in Dubbo or Toowoomba you are a better person than someone who lives in Annandale or Concord or Clayton or Sunshine, then I think you have got it absolutely wrong. There is no even playing field for these particular individuals. They are being marked down because they did not have anyone who was willing to desert their political principles or party or willing to roll over and support this particular legislation.

Senator Alston, you should be absolutely ashamed of yourself for putting forward an inequitable proposition instead of coming out and trying to get it carried on its merits. You did not. The statement you put out on Friday is absolutely explicit, especially that part that refers to Tasmania and to Queensland. I reiterate that the proposal to refer redeemable preference shares to a committee is a total farce. Everyone has made up their mind about it—not that that would stop you sending something to a Senate committee, I acknowledge that. But why have them flog themselves around the country in January, February and March when the report cannot and will not influence the legislation? I do not mind the fact that it was a promise made by Senator Alston to appease Senator Harradine, but I do not see why we should pay the price of having to go out and work to pay the bill for putting it on the committee.

It is quite possible for us to say that there will be no quorum on this committee—that our two people will not attend—but we do not deprive committees of quorums, because it is a rather childish way to approach things. So we will have to turn up. Our two key economic spokesmen in this chamber will have to put in to this particular report. But we know the minister will not be there. The minister will be lying on the beach at Waikiki, having had one‐third of a day at the conference, thinking, `Gee, isn't it great to be a minister, sitting here in the sun on the beach at Waikiki while all those dopes back home,' including his own backbenchers, `are serving on an economics committee.' They will be flogging their way around the country doing a report that you intend to scrap the next day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise now in the hope that the committee will not anticipate debate. The last speaker has anticipated the debate on the reference of the matter to the committee.
—It is not before me. Where is it?
—You have anticipated the debate.
—Well, nothing is before me; how could I anticipate? Where's the amendment?

—You know precisely that the amendment is coming. I am listening to what you are saying. Aren't you happy that I am listening to what you are saying because I may, indeed, change the particular reference? I am listening to what you are saying and I think it is most unfair to make the comments that you did about the question of redeemable preference shares. I will be tabling in the Senate today a detailed response to the Treasurers's letter. I recommend that you read it. Once you read it, you might agree wholeheartedly with the reference of that matter to the committee.
—They have made up their minds; they couldn't care less!
—You couldn't care less?
—They couldn't care less, I am saying. They have made up their minds.
—I suppose they might care if they see, as I have seen, that a number of the statements in the Treasurer's letter to me are able to be shown as being completely wrong.
—You can have that thrill of exposing it.
—I have no thrill in this debate or in the debate generally about—
—I wouldn't think so.
—No, I was only laughing at a joke by Bosie here and they reckon it is because I was chortling about the so‐called deal.
—We know that.
—There is no deal.
—Of course there is.
—Everyone knows that.

—I enter this part of the debate because the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, has raised the matter. I listened carefully to what she has said. Senator Ray has also raised a number of matters. I seek the indulgence of the committee to respond to them. The simple position is that the government in fact did take the issue to the electorate. The electorate made its decision to support the government. I do not know how many would have voted on the basis of a sale of a third of Telstra for the redemption of debt and for the establishment of a natural heritage trust. But, nevertheless, there was a mandate. My view about mandates of popularly elected governments is that the Senate should not simply be obstructionist about them.
—What about migration; you voted against that.

—Thank you Senator Kernot—but the Senate should apply certain principles which if those principles and values conflict with the government's legislation in discharge of its mandate then those principles should prevail. On this particular matter I would have voted very strenuously against the total sale of Telstra.
—It is going to happen.

—May I just deal with that matter please. One had to make a judgment as to what the government would have done had we blocked the third sale of Telstra. My judgment was that the government would have used this as a double dissolution trigger. And if that occurred, if they pulled that trigger, then in the current climate you would have a total sale of Telstra. The only other way that the government can get through a total sale of Telstra during this Senate is to gain the numbers in the Senate. As I read the numbers they are not there for the total sale of Telstra. I would certainly vote against a total sale of Telstra.
—You are allowing it to happen.

—Excuse me. I would have allowed it to happen had I voted against the third sale. I would have allowed it to happen because if it went to a double dissolution you would have had a joint sitting of both houses of parliament with this bill as one of those bills which the government could put before that joint sitting. We would have been overwhelmed by the numbers from the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: I may have made a faulty judgment, Senator Kernot, I do not know; but I did consider that matter very, very seriously and I do not think I have been wrong on those questions over a number of years. But I could be wrong. But, nevertheless, coming back to the question of mandate, then you apply principles. In this particular case I saw that the Commonwealth would still keep, overwhelmingly on the board of Telstra, control and ownership of that instrumentality. It is all very well for the opposition to lambast us for what we have done. What did they do about the Commonwealth Bank? Flogged the lot of it! Qantas, flogged the lot of it! I suppose they can argue that the Commonwealth Bank wasn't a natural monopoly and I can see that is a possible argument. Nevertheless, that is what they did. I voted against the sale of the Commonwealth Bank and of Qantas.

But let me come back to the questions raised in this debate: the statement, quite unfairly made, that the government is undertaking some differential treatment of Australian citizens over this matter. That is preposterous; that in some way Tasmanians are getting better treatment than they deserve in this matter. Mr Chairman, you would know as well as any of us that what has been happening—the government decided to get the money. Why did they want the money? They wanted to get the money to help redeem debt and other amounts would go to the Natural Heritage Trust. Wasn't it quite proper for the government to consider the question of Tasmania's pre‐eminence in that area. Nobody denies that. The government accepted that pre‐eminence and disbursements from the funds should recognise that, rather than be made on the basis of population. It is quite fair and reasonable; nothing underhand in any of this. I wrote to the Minister on 2 August and laid it out in the open.

The second thing I was concerned about was that Tasmania, so far as Telstra is concerned, had become the tail end of the Vic-Tas country region, and we had suffered because of it. Was it not legitimate for the government to consider representations that that should be reversed? It did reverse it, and I congratulate the government for seeing logic in that particular regard. That is not treating some citizens differentially to others. That is just making up the leeway. We have been treated, in effect, differentially by Telstra.

TALK.START.PARA: —But is this the appropriate way of doing it?
—Yes. I would have thought that this—
—Trade off some Australians against others?
—No. The situation simply is that I was concerned that if there was a one-third sale then maybe the situation may get worse in Tasmania, so far as Telstra is concerned. That is why I raised it.
—How long will the jobs be there?

—I say about jobs: the Labor Party gets up here and rants and raves about this particular matter as though it were a deal. I am sorry: you were not ranting and raving, but you were making out as though it is a deal. It is not a deal—

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The now opposition when in government made the decision on deregulation

SPEECH.PARA: in 1994 and Telstra was about slashing 22,000 jobs right throughout Australia, some of which, of course, unfortunately—

TALK.START.PARA: —They started that after the new government.

—What about 2 February 1994? You have a look at that date, and I will remind you if you cannot remember. You were in government then and you know that around that time the Telstra board decided—not on that particular date but the correspondence is dated then—on slimming the organisation ready for competition.
—By one-third?
—No. Irrespective of whether I or Senator Colston had voted against the one-third sale, that was still in place and going on.
—To prepare for the privatisation.

—No. I have the details, and it has been preparing for the deregulatory environment post-July 1997. If you do not know that, you are ignorant of things. Finally, I make a point about regional and rural Australia. I believe that a great breakthrough took place. I think the government responded to the particular needs of regional and rural Australia.
—That is $250 million over five years.

—That is a start. I want to put this in context. I am not sure whether the substance of our debate is more appropriate for another stage of the debate, but I would like Senator Alston to confirm or otherwise the accuracy of what I have said in respect of what has been occurring in Telstra. Would he confirm that the question of the reduction of jobs in Telstra has been as a result of the expectation of the deregulatory situation in July 1997? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to make a contribution to the committee stage of this particular debate. I, along with a number of senators, listened with interest to Senator Alston's summing up of the second reading stage of this debate last Thursday. I think his speech is best described as one of the most infamous ever made in the Senate chamber. He threw political bribes around like confetti at the expense of the people of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and the territories. That is the truth of the matter. Senator Harradine's contribution, which we have just heard, that there was no deal involved, is extraordinary.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think it is a coincidence, Senator Harradine, that Senator Alston put out a media release headed `Telstra presence in Tasmania and Queensland'. He then went on to outline, paragraph by paragraph, the sleazy, cynical political deal that was done by the government on this issue. For you to be so naive as to come in here and suggest that we did not see a political deal or suggest that this media release and the government's announcement of the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund was just a coincidence I think is a most extraordinary flight of fancy on your part.

For my part, I believe, just as I am sure the majority of Australians believe, that a political deal was done to ensure that one-third of Telstra was privatised. And what a way it was done. The deal was unexplained except at the last minute by Senator Alston—funds for regional employment, the details about which we know nothing, and mysterious extra dollars for the Tasmanian environment, probably worked out by Senator Alston on the back of an envelope the night before he came into the chamber to make his speech. Side deals—sleazy, cynical political side deals. D-e-a-l-s, deals—that is what they were. Of course Senator Alston, the government and those who were part of those deals stand exposed.

No wonder Senator Boswell is here with one of his running dogs from the National Party. They are already in the media salivating at the idea of extra funds for National Party electorates. You can tell the National Party, Senator Alston. They sniff the pork in the barrels, and what rancid pork it is. The National Party, above all others in the parliament, can really recognise when due parliamentary process goes out the window, can't they? They know that there is far more chance that money will be paid out for party political purposes rather than targeting genuine funds to address social and environmental problems in this country. The coalition's normal slogan—the Liberal slogan, the National slogan—is: slush before accountability. That is what it is all about.

Here in the committee stage of this bill, without any sort of consultation, we have Senator Alston subverting the proper role of the parliament, announcing a committee to look at the issue of redeemable preference shares. That is what we have had. According to Senator Alston, the committee will `flesh out some of the arguments that Senator Harradine has put before the Senate and the public over recent months'. If you believe that you would believe anything. How naive!

At the same time this committee is supposed to be meeting, Senator Alston will be off on his overseas jaunt, on his extended overseas holiday. He will be considering all these issues lying on the beaches of Hawaii, riding the waves, getting the information back on the progress of the committee via fax machines, if he can be bothered, while he expects Labor senators and other senators to be concentrating on the matters at hand.

Senator Harradine has bought this absurd suggestion. Senator Harradine has swallowed hook, line and sinker that it is all right for this committee to meet and discuss these issues and they can report back some time after the third reading of this bill has passed the parliament. I am surprised that you, Senator Harradine, would be so easily conned by the government on this issue. It is so transparent. A school kid would not fall for that one, Senator Harradine. I do not believe you are not fully aware of the consequences of your support for such a course of action.

If you were being fair dinkum, Senator Alston, you would do something about appearing before the committee instead of going off on your holidays in January, instead of getting out of the country. Perhaps the result of the Mansfield inquiry is something you might care to give attention to instead of bludging around in Honolulu, London, New York and all the other places you are going to. You should be explaining your intentions to the people of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and the territories.

BREAK.PARA: You are being disingenuous in the extreme when you say that the redeemable preference share idea is certainly worthy of further examination. You know it has been bowled out of court by the government. You have passed the buck to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and he has rolled the black ball on it. You know that the government does not think this idea is worthy.

What the committee will do is nothing more or less than dismiss Senator Harradine's redeemable preference share option because redeemable preference shares, as you and other members of the government have said on so many occasions, do not happen to fit the ideology of your government. All you want to do is go through the motions and call up a few experts. As I said on radio on Friday, it is a fig leaf for Senator Harradine before the whole idea is unceremoniously planted in the waste paper basket in the circular file in your office, Senator Alston. That is the truth of the matter.

Now the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has changed his rhetoric quite dramatically on this issue. You would recall when Senator Alston indicated that the full privatisation of Telstra was inevitable and highly desirable. What was the reaction of the Prime Minister at that time? He got his doormat, Senator Alston, to come in. He put his doormat through the ringer and Senator Alston was told to get out and change his rhetoric. Mr Howard said at that time:

I am not completely satisfied as of now that there is a public benefit in selling more than a third. I would like to see how the third sale goes before I turn my mind to the sale of any more. It may well be the best thing is to have a period where one-third is owned by the broader Australian community as individuals with two‐thirds being in government ownership and much further down the track considering something more. Now that has been our position all along.
Oh, really, Mr Howard. It has conned Senator Harradine and Senator Colston apparently. In the newspapers over the weekend the headlines read `Total Telstra Sale Unstoppable: PM'. The article reads:

Mr Howard has told a group of senior lawyers that the full sale of Telstra is now unstoppable whether or not it retains government at the next election. In relation to further privatisation, it is really a question now of not if but when and how.

This is the government line that Senator Harradine and Senator Colston have fallen for. How extraordinary! How obvious! How transparent can you get? You were hauled over the coals as Mr Howard's doormat when you made that statement, but it is fine for Mr Howard to make it.

It is fine for Mr Howard to make it, but it is naive in the extreme of you, Senator Harradine, to come into this chamber and seriously address other senators and suggest that on the government's agenda is not the full privatisation of Telstra. I find it incredible that you could actually put that forward as a substantive argument in this debate. It has been completely exposed not only by the responsible minister, Senator Alston, but also by the Prime Minister.

We have a situation where you seriously put that forward in the chamber in a debate just a quarter of an hour ago. No-one would fall for that. You talk about the issue of mandate in the last election campaign. When Mr Howard was Leader of the Opposition in 1987, he simply dismissed any concept of mandate, saying that the mandate theory of politics from the point of view of proper analysis has always been absolutely phoney. He has argued long and hard about mandate since, but it never seemed to apply in any election that the Labor Party won from 1983 to 1996, let alone the elections that were won by the Labor Party in 1972 and 1974, when Gough Whitlam was the Prime Minister.

The mandate of the Labor Party on this matter is absolutely clear. We made very clear, as did every Labor member and senator, which included Senator Colston then, what our position would be. It is absolutely clear in our platform what our position is on any proposal to fully or partially privatise Telstra. We said, come hell or high water, we would oppose the partial privatisation or any other attempts to fully privatise Telstra after the election. We have honoured the commitment that we have made.

We also said that we did not believe it was appropriate to see environment funding in this country tied to the partial sale of Telstra; that environment funding should be hostage to the sale of Telstra. We actually believe it is important enough to fund off the budget in its own right, and we made those comments time and time again. We made that position absolutely clear in the election campaign. Now we are in the process of honouring that commitment that Labor senators, Labor members and those who signed a pledge of loyalty to the Labor Party at successive general elections have made.

Our national platform has been clear. Our commitments in the election campaigns have been clear, and we intend to honour them. Is this a proper way for a parliament to run? Is this a way to properly investigate a policy that is supposed to be for the benefit of all Australians? Is there an attempt on Senator Alston's part to distribute Commonwealth money in a fair and equitable way? The answer is no. It is a sleazy, cynical, transparent political bribe that the minister stands condemned for. It is the sort of pork-barrelling that has never been accepted previously in Australian politics and for which all those who are involved stand condemned. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to enter into this debate until the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) attacked the National Party. I want to point out to the Leader of the Opposition and to all those in the Senate that the Labor Party's campaign and its pledge to the people were to oppose the sale of Telstra. In fact, when we went to the polls all around the polling booth was `Do not sell Telecom. Vote Labor'. The people of Australia rejected it overwhelmingly.
—You have sold out as well. You don't care about the bush.
—Shut up, will you. You are a fool. You are a complete and utter idiot, and you know it and so does everyone else.
—You are a doormat of the Liberal Party. You cannot win anything anymore.
—Order! Senator Boswell has the call.
—Name him.

—No, don't name him. If he wants to carry on like a fool, let him. As I was saying, the Labor Party did campaign on the retention of Telecom, but where they failed was that their supporters did not see that that was an overwhelming reason to return the government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine is saying in his own words very clearly that he, as an Independent, has had to recognise that the present government, which has been formed by the Liberal and National parties, went to the polls saying very clearly that it would sell one-third of Telstra and that $1 billion would go to landcare and various other—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you cut it in the budget?
—Senator Cheryl Kernot, I know that you are tired and emotional about this issue and you are taking it personally.
—Don't be patronising.
—You are; you are taking this issue personally.
—Senator Boswell, address your comments through the chair, please.

—Mr Chairman, I am making the point: the Labor Party went to the people and said that they would not sell Telecom; this side of the parliament went to the people and said that we would sell Telecom and we would give $1 billion—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If they did not like it, they did not have to vote for us—and they overwhelmingly voted for us. We said to those people that we would give $1 billion to landcare and various other issues to rectify the degradation of Australia's environment. I would have thought that the Greens and the Democrats would have been overwhelmingly supportive of the idea that we were going to give $1 billion to promote programs that Australia is sadly in need of.

SPEECH.PARA: Caught in the middle is Senator Harradine. He has come to the conclusion that an overwhelmingly elected government has a mandate. He has tried to balance that mandate in his own way—and he should be commended by the Senate for the hard job that he has had to do. He has done it to the best of his ability, and he deserves commendation. He has given recognition to the government's mandate; he has recognised the overwhelming support of the people.

Oppositions senators come in here and say, `What about the workers?' Well, what about the workers in the woodchip area? What about the workers that you have had sacked with the demise of the Commonwealth Bank and every other thing that was possible to be privatised? You did not recognise the workers when there were thousand of them out here, with their trucks all drawn up, asking you for support; you did not recognise them. Do not come in here and cry crocodile tears because the workers have rejected you. The blue-collar workers rejected you out of hand and came over to the National and Liberal parties; they rejected you.

Senator Harradine has done a difficult job, and he has done it well. You have been rejected by your own constituency. So get back there for another three years. Try to develop a few policies which will get you back in. You will not make it in three years but, if you try real hard, you might get there in six or nine years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an exquisite irony in today's debate. That irony is related to the fact that the deal that the government is making in relation to the sale of Telstra is `whatever it takes'. The irony is that the very passing of the legislation will make it impossible for directions to take place in the public interest, whether for Tasmania or Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine has mentioned that there will still be the majority public ownership. Senator Harradine, please consider that under the Corporations Act it is not possible for the majority owners—that is, the public—to get public interest as the main component of the way Telstra will operate. Under the Corporations Act and with the Gambotto case for precedent, it is quite clear that the interests of the minority shareholders in maximising profits must—not can, but must—be paramount. Therefore, the very fact that you have the directional concern about whether or not there is broadband rollout in Tasmania, whether or not there is employment lost in Tasmania or Queensland, goes out of the agenda once there is minority shareholding. The very ability for this minister to even impose those changes without government direction, once there is a minority shareholding, is out of the window. That is the exquisite irony.

The irony also is that perhaps the concept of redeemable shares may be looking at that. But we had on the weekend Lenore Taylor saying to the media, `Well, Senator Harradine wants redeemable share options.' She also said that that is a pretty silly idea but did not give any details of that. There are two possibilities here. Firstly, Lenore Taylor may have looked at the legal, social and other aspects of redeemable shares—I doubt it. Secondly, she may have believed what the government spin doctors have been saying to the press gallery—and I think that is more likely.

But we know that all along the government has been saying those things about redeemable shares, so we know what the reality is. Once this bill goes through, the reality is that the interest of the majority of Australians—the public interest in providing telecommunications services equitably—cannot be enforced under this legislation with the way it has been drafted.

In fact, the opposition has circulated an amendment removing the ability of the minister to direct Telstra. Obviously, it will be interesting to see whether Senator Harradine supports the removal of that ability to direct Telstra. If he does not, then this whole deal, I would say, is worth nothing—nothing in the short term. There might be something right now, whilst Telstra is still in public ownership. But, in reality, this deal may legally be challengeable once this bill goes through.

This is the irony of what we are talking about today. We are trying to talk about realities. If Senator Alston can tell us why the Gambotto case is not applicable, I will be listening avidly. But that is not my understanding. Then there is the minority shareholders' ability to maximise their dividends and profits; if it is not considered to be the most profitable thing to guarantee broadband rollout to Tasmania, the minority shareholders have the ability to challenge that—and that is under the Corporations Law. I have not seen any changes to Corporations Law to nullify that. I have not seen any indications that that will not be the case. That is the irony of what we have seen today and also over the last few weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, sits over there on the other side of the chamber in all his vanity trying to look as if he is not smirking. In reality, this deal demonstrates what a weak, sneaky and unprincipled government this is. This deal exposes the fact that this government is essentially amoral. This is a government that has no principles. We have seen it for months in here where one line of argument will be pursued and, for the sake of momentary political advantage, another line will be taken. That is essentially what we are looking at here with this sleazy arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: For some years Senator Alston has made a political career out of alleging that other people have been engaged in deals. I recall a number of Senate select committees where he based a considerable line of argument on his belief that the Prime Minister of the day, Mr Keating, had been engaged in all sorts of immoral, underhanded arrangements. For instance, with regard to the ABC inquiry, all sorts of allegations were made about the way in which senior executives were behaving within that organisation. The same sorts of allegations were made in the print media inquiry.

We see quite clearly what happens when Senator Alston gets into office. There is no doubt about this whatsoever; this is a government founded on deals. This proposition is essentially founded on a crooked deal. I recall what you said, Minister, at the time of the print media inquiry. You said:

BREAK.PARA: We would also hope that all the dirty double deals of those opposite will no longer be tolerated and that, having been exposed and caught out in this instance, they will never ever try to do it again.
How weak and sneaky you now look. How hypocritical you are. How totally unprincipled you are.

What we have in this arrangement is an operation that essentially deals out workers in the industry, particularly in my and your state. I suppose it is fitting, coming from the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party, that you see nothing wrong with that. We see the whole structure of the Liberal Party in Victoria—this is the Ronnie Walker approach to policy making; this is the Jeff Kennett approach to policy making.

This deal essentially undermines the reasonable approach to public policy that one can expect. This is a discriminatory policy being pursued by this government which will directly disadvantage the people of the state you claim to represent in this chamber. It is a deal that essentially sells out city workers in particular. It is a deal that is cynical and flawed. Job arrangements already entered into with Telstra, which are founded on the presumption of privatisation, have been directed by CS First Boston as part of developing a prospectus aimed at securing benefit for the private shareholders rather than the public.

In relation to this proposition, we already know that of those job cuts 20 per cent will come from rural areas and 80 per cent will come from city areas. We already know, on the basis of answers given, that 70 per cent of those job cuts will be in Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane. You, in the most cynical of manners, suggest that somehow or other we could establish an infrastructure fund—to particularly direct money to pork‐barrel your way into getting a few votes in this chamber. It is a deal that fundamentally undermines research and development in telecommunications. It is a deal that fundamentally attacks the principle of accountability in terms of the way in which money should be expended.

It is beyond doubt that a disproportionate number of jobs will be lost in Victoria as a result of this sordid arrangement. Minister, I ask you a very simple question: is it not the case that the operator jobs in Queensland and Tasmania that are supposed to be created by this arrangement add up to about 140—30 in Hobart, 70 in Burnie and 40 in Toowoomba?

Is it not the case that you are proposing a new product called call connect? Is it not the case that you will be seeking to maintain this on the basis of a charge of some 70c to a dollar to directly connect customers seeking directory assistance—directory assistance that we could normally expect to be provided free of charge—and introducing a new charge which will be distinguishable by the new number imposed from the current 013 number that was operating across the country? Is it not the case that this service will not affect the total flow of traffic in the directory areas? Is it not the case that what we are looking at is a refunnelling of some traffic into these new service directory categories?

So the establishment of the new centres will not involve any new jobs at all. We are seeing a transfer of some jobs from some regions to new regions. The total number of jobs in Queensland, however, will not grow. There will not be an increase in the number of jobs as a result of this sordid arrangement; positions within the Telstra network in other geographical areas will be lost.

For instance, in Victoria and Tasmania they will still be operating one pool. Operator assisted services will not necessarily increase, but jobs will come out of other parts of that region. There will be a disproportionate attack upon workers in Victoria to pay for this sordid arrangement. At which Victorian centres will jobs be lost to provide for these 100 so-called new jobs in Tasmania? Similarly, of the 40 so-called new jobs in Toowoomba, how many will come from other parts of Queensland?

This proposition is essentially founded upon that fraud, and that is what it is—a fraud. I would be very surprised if you expected anyone to see it any other way. Very experienced politicians cooked this little deal up. Now they are going to come in here and suggest to us that this is a matter of high principle. There is nothing high about this and there is certainly nothing principled.

This is a deal put together by low‐lifes to get their arrangements in place in such a way as to undermine the normal legislative program that one could expect from the Senate. We all have obligations to the people of this country to administer legislation and our duties on a normal constitutional basis. There ought not be discrimination between citizens in one part of this country and citizens in another part of this country.

What is at the heart of this deal and is so obnoxious is the fundamental discrimination inherent in it. You put together, on the basis of some pork-barrelling arrangement, a proposition that gives advantage to some people in Tasmania and some people in Queensland at the expense of most people in Queensland and Tasmania and just about everybody in Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia and South Australia.

We have to ask ourselves: what was the arrangement before these matters were brought before this chamber the other day? Was it not the case that the business plan being considered by Telstra already had in mind these arrangements being entered into? Was it not the case that the business plan had already concluded that 22,000 jobs would be taken out of the system, that one-third of the company would be taken out the door? Wasn't that the direction of CS First Boston? Were those not the arrangements this minister had already entered into? Was is not the case that the project Mercury documents clearly identified the basis on which decisions were currently being made within Telstra—that is, that privatisation would proceed?

In relation to saving $600 million a year off the bottom line to give benefit to the private shareholder at the expense of those workers in Telstra, their families and those regions that have come to depend on not only the salaries and services provided but also the income to those towns, was it not the case that those arrangements were already in place? If that was not the case, Minister, why is it that for the first time in the history of telecommunications in this country the government is now paying Telstra for community service obligations? That is what is happening. This is a great innovation, isn't it—privatisation leading to a situation where the rest of us pay one of the most profitable companies in the country to provide community service obligations?

Was there a sordid arrangement that had taken into account what the business plan already said, or was it a new arrangement entered into whereby this company was for the first time receiving money from the government to provide what we would expect to be its obligations to the community as a whole? Which is it? I put it to you in those terms, Minister, because the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has made it perfectly clear that what we are engaged in here is nothing more than a sham. He says the total sale of Telstra is unstoppable, as was illustrated by the headline in the Sun‐Herald `Total Telstra sale unstoppable: PM'.

This is not a proposition dissimilar to the one that you put forward, that you were carpeted for but nonetheless clearly spelt out. That is the policy of the Liberal Party. There can be no doubt that the implications of the actions this chamber is taking is that this government will seek to sell all of Telstra within five years. The Sun‐Herald article states:
The whole of Telstra—worth up to $45 billion—will be sold within five years now that the ball has been set rolling, according to Prime Minister John Howard.
Mr Howard has told a group of senior lawyers that the full sale of Telstra is now "unstoppable", whether or not he retains government at the next federal election.

That is the Prime Minister's position that has been spelt out in articles. It is the position that you, Minister, have spelt out—or are you saying you have not? It is a position that is deeply held within the Liberal Party. I would find it extraordinary if any experienced politicians tried to pretend to us a position contrary to that. You must expect to enjoy a degree of gullibility. I am afraid it just will not wash.
What will be the consequences of these actions? This morning's Financial Review spells out the statistics, and even the National Party should be able to understand the discrimination inherent in—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are under the doormat—they cannot hear anything.

—Well, the doormats of the Liberal Party may well understand that, under this proposal, New South Wales rural residents will get $16 per resident, Victorian residents will get $22 per resident, and Tasmanian rural residents—that is, those living outside Hobart—will get $200 per resident. So the allocations have been made not on the basis of need but on the basis of a political fix, a stitch up, which provides this government with the relevant numbers it needs.

BREAK.PARA: The rules are pretty straightforward, aren't they? What are the principles we are operating under? As we have seen in recent times, it is always 35 votes to 37. That is the rule here, isn't it? That is the basis on which the government operates. That is what it is looking for, and that has been the pattern in recent years—winning by two votes. That is all that matters. A win by one vote will do this minister. We have to ask ourselves: what is the deep principle—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is called democracy, Senator.

—`It is democracy', we hear from one of the doormats from Queensland. What about the Labor voters who put a particular senator here on one basis but he of course votes on another? What about the democracy of being able to buy a few votes in Tasmania at the expense of the great majority of people of this country? What about the democracy that is involved with a proposition whereby we see a great Australian company being undermined, being sold off, being hacked in a manner to provide short-term slush funds for this government? That is what this is really all about, isn't it—providing you with a permanent source of funding for your election promises in the marginal seats across this country?

BREAK.PARA: The great matter of principle here is how long those opposite can stay in office. That is what this government stands for now, isn't it—standing for office? Remember the great principles of efficiency, the new world order, the new way of doing business? It is really all about providing the resources to government—and that means the numbers in here— to ensure that its policy is put into place as quickly as possible.

This is a minister who, as I say, will throw all principle to the wind to put together a deal, to put together a proposition, which is essentially unprincipled, is essentially weak and is essentially very sneaky. It is a proposition that we reject, and we will fight it all the way down the line. Minister, be under no illusion: you will get opposition all the way down the line because it is unprincipled, it is weak and it is sneaky.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak again in the committee stage. More details are becoming clear since the minister made his announcement in the parliament last Thursday at the end of his second reading speech. A subsequent statement was issued after the vote was taken late on Thursday afternoon, giving more details of the arrangements he had particularly reached with Senator Colston and Senator Harradine to obtain their votes and their support of the second reading. What an astonishing statement it is in its lack of detail, in its sloppiness and in its looseness.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we have seen—and Senator Carr has already mentioned this—the first area of `extraordinariness', and this is the way the fund of $250 million has been allocated around the states for this telecommunications infrastructure fund. Firstly, this is $250 million over five years. One should just point out that, in the same five‐year‐period, Telstra, as presently constituted, would be spending $20 billion on telecommunications roll‐out. Minister, I say that because you say in your statement on presence in Tasmania and Queensland that over three years some $12 billion has been allocated by Telstra. By extrapolation, that $4 billion a year over five years is $20 billion, give or take an odd billion here or there.
Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What I am saying is that, if Telstra is spending around $4 billion a year on broad capital works, that means that, over five years, the figure will be about $20 billion. In that same period, you are going to say that we are going to help fix all the problems in regional Australia for $250 million or $50 million a year. Compared to what Telstra is already doing, your bid is minuscule. I am telling Senator Harradine and Senator Colston what the minister has done, and what is now becoming clear. He has had access to the Telstra business plan; he has picked a couple of eyes out of it and has said, `This is what we will offer Colston and Harradine.' You offered them what you were going to do anyway. Of course, they think that $250 million is a sizeable amount of money, and for ordinary Australians, of course, it is. It is over five years; it is not over one year.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what has been put. You have got hold of the Telstra business plan. As I understand it, you have had it before you now for several months—maybe a couple of months. The old board that you half sacked approved it, and I understand that the new board has not disagreed with it. That business plan for the next three or four years has been before you now for several months. You have picked the eyes out of the business plan and sold it to Senator Harradine and Senator Colston as something special for them.

Let us look at the allocation of how you have done this to pay off these two senators. It is $250 million to be paid to the non‐rural residents outside the capital cities of each state, which has led to the most extraordinary misallocation on a per capita basis. Senator Carr has pointed out that New South Wales gets $16 per person, Victoria $22, Queensland $30, South Australia $67, Western Australia $57, Tasmania $208, and the Northern Territory $168. But the bobby‐dazzler of all is the ACT: they get $4 million for around 800‐odd people.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a capital city.

—Senator McGauran interjects. I am glad you have because what they have given to the ACT on a per capita basis is about $10,000 per rural person—outside the urban area of the ACT. This is the party that has abused the ACT, has attacked it as a waste of time to say it is remote. And yet they have picked what we ought to call the lucky 800. The lucky 800 have got hold of $10,000 each under this per capita grant. They will be pasting dollar notes inside telephone boxes in the rural area to find a way to spend it. This minister, in trying to get a formula that is rorted to give a bucket of money particularly to Senator Harradine, has to come up with this convoluted formula which means that 800 get $10,000 a head in the ACT. Senator Harradine, that is what they get. You did pretty well to get $278 per head in Tasmania, but you didn't crack it like the ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why this is a rushed and rorted job. They did not think of the ACT until the figures actually came out. I ask the minister this in this committee stage: when you reached the $250, and although you are giving it on the basis of a percentage of non‐capital city residents, in the raw figures, how could New South Wales get $37.4 million, Victoria $28.5 million, Queensland $53.1 million, South Australia $26.5 million and the Northern Territory $16 million and so on for the other states? The ACT got $4 million. Before you allocated it to the non‐rural area, how did you get the list broken up? This seems to have been done almost like throwing a dart at a dartboard: whatever number you hit, that is what you have got. This table clearly shows the rort, and the fix is on. Senator Harradine, if you do not happen to live in the rural area of the ACT—if you do not live down the back of the Brindabellas—you really have not done as well. Someone has done very well for the ACT. The per capita figures and the calculations show exactly how this has been rorted.
Senator McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Someone interjects from the National Party. Not even the National Party in the old days of the Country Party, going around with a carpetbag, would have had the temerity to put out this list of allocations, this absolute rort. You would have done a bit better in the outlying areas of New South Wales and Queensland, where your constituents are, but you were marginalised by Senator Harradine. He outdid you lot, the Country Party of old; John McEwen's Country Party would have died with their leg in the air before they let Senator Harradine take you down, Senator McGauran. The new National Party is now nothing more than a very sick leg of this coalition. When this debate continues, we will be saying a few more things on this rorted deal.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: Unauthorised Disclosures

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, the minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it a fact that details of a plan to crack down on unauthorised leaks or disclosures has actually been leaked? How many DFAT officers have been disciplined in the last five years for unauthorised disclosures? Is it the intention of the department that the leaking of the details of the retreat contained in the Sydney Morning Herald will be dealt with under the new provisions of the Public Service Act?
—I can recall that in the last five years under Labor there were many leaks from the Department of Foreign Affairs.
—Do you know how many DFAT officers have been disciplined?

—We have only been in government since March and I presume that this question is principally about the regime that existed under your authority. I do not have the answers to your questions, but I will find out and let you know.

—My question relates to the living standards of Australian middle income earners and is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. You would be aware of further evidence released last Friday by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling which found yet again that middle income earners were neglected by 13 years of Labor government. In particular, the evidence reveals that the real incomes of the middle 40 per cent of Australians were $12 a week less in 1993‐94 than in 1982. How is the government delivering for middle Australians and what are the benefits to middle income Australians of the government's policies?
—A good question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —As a number of people said around the chamber, this is a good question and it is a question that I am pleased to answer. I have seen evidence that supports the proposition that Labor left middle Australia far behind. For example, there were reports at the weekend that in a paper presented to the eighth national conference of the Australian Population Association Ann Harding suggested that:

ANSWER.PARA: After taking full account of inflation, there were declines in real market and disposable incomes received by the average Australian household between 1982 and 1993‐94.

Professor Harding continues by noting that the 40 per cent of Australians living in the middle of the income distribution faced a $12 a week real decline in their needs adjusted incomes during the 11‐year period.

Of course, there are always caveats to studies of this kind. But the study is quite consistent with what most Australians strongly believe, that Labor was not about helping middle Australia. Frankly, I cannot recall a constituent of mine ever saying to me that Labor looked after middle Australia. In fact, they did not and that is well known and they paid a heavy penalty. Labor have confessed as much following their massive defeat at the March election.

The shadow Treasurer, Gareth Evans, said that many Australian families earning between $30,000 and $40,000 felt badly treated under the Keating government. How right he was. In a report earlier this year a New South Wales Labor Party committee—which had Laurie Ferguson on it—stated:

Labor waged a back‐foot battle to convince the electorate that due to social wage gains poor Australians were better off. Insecurity was rampant and a central issue. Few believed that their conditions had improved. What they noticed was essentially wage stagnation.
The report went on to say:
Over time the Accord forced wage earners to make a disproportionate sacrifice to the process of restructuring the economy.

The coalition recognises that middle Australians did it very tough under Labor. This government is not going to leave middle Australia behind and our policies are aimed at ensuring that middle Australia gets the recognition and the support it deserves. For example, since coming to office families have enjoyed a $145 a month benefit on an average $100,000 loan through lower interest rates. The coalition is serious about securing a low interest rate environment and its policies aim to achieve that goal.

Of course, recently the government passed legislation fulfilling its promise to provide the $1 billion family tax initiative which will help 80 per cent of all families with children starting on new year's day. The government has introduced a budget strategy which will turn around the $100 billion debt which Labor left behind for Australian families to repay. Of course, the workplace reform bill aims to boost employment and raise living standards. The coalition was overwhelmingly endorsed by middle Australia at the election after 13 years of Labor betrayal and is now delivering on its commitments to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Newman representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Now that New South Wales has been forced by your government to consider cuts to dental services, including slashing budgets to the two major dental hospitals and charging some fees for public patients, do you now concede that your policy of terminating the Commonwealth dental scheme was wrong? Are you also aware that pensioners, the unemployed and their dependants holding health care cards will be charged substantial fees for these dental services? Will you concede that your government is hurting the poor, the needy and the vulnerable and that they are directly affecting public dental waiting lists and lengthening them from up to two to 11 years in some cases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Neal has a misunderstanding in her question.
—There is nothing new about that.

—Yes, it is pretty much typical, I guess. The situation is, as I have said in this place before, that there was a dental health scheme in place before the Commonwealth decided to introduce extra funds about three years ago. The Common wealth introduced the extra funds to reduce the waiting list. I am advised that these have been substantially reduced around the country. If the New South Wales government is choosing to consider cuts to the dental health program, it is and always has been the states' responsibility. The Commonwealth was simply putting extra funds in.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to people entitled to health care cards, we undertake the means testing of that so the states do know who would be entitled to their system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister may not be aware that funding of dental care was initially provided by the federal government—that is, the Whitlam government's provision of dental services to school aged children. She is probably not aware of that. What I really want to ask you is: will you now reconsider your heartless decision to cut the funding to the Commonwealth dental health program?

—I think a more appropriate question is: will the Labor opposition now reconsider their opposition to budget measures which have been occasioned by their misuse of the budget and by inadequate financial management? None of these decisions would have been necessary if the books were not in such a disgraceful state at the handover after the election on 2 March. I will be waiting for the day when I hear the Labor Party being prepared to say `mea culpa'.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, there has been widespread community concern following media reports over the weekend that the federal government is considering allowing mining in Kakadu National Park. Can you please inform the Senate whether these reports are correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It started from a story in the Sydney Morning Herald that referred to the draft management plan for 1996 of Kakadu National Park in which the current board and my department raised the issue of the definition of `wilderness' as a management zone within that park. The implication of the story was that, by addressing that definition of `wilderness' within the management zone, it might be permissible for mining to be a use.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, that is misconceived. Under the existing law, mining in Kakadu park is illegal. We understand that. It is because a decision was made that it was the best way to protect the conservation values of the park. It is a decision that we support. That is not surprising because no government in Australia's history has been more committed to environmental values than the Howard government. No government in Australia's history has sought to set up a $1.1 billion fund to reinvest in Australia's natural heritage. No government will be able to ensure, through the proper application of that fund, that the state of the environment is passed to future generations in better shape than we inherited it.

Consistent with a government that is committed to environmental values and is prepared for the first time to set up a massive natural heritage trust to reinvest in Australia's natural environment, yes, this story in its implication is totally inaccurate. We support the conservation values of Kakadu National Park. We support the legislative prohibition on mining. We will not be seeking to mine within Kakadu park.

In relation to addressing the issue of the draft management plan, yes, that will be addressed. That will continue. It is an internal one to allow legitimate usages under the law within Kakadu, including tourism, and that is for the best interests of all those who are interested in the future of Kakadu.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. A private health insurer in South Australia, Mutual Community, has an agreement with the universities in South Australia through their alumni associations to contribute to university scholarship funds if the alumni take out private medical insurance with Mutual Community. In the light of recent increases in premiums for private health insurance, does the minister support private health funds contributing to university scholarships rather than reducing premiums?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested in the fact that the Labor Party, apparently, are suddenly interested in private health insurance because for 13 years they neglected private health insurance. The mess that we have inherited with Medicare is clearly a part of it.

ANSWER.PARA: I have always believed that the private health funds should be doing more innovative things, both in terms of the products they deliver and in the way they sell their message to customers. I think this may well be one of those occasions. I do not have the detail of it, but I would be happy to pursue it if you would like to give me the details of it.

But, as a general principle, they are in the marketplace. They do have assistance from the Commonwealth. Nevertheless, they do have to get a message through to potential customers. We in government believe that people should be encouraged to get into private health insurance for the sake of the protection of Medicare.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Firstly, Minister, I am a bit surprised that you do not know anything about it because I asked extensive questions about this in the last estimates. Secondly, Minister, I have received a further letter from the University of South Australia that points out that one of the reasons it is doing this is the lack of funding from your government to universities. It also says that, if you do take out a membership, you will eligible for a very significant prize of a trip to either Cambridge or Harvard, at the value of $8,500 each prize. Minister, does this not seem to be quite over the top by way of persuading people into private insurance when those dollars could well be used to reduce premiums?
—I can think of no more wonderful prize to be offering than that. Are you decrying it, Senator Crowley?

—My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. I ask: has the government dramatically downgraded Australia's representation at the ILO, including giving up our ILO permanent representation? Does the government want to limit action on labour issues, including the exploitation of child labour, solely to the ILO rather than also being included within the WTO's purview? Can the minister advise the Senate: what is the government's attitude to the use of child labour by our trading partners? What is the level of the government's commitment to human rights in the context of international trade and minimum labour standards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert
