TALK.START.PARA: —The government would be appalled at the use of child labour in the way that I think Senator Bourne is recognising that, unfortunately, in some places children are so abused. Australia supports the pursuit of, and adherence to, core labour standards consistent with universal civil, political, economic, social and cultural right standards. It is true that we believe there are multilateral organisations other than the WTO in which it is more appropriate to address this unsatisfactory state of affairs.

ANSWER.PARA: As you indicated in your question, Senator Bourne, the ILO is one such organisation and, in our view, a more appropriate organisation. In our view, there are more appropriate bodies. We seem to have the support of an Australian tripartite working party on trade and labour standards, which earlier this year agreed that there was a more immediate prospect for constructive multilateral discussion of labour standards in non-trade fora. Consistent with our view on the role of the ILO, we look to that organisation which regards labour standards as being its core business, as having the central role in strengthening adherence to internationally recognised labour standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to answer the question?

—I know that you looked for a job there once, Senator Cook, but got rejected, if I recall. That is when you thought you were going to lose and you were trying to jump ship. Unfortunately for you, you did lose but they did not give you the job. What is more important than musing over the future of Senator Cook is that the ILO has estab lished a working party to examine the social dimensions of international trade liberalisation. The government will be retaining its membership at the ILO and will continue to play an active and constructive role as it did at the ILO's International Labour Conference in June of this year.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer, but I am sure he realises that maintaining our membership of the ILO is quite different from what we had before. If the government does believe that the ILO is the best place to consider labour standards, including child labour, and if the government does consider human rights to be important in this context, will the government be upgrading our membership of the ILO again to the level it was at before this government came into power?

—I do not know whether I have even acknowledged that it has been downgraded, as you seek to define it. What I said is that the Australian government will retain its membership of the ILO and will continue to play an active and constructive role within that organisation.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Newman. Minister, I refer to your announcement that women's groups will be forced to compete with other groups for funding rather than apply through the Office of the Status of Woman. Minister, are you willing to guarantee that the total funding going to groups providing services to women will not fall as a consequence of this? If women's groups are successful, does this mean a diminution in funding for other community organisations? What is a core group for the purposes of the new funding arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad to think that there is a Labor Party senator who is interested in the programs of the government, so I will be very happy to tell the senator some more detail. She actually said that women's groups would be forced to compete with other organisations rather than go to the Office of the Status of Women. Of course that is not true. We are opening up opportunities for women's organisations to achieve funding. We are talking about having two routes—one added to the other. One is that national or core organisations—the criteria of which will be announced—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—Applications for that core funding will be called in March next year. We believe a number of the other organisations have a specific involvement in a particular portfolio. They have lacked influence over those portfolios and those portfolio ministers, as we saw during the previous government, because their voices are not heard as are other organisations which do receive.
—Give us an example.
—I think it is very appropriate, for example, that women with disabilities should be funded by the health portfolio, where they have a particular need for it. They are now being funded out of that.
—Are you going to allocate extra money for that group? No way.

—They do ask questions, but they seem to have terrible trouble listening to answers. The point is that we believe it is very important—as Hillary Clinton emphasised when she was here—that women's organisations be mainstreamed. For too long too many of these women's organisations have been left in the girls' sandpit and, therefore, carefully ignored by other portfolios.

ANSWER.PARA: If people like Senator Reynolds and Senator Crowley were being honest, they would acknowledge that many women's organisations have gone to other portfolios and been told, `No, no, no, you go and get it from the Office of the Status of Women. That is where you are cared for.' That leaves them only being heard, in policy terms, by one part of one department. We believe it is very important that women in agriculture, for instance, have an impact in the primary industry portfolio and that women who are particularly concerned with health issues have an important impact there.

Those are very important considerations which we believe will enhance the opportunities for women and women's organisations. I point out to you that not only did I announce the funding arrangements, I also announced greater opportunities for input and coordination—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you announce the funding proposal?
—Senator Mackay, you are persistently interjecting.

—Thank you, Madam President. The women's organisations have not had the sort of opportunity to be heard in government because the previous government was only interested in big peak bodies. There are lots of voices around Australia which are not big national organisations. We have set up a mechanism of using the women from our parliamentary party to contact people in the communities so that—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—The Labor Party does not like to acknowledge that so many women came into the parliament on our side at the last election. They are very appropriate to act as contact points for women's organisations in their home states, to attend conferences, to attend workshops, to bring back messages of importance to the Commonwealth and to take Commonwealth messages back to those women's organisations. I announced that in August next year there will be a two‐day conference of women's organisations. They will have an opportunity to meet with ministers—
—Order! The time for answering the question has expired.

—Minister, I asked three specific questions in that first question, so, in my supplementary question, I will ask you another three. Firstly, can you please define what the criteria are for the core group that you have alluded to in your answer? Secondly, can you tell me how the groups that currently receive operational funding and that will lose their operational funding on 31 December will survive until next March? Thirdly, can you please advise the Senate as to my first question: whether or not funding levels will be maintained for women's groups regardless of whether or not they are funded through the Office of the Status of Women or other departments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the Office of the Status of Women or other departments—it is both. The opportunities for women and the funding available to women have increased. That is that one. I have already said that the criteria for what are core groups will be announced when applications are called in March for that core funding. For the other organisations it will be announced in the budget.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as those groups that are supposed to be collapsing on 31 December are concerned, perhaps, Senator, you did not register: we have not only extended their funding for the first six months of this financial year, I announced last week that we were extending it for the next six months. Nobody is without funding. They are getting two years funding in a row, which is unprecedented. Under your government and previous governments they were funded annually. Because of the uncertainty caused by the review of all non‐government organisations—women's and others—they have been extended for a extra 12 months. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —My question goes to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, on 14 October in Newcastle you announced that the government was:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . determined that regional forest assessments must include at least broadscale assessments of mineral prospectivity.
You went on to say:

Our objective is to ensure that any new forest reserves set up under the process provides for management plans which do not unnecessarily exclude access for mineral prospectivity, mineral prospect exploration and mining.

I ask: can you confirm that the government's so‐called comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system will in fact be conclusively influenced by mineral prospectivity and that the environment minister, Senator Hill, has agreed with you on this matter? I finally ask: is it true that, in Western Australia, important high conservation value jarrah forests are set to be put into the government's second‐class reserve system because they are on top of bauxite deposits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat—I think Senator Brown has asked me this two or three times in two or three different ways—that I would like to absolutely reaffirm that neither this government, myself, Senator Hill, the Prime Minister nor anyone else has any intent to mine in national parks. I will say that answer over and over again.
—Why couldn't cabinet decide the matter? Why were you sent off?
—What are you talking about? Being sent off? Who is down the back of the chamber!
—Order!

—This whole debate, of course, is about the RFA process. This is a matter of negotiation between the federal government and the states. Senator Brown would know—even though I don't think he recognises it—that basically land management is a matter for the states. It is not a matter for the Commonwealth, except in Commonwealth government areas. Senator Hill made it quite clear early in question time—it is something with which I entirely agree—that there is no intent whatsoever to mine in national parks in the Northern Territory, including Kakadu.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me also say that in regard to your so‐called high conservation areas in Western Australia—I know you don't like to hear this, Senator Brown, but—you might recall that Alcoa did mine bauxite in the jarrah national parks in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it won one of the environmental awards.

—It won an United Nations environmental award for rehabilitation, Senator Hill. We have said right through in this place that, while we certainly recognise the RFA system, there has to be some commonsense and balance across this whole issue. I think I have said in this place be fore—it is something that I think you might have some difficulty relating to—that we are looking for common sense and balance and that we are looking for a system where, in some instances, you can have multiple and sequential land use. What that means, of course, is that any sort of proposal in areas where you would have multiple land use would be subject to extensive and proper environmental impact assessment processes.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has ducked the question again, but I will ask it again and try to be explicit. Is the primary parameter for the establishment of these comprehensive and adequate reserves—I am not talking about national parks, and you know it—the intention to mine? I ask you explicitly, because you have now given tacit agreement to this line of thinking: will you be influencing what the Minister for the Environment has to say on forests in Western Australia to ensure that there are not comprehensive, adequate reserve systems over bauxite mining? Or will you be implementing your new twist to this story by saying that, if they are, they can be logged and later rehabilitated to get a UN award?

—Let me state again, for Senator Brown's information, that the whole RFA process is a matter of negotiation between the states and the Commonwealth government. In the end they are responsible for land management use, but a negotiation process will take place. As to the categories that you talked about, where you have areas that are designated as being of high environmental value—I have forgotten the exact term that is used—they will certainly be categorised under one to four under the IUCN where mining will not be allowed. This is an area that has the support not only of this government but also—much to your surprise, Senator Brown—of the mining industry itself.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, I refer to your answer to my question on notice of 21 October relating to consultancies. In that answer you indicated that your department engaged Russell Reynolds Associates on 30 September to conduct `an executive search for an agency CEO' at a cost of $170,000. Can you confirm that the agency concerned is the proposed Commonwealth service delivery agency? Has Russell Reynolds Associates identified a suitable CEO? When do you expect the CEO to be appointed and on what basis, given there is no agency to administer? Do you believe the expenditure of this extraordinary amount of public money is justified?

—Senator, the Commonwealth agency you refer to is the one‐stop shop—that is another way of describing it—which is proposed to be established by the government next year. The executive search people have been looking, on the instructions of the department, for suitable people to short-list. I have had no such short list as yet. Therefore, as to when and on what basis, I am not able to give you any further information. It has not come along that far yet.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the minister has indicated we will be looking at next year, and she is not advised as to a final decision but has been advised of a short list, I ask the minister: why is it indicated in your answer to my question on notice that the request was on a restricted tender urgency basis when there clearly was no urgency?

—The senator misquoted me. I certainly did not say that there was a short list; I said that I have not yet been advised of a short list. The situation is that our chief executive officer is needed in an interim capacity to get the agency established. The sooner that that can be achieved the better. In the meantime, both Senator Vanstone's department and mine are working continually, in a very strenuous way, to achieve decisions on how the agency will be set up and how it will proceed. At this stage, no proposals have come to me for consideration as to who might be the interim CEO.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications. I refer to Australia Post, which is wholly owned by the Commonwealth. Will the minister confirm to the National Competition Council whether Australia Post, with its rapidly growing stationery and book retailing activities, has a competitive advantage over private newsagents and businesses selling similar products by means of taxpayer funded rents and employees and other business costs?
—We used to get asked this regularly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I think it has been around for a while. Nonetheless, it is a matter that needs consideration.
—Compare your answer with ours.

—Ever since Australia Post became a government business enterprise in 1991, it has had an obligation to act commercially. That means ensuring that it operates in accordance with sound commercial practice and that it gets a proper rate of return on its assets and its investments.

ANSWER.PARA: It is permitted, under the Australian Postal Corporation Act, to use any spare capacity to undertake various types of business activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to send Ron a card from Honolulu?

—You will get one if you are lucky. In recent years, as it has upgraded its range of products, it has been extending the products available to greeting cards and stationery, amongst other things. Concern has been expressed from time to time—I certainly get letters on this subject—about whether or not Australia Post is using its profits to cross-subsidise its activities in those areas. That has been a matter for examination by both the Auditor-General and the Prices Surveillance Authority. Indeed, each has given a clean bill of health to Australia Post practices in this regard.

ANSWER.PARA: Nonetheless, we do acknowledge that it is necessary to maintain continuing scrutiny. Therefore, we announced in June this year that, through the legislation review schedule, as part of our commitment with the states and territories under the competition principles agreement, there will be a review of the Australian Postal Corporation Act. That review will consider the remaining limits on competition to postal services. Currently, Australia Post earns in excess of 50 per cent of its revenue from non-protected areas, even though it continues to have protection for the reserve letter service.

The principles that will govern that review will be those determined by the National Competition Council, and the review will be conducted by the council. The terms of reference will include issues such as access to infrastructure—interconnection—pricing, competitive neutrality and regulatory restrictions on competition. The national competition reform principles agreement provides that legislative restrictions on competition should be removed unless it can be demonstrated that the benefits of such restrictions to the community as a whole outweigh the costs. So the review will examine issues such as the extent of the reserve letter service and Australia Post's continuing involvement in ancillary businesses, such as the one that Senator Boswell has quite rightly addressed.

As a result of that third inquiry in recent years, we will be able to put to rest the concern that some might otherwise have—particularly in the small business sector where they are in competition, either through newsagencies or other retail outlets—that a very large player is somehow using its resources to unfairly compete against the smaller players.

As I say, none of the evidence to date has supported that proposition, but I understand the continuing concern that people would have. Therefore, we want it examined yet again to ensure that consumers are getting the best value for money, but not at the expense of small businesses. I think we can accommodate both of those concerns. I commend Senator Boswell for bringing that question to the government's attention once again.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. In answer to a question from Senator Murray regarding foreign investment, you stated that the rules which provide for the rejection of foreign investment on the basis of being contrary to the national interest test are likely to be weakened. In particular those considerations relating to national security, public order, environmental protection and heritage issues were singled out by you as areas for change. Could you explain, in regard to those four areas that you singled out for change, when they would be considered important enough to be contrary to the national interest test and how your proposed change differs from the current test.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Sherry said, Senator Murray was kind enough to ask some questions in relation to foreign investment and I responded to those questions. As you know, the rules governing foreign investment have been in place for a considerable period of time, as have the current procedures. The government seeks to ensure that any foreign investment in Australia is not contrary to the national interest.
—Oh, really!

—I am surprised that you find that surprising. I thought that was the policy under your government. There are different rules, as you know, applying to sensitive areas of the economy—and non-sensitive areas. Under the individual APEC action plan, which I think Senator Sherry was referring to, the government committed itself to reviewing by mid‐1997 the screening system for foreign investment in relation to non-sensitive areas. We stated in that action plan:

ANSWER.PARA: Review, by mid-1997, the screening system in relation to foreign investment in `non-sensitive' areas. This would possibly include: limiting the criteria for rejection using `contrary to the national interest' test to considerations relating to national security, public order, environment protection and heritage issues.
As I said, this is a review process and those are the issues we will be looking at.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We know all that, Senator, but you have not provided us with any detail of your proposed review. You might also consider that, in relation to the rationalisation of investment policy for real estate, in the same answer you stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Whilst rationalisation is likely to involve some overall liberalisation, this would be quite limited.
Can you therefore inform the Senate what these limited changes will be in the area of real estate?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, we are planning to review the matters which I referred to in my earlier answer. There are strict rules, as you know, applying to residential real estate. As I have said before, the general prohibition on the purchase by foreign interests of existing developed real estate—houses, flats, et cetera—will be maintained.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. On Friday the Queensland government announced that it would be moving to connect the power grid to those north of the Daintree River. This means powerlines over or under—most likely over—and through the world heritage area and it means, in particular, the opening up of large tracts of land up there for development, including, I understand, some 1,000 at Cow Bay. As you know, putting power through this sensitive area is prohibited in the draft joint management plan for the Daintree. Do you still support the provision in the draft plan that prohibits powerlines crossing the Alexandra range? Do you agree that the Daintree rescue package will now not go as far as it would have because land prices are going to go up substantially? Finally, are you aware that these proposed powerlines are likely to bisect existing national park and also bisect land purchased under the Daintree rescue package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reasonably familiar with this issue. I have discussed the issue with residents of the Daintree region. As a matter of interest, I found that about 50 per cent wanted the extension of power and about 50 per cent were opposed to it.
—How do you know that?

—Because I met with a representative collection, Senator Faulkner. With regard to the issue of my responsibilities in relation to the world heritage area, I was comforted to receive correspondence recently from Mr Gilmore, the relevant Queensland minister, to say that any decision the Queensland government took would be subject to completion of the plan of management under the wet tropics, and also land clearance controls by the Douglas Shire Council. I presume that those commitments still stand.

ANSWER.PARA: I said also to the Queensland government that I believed any assessment of an extension of the powerlines—as you know, Senator, the powerlines actually cross the river in a number of different places and do extend into the Daintree already, so this a question of a further extension—should be subject to an environmental impact assessment in which not only the state participants but also the Commonwealth participates. I suggested, because of the special interest in relation to this matter, that local government should participate in that process as well. That basically remains my view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does this mean your government will support a change in what is now the draft wet tropics management plan to allow the power lines to go over the range?

—The draft is, as you say, a draft, and it is still subject to negotiation. What I have said is that I understand my responsibility to ensure that the World Heritage area is not damaged by any extension of power. With the assurances that have been given by the Queensland government that I mentioned a moment ago and then further to that a proper environmental assessment study that includes the three tiers of government, I am sure I will be in a better position to make the decisions that are necessary to protect those World Heritage values.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, you would be aware that a very large group of Australians are attending anti-racism rallies across the country. Minister, are you aware that the Australian vice chancellors recently condemned the federal government on race issues? Do you now acknowledge the concerns of the vice chancellors that the reputation of Australia's institutions and their capacity to generate more than $1 billion a year in fees from foreign students are under threat from what the vice chancellors assert `appears to be a rising level of racial discrimination'? Specifically, do you agree with the AVCC President, Faye Gale, that the considerable benefits to Australia from the participation of international students and academics is now at risk by the impression that there has been a rise of racist views in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for his question. You would have to be living in a cupboard not to be aware of the support for an anti-racism campaign around Australia and I welcome that. As to the specific remarks of vice chancellors and the head of the vice chancellors committee, they have not been drawn to my attention, but I will make a point of seeking them out and having a good look.

ANSWER.PARA: I can assure you, Senator, that on a recent trip I made to Malaysia, Indonesia and India associated with higher education the only occasions on which these matters were raised with me other than one in India were by Australian journalists overseas. They were always the first and they jumped in ahead of local media who were invited to get a clear understanding about what the government was doing, what the Malaysia‐Australia Foundation was doing celebrating its first alumni convention in Indonesia, for example, signing a memorandum of understanding vis-a-vis tourism, trade and so on, through to the Australia‐India New Horizons Foundation.

I have, however, heard anecdotally from one or two vice chancellors that these matters have been raised with them—no more than this—when they have been overseas. It is a matter that I will be keeping a very close watch on. As soon as I have anything to report back on any substance to the Senate, I will obviously do so.

Senator Carr, you have this assurance: it is a matter I take importantly, not as a function simply of the money we earn by higher education exports, which I do acknowledge is substantial, but from the simple point of view that I do not believe Australia is a racist country, whether in the higher education industry or any other industry. But since I am responsible for higher education, I would not be happy for that image of us and the higher education industry to be portrayed overseas.

BREAK.PARA: I acknowledge that one of the key benefits of international students coming to Australia over and above and separate from the income provided to universities is the enriching of the undergraduate experience for Australian graduates. That was clearly recognised in the assessment of this year's university of the year, which was the University of New South Wales.

You may well be aware, Senator, that the undergraduate experience and the involvement of international students is a key part as to why the University of New South Wales was selected or why any universities would be selected to be successful in getting that award. It is a very valuable role in higher education quite separate from the issue of income that is raised. For that reason, in addition to the concern about income raised, I will be keeping a close eye on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you believe that your recent visit to Malaysia and India has helped dispel those fears amongst foreign academics and students. I presume that is what you are suggesting. What plans do you have to similarly dispel those fears amongst academics and students throughout the rest of the region? What action is this government undertaking to dispel those fears about concerns that there appears to be a rising level of racial discrimination within Australian universities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I am afraid you have misunderstood. It may be the case that previous ministers have announced, as a consequence of their visits, that great and wonderful things happened and the world lay down before them. That was not an assertion I made. I simply indicated to you that on that trip, which was for the purposes of negotiations vis-a-vis primarily higher education, the matter was always raised with me, except for once being raised with me in India, not by way of complaint but by way of question, first by Australian media who pushed in over and above local media. That is what I told you. So I did not make that assertion. If it occurred to you that that was what I was saying, it is only a function of the ego of previous ministers of your former government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, how important is reform of Australia's social security system? What benefits will there be for Australians if the government's budget program is implemented in full?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is that reform is vital, but I intend to give the Senate a bit more information than that. We need to improve the effectiveness of the system because, as the Labor Party found when it did its wash‐up evaluation of its position after the election, the concern about the social security system was one of the reasons people gave for why the Labor Party did not get re-elected.

ANSWER.PARA: More importantly than that, if we do not have a social security system that people can respect, we have a problem for those who are genuinely entitled to benefits because people will consider them to be using the system. They will not have the respect that they are entitled to. Also, we have to give a fair go to the taxpayers who are funding the system. It has to be acceptable to the taxpayers as well as fair to those who are entitled to benefits.

The situation is that the taxpayers over the last 13 years really copped it from the previous government. Senator Kemp has already referred in question time to Professor Ann Harding's study which was released last week. That exposed exactly the results of the ALP stewardship in which Australians over the last 13 years have really changed their positions. The ALP trod water for 13 years, but an awful lot of Australians got very much poorer. The middle 40 per cent of Australian households lost $12 a week, but what happened to the top 30 per cent? They went up by 15 per cent. So while the middle 40 per cent were losing $12 a week, the richest 30 per cent were earning an extra $15 a week.

I welcome the fact that there was an improved share of income for the poorest Australians. Of course I welcome that. Nevertheless, people are being asked to pay for a social security system of $40 billion. That is four times what we spend to defend our country. Therefore, that money has to be spent wisely and carefully otherwise the support for the system will disappear. The ALP do have a chance to make amends for the situation that they handed over to Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —What can they do to atone?

—What can they do to atone, asks Senator Alston. By passing the budget which we have introduced, which has been recognised by the Australian people as tough but fair and which is certainly needed in order to redress our financial position as a nation, and by allowing us to introduce our social security reforms, they have an opportunity to redeem themselves in the eyes of the nation; in the eyes of the people whom they squeezed so badly. Our reforms are designed to achieve a few goals. First of all, they are designed to improve self-reliance for the people who can look after themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on my left.

—I would not have thought that people would regard it as unfair that those who have the means should be asked to first support themselves before they look to the taxpayer. With regard to the issue of over‐55 superannuation, you would have to ask why it is that people who have their retirement savings in their small business or in some shares or a flat or something like that should be means tested when their neighbour who has superannuation of the same amount is not. Most people would believe that that is unfair and that somebody with $250,000 worth of superannuation should be prepared to look after themselves. If they had $250,000 in shares or in property, they would be expected to. (Time expired)
—And now you have a high level supplementary.

—Yes, I have. Minister, have you seen the reports of the Democrats' view of your social security reforms? Is their criticism of the reforms accurate, or do the Democrats appear to misunderstand the government's position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, the Democrats do have some misconceptions, despite the effort to try to help them understand otherwise. For instance, in terms of tightening the activity test, we have made every provision to protect people with low literacy skills, people with psychiatric problems and non‐English speakers, in contrast to what the Democrats are claiming. We have found that, amongst the claims of the Democrats, the misconceptions are just rife. One hardly knows where to begin to try to set them straight on the measures that they claim they are going to oppose.

ANSWER.PARA: I would be very happy to give the Democrats further briefings if we can help them to understand why our measures are fair. For example, it is clear that most Australians do believe that it is not unfair to ask migrants who have sponsored themselves to honour their commitments and wait before they access social security benefits. I have found existing migrants to this country believe that is fair also. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I draw your attention to your failure to provide answers to questions regarding Mr Fahey and his involvement in Lockreagh Investments Pty Ltd which you took on notice over two weeks ago. I therefore ask again: have you categorical advice that no liability for taxation arises from section 108 of the tax act regarding the directors' loan from Lockreagh to Mr Fahey? Why have you and Mr Fahey deliberately misled the parliament by stating that all relevant documents regarding Lockreagh have been lodged with the ASC when the ASC have no record of any documents being lodged? When will you refer these issues to the ASC and the tax commissioner for full and proper investigation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the question that I have just received from Senator Conroy, fresh from his triumph at the federal executive recently. One of the problems of your party is that you seem to be a totally policy free area. Your colleagues obviously do not wish to ask that question in the other place, because Mr Fahey is in the other place. What clearly happened is that your questions committee went over and said, `Would you mind asking this question to Mr Fahey?' They basically said—putting it politely—`Get lost.' That is the reason you are asking this question here now.

ANSWER.PARA: I will have to read carefully what you said, Senator Conroy, but I think you may have misled the Senate slightly in your response. I said that I would refer the matter to Mr Fahey and see whether he wished to make any response or words to that effect. Seeing you have raised it again, and seeing your colleagues refuse to raise it in the other place, I will again refer this—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order.
—This is to cover up your job application.
—You are wrong about that. You have never bothered to get your facts right.
—Senator Cook, I will be pleased to listen to your point of order when there is sufficient silence in the chamber to enable me to hear.

—My point of order is on relevance. We have now had Senator Kemp answer or attempt to answer this question for at least two minutes. He has taken us on a tour of all other things but the question. Madam President, I wonder whether you would not mind directing Senator Kemp to be relevant and actually break his duck and answer the question for the first time in his life.
—Order! There are still two minutes and 41 seconds for Senator Kemp to get past his preliminary observations on the matter and deal with the question.

—Thank you, Madam President. Before the point of order from Senator Cook—and I was surprised that he jumped to his feet on that matter—I was saying that I would refer the matter to Mr Fahey to see whether he wished to make any response.
—What about the ASC?
—But as you have raised that issue again, I will again refer it to Mr Fahey.
—Through the ASC?

—As far as the ASC is concerned, as I said before—and I will stick behind what I have said—I would not refer anything to anybody on the basis of the say‐so of you, Senator Sherry, or Senator Conroy. That remains my continuing position on that particular issue.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it appropriate for the minister to breach the Corporations Law and then engage in a sloppy attempt, with your assistance, to try to cover it up?

—Senator Conroy, the incredible assumptions which underlie the proposition you have made barely warrant a reply from me or anybody else. But I will reply, Senator Conroy, because I know that you are young and enthusiastic and eager to make your name on that side of the chamber—and there is a dreadful lack of talent on that front bench, I can tell you, a dreadful lack of talent. Because we wish to see what we can do to assist, I will refer that matter to Mr Fahey and get back to the chamber if he wishes to make a response.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—On 5 December 1996 the Acting Deputy President, then Senator Calvert, undertook to refer to me his ruling that the word `ignorant' referring to a senator should be withdrawn. The Chair has ruled on several occasions, most recently in 1993, that the word `ignorant' when applied directly to a senator is offensive within the terms of standing order 193. Senator Calvert was therefore entitled to rule that the expression should be withdrawn, having regard to the manner in which it was used.

—Last week Senator Faulkner asked me a question in regard to the possible relocation of the CSIRO division of petroleum and gas to Western Australia. The minister has advised that the proposal to establish a national petroleum and mineral centre at a site adjoining Curtin university has been under consideration for some time. The former government had considered this proposal and failed to provide support for it. The CSIRO has advised the government that it is committed to the centre and will moved the division of petroleum and groups from the minerals division. The government will continue to examine the issues surrounding the proposal in the ordinary course of business.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week on 5 December Senator Crowley asked me a question regarding the privatisation of the Public Service computer network and also referred specifically to EDS, electronic data systems. As I indicated in my response last week, the issue of outsourcing of government IT systems has been under active consideration. The Office of Government Information Technology, OGIT, and the Department of Finance are midway through a data collection exercise covering the government's IBM and compatible data centres, mid range platforms and desktop systems. This will be an input to the development of a business case for IT consolidation and outsourcing which will be considered by the government in the 1997-98 budget.

QUESTION.PARA: As to the issue of which companies might pick up outsourcing business from government, this is still to be determined. There are some multinational companies, including those nominated by Senator Crowley, who are in this line of business and can be expected to bid for contracts that might eventuate. There are also Australian known companies who are doing outsourcing work and could be expected to compete, depending on the nature and scale of the work.

BREAK.PARA: The government expects there to be a number of service providers for its IT infrastructure across a number of areas, thus avoiding the establishment of any monopoly situation with one service provider. We should not lose sight of the fact that most of the major global IT companies now have significant operations within Australia. Further, through the partnership—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you have the answer incorporated in Hansard ?

—Only because I know that Senator Crowley wants to hear it. Further, through the partnership for development of fixed term arrangement programs, they are contributing to industry development in this country with activities such as exports of goods and services, R&D, regional headquarters and strategic alliances with smaller indigenous companies.

BREAK.PARA: One element of OGIT's current scoping work is to look at how industry development might flow from outsourcing initiatives. The office is seeking input from industry on a number of issues, including how small business enterprises can be incorporated into outsourcing. It is expected that local companies will have the opportunity, as in the past, to establish alliances with prime contractors for the provision of services to government. In the light of the work under way, it would be possible for some judgments to be made early next year on the broad impacts of outsourcing, including on local R&D and other activities.

As to the matter of the contract EDS has secured in South Australia, I am not in a position to comment on the company's legal affairs. What I can say is that the company is a participant in the partnership for development program and has committed to industry development activities totalling $300 million over seven years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Parer, for that answer. But moving on to the matter at hand, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) to a question without notice asked by Senator Crowley today, relating to private health insurance premiums, and to a question without notice asked by Senator Lundy today, relating to funding for women's organisations.

I find that the answer given in response to my question on the best allocation of private health insurance dollars is a matter of grave concern. When people contribute to their private health premium, I do not think any of them understand that they are actually funding university scholarships or overseas trips to the value of some $8,500 in the event you are a prize winner.

Senator Newman said with great flippancy, `I'd like to win a prize like that.' That seemed to me to be one of the worst answers ever given by Minister Newman. I do not care whether the minister would like to win a prize or not. What I am concerned about is whether or not people buying private health insurance in this country are having their health dollars taken straight through their health insurance companies and put into assisting the subsidies of university scholarships. It may be that university funding is being pushed, particularly by this government, to look for other sources besides government grants and contributions, but that is a separate issue.

Why should people have to pay precious private health insurance dollars to subsidise university scholarships? Why should we have private health insurance companies coming to this government and saying, `We need your approval to increase the funding,' when they are actually taking some of those precious dollars and putting them straight into funding for scholarships in universities? That is an education dollar, not a health dollar.

The private health insurance companies—Mutual Community in South Australia in particular, in this case—say, `It's just part of the way in which we try to get access to the community and an alternative way of encouraging them to buy private health insurance.' They could have very likely done that without necessarily allocating any dollars. A university might be pleased to include a letter in its letters to the alumni—`There is no need necessarily to try to buy this provision,' or the enclosure. Maybe you could have paid for the postage. But why scholarships? That is an educational dollar through private health insurance.

At the same time, these private health funds have complained bitterly that their premiums are going up so much that they now need a tax handout from this government—$1.7 billion over four years, as I recollect, to try to subsidise private health insurance. We have seen all that benefit completely gone because of the rises in private health insurance premiums. Partly those rises are going to deal with the administrative costs of all private health insurance companies, except Medibank Private. The administrative costs are about 14 per cent for most funds compared with about four per cent for Medibank Private. Most of the private funds cry foul about this. There is a distinct advantage because of the administrative efficiency of Medibank Private. That should be seen as an advantage to that company and not something that government should try to subsidise or write out as the private health insurance companies want it.

But I cannot possibly stand by and see precious private health insurance dollars go to university scholarships—in other words, for education—nor can I see them go to pay for overseas prizes. That is the sort of business you might get if you try to sell a car, but it certainly does not seem to me to be the way we should be trying to persuade people to buy private health insurance.

I am very concerned that the minister said nothing very much in her answer, certainly of no substance. She did not even agree that she would seek too much information and whether there was anything further to provide. I sincerely hope she does. I sincerely hope the government takes a long hard look at what is going on in private health insurance, because it is not to the advantage of citizens who want to buy it.

The minister's responses on funding for women's organisations leave and have left so many women's organisations in a state of terrible confusion and anxiety about their ongoing funding. Many of them will now have to compete within departments to see whether they can get an allocation of dollars to support the work they have been doing up to this point. I sincerely hope they will be able to achieve that.

I do not believe the minister assists those women's organisations by leaving them to hang out to dry for months—getting three months funding or six months funding. It may be in place now for a few more months, but those women's organisations need more support, more assurance and more direction than they have gotten to this point from this government. Minister Newman, in both of her answers today, has left a great deal to be desired. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very disappointed in the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, because she has been very lacking when it comes to standing up and speaking on this area of her portfolio. She is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. I understand full well how difficult it can be in cabinet. But quite clearly this government is not committed to continuing the policies of the previous government with regard to gender policy development. I have spoken on a number of occasions about these issues and here is further example of the fact that the coalition is not committed to continuing policies in relation to gender.

SPEECH.PARA: What are these women's organisations expected to do? Senator Newman has made some announcements, but they are so general; they are not specific. When she was asked by Senator Lundy in question time today to be specific about the aggregate of funding that will be provided, she did not provide an answer. Do we assume that there will be more money available for community groups and for the Office of the Status of Women? Sadly we cannot assume that because this government is all about cutting expenditure to the community sector and certainly cutting expenditure to the Office of the Status of Women.

BREAK.PARA: I wonder whether honourable senators would be aware that on a recent occasion two women from China came up to me and asked, `Whatever's happening to women's policy in Australia?' This is extraordinary. After all the criticism that has been directed at China in relation to its policies and attitudes to women and the focus on it during the lead-up to the Beijing United Nations conference and after, here we have Chinese women who have already heard that there is a problem in terms of this government's attitude to a continuing commitment to women. In estimates we heard that the national agenda for women's grants program has been cut. Now we find that women's organisations are going to have to compete with all other organisations.

I find the minister's comment about the sandpit extremely gratuitous. Of course there should be a place where 53 per cent of the population can apply to when it comes to priority funding. There is absolutely no problem with having an identifiable area that women's organisations can apply to. That has been the role for the Office of the Status of Women. But their funding has been cut back, and they are operating effectively with skeleton staffing and are unable to keep up with monitoring the government's plans for implementing the platform of action from Beijing.

So, quite clearly, many women's organisations will be extremely depressed and very unclear about what the policy of this minister and this government is. While they will be able to apply—there is nothing special about being able to apply through other government departments as they have always been able to apply—we still do not know what the minister considers to be a core group.

What is the definition of `core women's group'? The minister mentioned women in agriculture, I think, and women with disability. Are these groups core groups? What about the National Council of Women? What about businesswomen? What about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women, women from non-English speaking backgrounds, young women, older women? What about the Older Women's Network? Are they considered to be core groups? Quite clearly, the minister has raised many more questions than she answered in her statement on Friday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to take note of the answer given today by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) in relation to funding to women's groups in this country. It was with quite a deal of amazement that I listened to the answer. As is typical of Senator Newman, we got only a quarter of an answer. One of these days she will give us a full answer to something that is in her portfolio area. A quarter or half of an answer for a portfolio she represents in this chamber maybe we will accept, but this government is a quarter of the way through its term and this minister is yet unable to fully answer a question that she is asked on her portfolio. That is pretty slack.

SPEECH.PARA: We know there is going to be funding for core groups. The word `core'—we have heard about `core groups' and `core promises'—seems to be the in word following the election of this government a quarter of a term ago, but the government is never happy or willing to define what is in its core groups. We now have the minister saying we will know what is in a core group when the government puts out the guidelines and the criteria for these grants in March next year. What do the women's groups do between now and March? They have a quarter of a year, three months—it may be nearer four months, depending on the date of the announcement—to work out or try to fathom whether they are a core group.

How much money will be available for these groups? The budget will tell us that. When does the budget come down? It comes down in May. So the government is calling for submissions in March, and they will know in May how much they have to spend. The minister says, `But the money will be ready for them by 1 July.' This is a very interesting time frame. They are going to have to work out what groups are core groups, who is going to get funding and how much funding they are going to get. We do not know. The minister cannot answer that.

The minister did say that the government will spread the funding between the Office of the Status of Women and departments, but we do not know how much will be available through the Office of the Status of Women and how much will be available through the ordinary departments. I do not have a great problem with some of the money being available through ordinary departments, because it does make those departments aware of the needs of women. But, if there is not going to be any guarantee of funding, then this is a farce of a program. It is not a good and adequate program.
The minister also made the disparaging comment about women playing in the women's sandpit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Girl's sandpit.
—The girl's sandpit. I would suggest to the minister that she learns a bit more about sand and watches out for quicksand because she might find herself—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Murphy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes; with the handpainted periwinkles. But I suggest the minister be a bit more concerned about sand and learn the difference between sand in a sandpit and quicksand because, in relation to this situation, she might find herself in quicksand.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister also made the comment that she was going to increase the role of coalition female members of parliament to act as intermediaries, advisers and consultants for women's groups. For many years now we have had what would resemble a bipartisan women's policy. There has been unity about issues that concern women. The Democrat women have concerns about issues that are specifically women. Women from the Greens also have concerns. So do Labor Party women—and I have to say that Labor Party women make up 33⅓ per cent of all Labor members of the chamber, but the minister does not seem to notice that.

This is obviously an abolition of a bipartisan approach to dealing with issues that affect women. I have a great concern about this politicisation of women's issues and women's business, for want of a better word. It is to be deplored, and the minister is to be criticised very severely for this. What will happen? Does this mean that the female members of the government will be able to choose which women's organisations to support or think are worthy? It removes from women's organisations the assurance that they will be treated in a non-partisan way and that public servants will use an objective method to determine who gets funding. It almost smacks of whiteboards—choosing who is more worthy than others. I think this government needs to be very cautious about this.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to a question without notice asked by Senator Panizza today, relating to social security.

I want to spell out a bit more of what I have said previously on the various programs that Senator Newman has avoided answering questions about. One of the issues she talked about was who gets hit when governments tighten the criteria for unemployment.

I have no doubt she has read this, or if she has not read it, she ought to. If she has read it, she must have ignored it. The submission from Welfare Rights, in a letter on 28 October 1966, on this very issue, in committee, pointed out very clearly who is subject to the tightening of criteria when governments use this method, so they say, to crack down on fraud. In fact, they do not crack down on fraud at all. People who are into fraud and who, in a very sophisticated way, are defrauding the system are not caught by these measures. Welfare Rights, in its submission, comments on the people who are caught by the measures. It says:

It has been our experience that those individuals who are incurring breaches, and multiple breaches in particular, are those people with mental illness (usually undiagnosed or untreated), drug and alcohol dependency or literacy problems, and people with neurological or fatigue related illness. As can be seen from the case studies cited in the attached report, these people incur breaches because either they cannot understand or cope with the system or the system cannot understand them.

We are not talking about people who sit in Canberra in some airconditioned bureaucratic office, or even in the minister's office, who dream up these schemes to push people who are already disadvantaged even further down the heap. We are talking about people who, day by day, face to face, meet with people who are disadvantaged and who try to help them. And their testimony to this parliament—to this Senate and to its committee—is that it is those people I have just described who are the people caught by these measures.

Let me say to you that over 18 months ago, I gave to the Department of Social Security a number of examples of real, sophisticated fraud. To date, those people are still at it. They have not been caught because these measures do not catch them. Senator Newman can answer questions until the cows come home but neither the question nor the answer today got at the issue, and the issue is that the methods that have been put in place by the government simply do not work and do not fulfil the purpose which they say they are going to put them in place to fulfil.

Let me tell you a bit more about what I have said in the press in the last couple of days. One of the effects of the policies of this government will be that these people whom I have described will go from an average of 3.7 weeks without income to 6.8 weeks without income—with no income at all. They will not be able to look for work because, without income, all of the evidence proves that you cannot go out and find work. They will have to go on to emergency relief, further straining the resources of groups such as Lifeline, St Vincent de Paul, the Smith Family, et cetera.

Let me give you some comparisons. This also came from the submission by Welfare Rights. Let me just show you by using some comparisons how uncaring, how bad—I cannot think of another word without swearing—this government's tactics are going to be. Let me give you some of the fines for people who break the law. For traffic offences involving low levels of alcohol, the fine is between $200 and $400. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Conroy today, relating to the financial interests of the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey).

Senator Kemp's answer was a non‐answer and there seems to be a conspiracy of silence over this particular issue. Senators may well ask: what is this conspiracy of silence; what have the ministers got to hide?

The simple answer lies in the Minister for Finance and his incompetence and total disregard for both the taxation and corporation laws of this land. The edict in this case by Mr Fahey, ably assisted by Senator Kemp, is `Do as I say, but not as I do.' What we have is this bumbling Minister for Finance who has been caught out once again regarding the management of his personal finances. It is a good thing that Mr Fahey became a `has‐been' lawyer, rather than an accountant, because if he had become an accountant and applied the same standards of financial probity to his clients that he does to himself, he would have been declared bankrupt by now due to the flood of professional negligence cases that he would have lost.

Let us look at the substance of this issue and the systematic failure by Mr Fahey and his representative in the Senate, Senator Kemp, to provide any answer to the now number of questions and issues that should be of concern to both this chamber and the Prime Minister and the public. Mr Fahey established a company in 1978 called Lochreagh, which, for a number of years, received management which I can only assume was in relation to his legal practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, this sort of vitriol is probably fairly normal coming from the other side but I do ask whether, in a debate such as this, a senator should be reading—which is contrary to the standing orders; I know it is a standing order that is not applied very regularly—five minutes of vitriol, and not reading it particularly well.
—On the point of order, at least I want to provide some accuracy with regard to the points that I make, rather than what has been provided by Senator Kemp, which has no accuracy and gives no answers.
—I accept that you are looking at copious notes as you are making a contribution and I would ask you to continue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —Until 1986, as far as can be ascertained, Lochreagh for all intents and purposes was in compliance with the company law at the time. From 1986 to 1992, Lochreagh, of which Mr Fahey continued to remain both a shareholder and director, failed to lodge company annual returns in direct breach of section 335(1A) of the Corporations Law. Due to this failure to comply with the Corporations Law, Lochreagh was deregistered by the ASC in December 1992, at which time the current asset of the company was a one‐third equity interest in a property at 19 View Street, Camden, which would then have become vested in the ASC commissioner as is required by section 576(1) of the act.

ANSWER.PARA: Given that Mr Fahey was Premier of New South Wales at the time, obviously trivial matters such as compliance with the Corporations Law did not even raise a concern with him; otherwise he would have done something about it, and he did not. We move on four years later to 23 May 1996—with Mr Fahey now a minister of the Crown—to the House of Representatives pecuniary interest register where Mr Fahey indicates that he is still a shareholder and director of Lochreagh Investments Pty Ltd, a company that no longer exists.

That Mr Fahey could still make that claim is a real indication of his capacity. If someone in the position of Minister for Finance for this country could make such a stupid mistake—if it is a mistake—about his own personal finances, what is he able to do with regard to the $100 billion that he manages on behalf of the public of this country?

Those are the things that ought to be of concern to the public and certainly of concern to the Prime Minister. Outside of that there is this question of the Prime Minister's ministerial code of conduct. We have seen how it has been applied to Senator Short and Senator Gibson, although when you look at Mr Moore there has been a different application. It would appear that again it has a different application for Mr Fahey. Surely the public and this chamber have a right to know exactly where the Prime Minister stands on these issues and why we have not received answers to some of the very important questions that relate to the fact that Mr Fahey is clearly in breach of the Corporations Law—and may quite possibly be in breach of the taxation law of this country—yet he is the Minister for Finance of this country.

Surely the government and Senator Kemp have a responsibility to answer these questions quite categorically and clearly. If Mr Fahey is not in breach of the taxation law and Senator Kemp actually wants to clear the air on the issue, why does he not refer the issue to the taxation commissioner for investigation and report? Why not? That would clear Mr Fahey one way or another. That is a challenge for Senator Kemp, the government and the Prime Minister. If the Prime Minister wants his prime ministerial code of conduct to have any integrity, then he ought to propose to Senator Kemp and the Minister for Finance that that happen.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should recognise that the Coalition's proposed cost‐cutting measures to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will remove the broadcaster's ability to properly provide services to both its radio and television audiences—particularly those in rural and regional areas.
Your petitioners oppose any cuts to the ABC and request that the Coalition be held to its pre‐election promise to "maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC".
Your petitioners request that the Senate reject any measures to downgrade the ABC's budget.

Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1996 SPRING SITTINGS
PROCEEDS OF CRIME AMENDMENT BILL 1996
The bill provides for the annual transfer of the Confiscated Assets Trust Fund net balance to the Consolidated Revenue Fund, and establishes an international equitable sharing program.

The bill is part of the Government's major savings proposals. The bill must be passed before any funds can be transferred and in order to achieve savings in 1996‐97. Any delays in the passage of the bill will reduce achievable savings.

BROADCASTING SERVICES AMENDMENT BILL 1996
Purpose:
To extend the power of the Minister for Communications and the Arts to direct the Australian Broadcasting Authority to investigate and report to the Minister.
Reasons for urgency:

The proposed amendment is necessary to enable the extension of the ABA's role in the development of a regulatory framework in the online services area. The amendment is required urgently to ensure that the development of the proposed national regulatory regime in respect of online services is not delayed.

That the Senate—

(ii) the release of preliminary findings of a coronial inquest implicating PNG Defence Force soldiers in the October 1996 assassination of Bougainville Premier Theodore Miriung, and
(iii) the perceived lack of control of the military by the elected Government of Papua New Guinea; and

PARA.TAB: (i) to express its strong concern to the PNG Government about the continued human rights abuses committed against Bougainvillian people, and
(ii) to take strong action, such as reviewing the Defence Cooperation Program and facilitating peace negotiations between warring parties on Bougainville.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the Abolition 2000 Campaign in Australia, which is a global network of groups calling for negotiations for a nuclear weapons abolition convention within a time‐bound framework, and

(ii) the resolution submitted by Malaysia and 32 co‐sponsors, in the week beginning 8 December 1996, to the plenary session of the United Nations General Assembly, calling for negotiations leading to a nuclear weapons convention; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the Government:

PARA.TAB: (i) to join with the Abolition 2000 Campaign to call for the initiation of a nuclear weapons abolition convention that requires the phased elimination of all nuclear weapons within a time‐bound framework, with provisions for verification and enforcement, and
(ii) to support initiatives, such as the Malaysian resolution, which work towards the agreement of a nuclear weapons convention as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

(a) notes that Miss Lois O'Donoghue retired on Friday, 6 December 1996, as the chairperson of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), having been the foundation chairperson of ATSIC and having served as chairperson for more than 7 years;

(b) notes that Miss O'Donoghue steered ATSIC through some of the most tumultuous and yet productive years in the relationship between indigenous and non‐indigenous Australians, through the first‐ever recognition of prior indigenous land ownership by the High Court in its Mabo decision, through the subsequent debate over the development of a responsible legislative response to Mabo and through the first change of government in 13 years; and
(c) pays tribute to Miss O'Donoghue for the enormous contribution she has made to the indigenous community and to the broader Australian community.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Allison) agreed to:
That the following matter be referred to the Community Affairs References Committee for inquiry and report by 30 September 1997:

Current arrangements for the provision of housing assistance in Australia, including the public provision of housing, cash subsidies and taxation measures, and options for reform of those arrangements, with particular reference to:
(a) the success of existing forms of housing assistance in alleviating housing-related poverty and ensuring Australians have access to affordable, adequate and appropriately located secure housing;
(b) the equitable distribution of housing assistance;
(c) the responsibilities of Commonwealth and State governments in the delivery of housing assistance, with specific reference to:

PARA.TAB: (i) the efficiency, effectiveness and delivery of housing assistance,

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Margetts) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 to phase out diesel fuel rebates for mining operations.
Motion (by Senator Margetts) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

At a time when huge cuts are being made to health, to education, to dental programs, when pressure is being put on migrants, aboriginals, workers and the poor, it is hard to justify continuing massive expenditure to the rich and powerful.
For the last few years, under the pressure of international "free‐market" competition, we have seen Australia become more and more divided between rich and poor.

Taxes cuts have been touted as "benefits", though inevitably service cuts have followed. Despite the clear impact on revenue, it has been government spending which has been blamed for government budget deficits rather than a diminished revenue base.

There is no evidence that public need for government services has diminished. Governments, Federal, state and Local are providing more of these services on an increased cost‐recovery or a full user‐pays basis.

Policy decisions to withdraw support for a tax‐funded universal public service, even if it means taxes go down, cannot be justified if the result is reduced outcomes or being required to pay for a more costly private‐sector alternative. It may result in pricing those who need the service out of the market. It may lead to the reduction of disposable income if the service, such as education, affect most people. A system of collective payment for a collective service may be a smart option, especially if payment is based on a sliding scale that increases with income level, therefore increasing overall social and economic equity.

When we shift to the private market, the winners are always the big income earners. If the price is flat, the same for all, it advantages those incomes well exceed the basic level needed to survive. Where there is an income‐based sliding scale, contributions will be greater from the rich. For those with less income, they may get a public service below cost. Fair is a relative term. An equal price seems fair, but is not fair when there are huge differences in income. Ultimately the measure of equity must be whether it moves society in a more equitable direction.

We have been skewing our economy in the direction of the rich for many years. Unlike many company executives, who appear to be under no salary constraints, ordinary workers have had their wages and services eroded in real terms, although the previous government made efforts to minimise the effect though measures and benefits delivered and targeted through Social Security. The current government is now moving in to take that cushion away, claiming it is "middle‐class welfare". It will uncover the structural inequities based on wage disparities, leaving them visible in all their stark awfulness.

While it is cutting basic universal services to the public, and making cuts to areas like merit‐based education, government continues to subsidise the rich. The academic, the nurse and the teacher, working and returning value to community and humanity are penalised and under threat. The corporate executive, and the corporation he works for, remains a favoured son, although their agenda is to increase private profit and the concentration of wealth, though not necessarily in this country.
One of the biggest single handouts in terms of "corporate welfare" is the provision of the diesel fuel rebate to mining companies.

Each year, we hand out hundreds of millions of dollars in benefits from these rebates to corporations that are among the biggest and most powerful in the world. Over the last 4 years, BHP alone received over $300 million. Major recipients include BHP, MIM, ESSO, the Aluminium Company of America (ALCOA), or Rio Tinto Zinc (RTZ) (which has recently ended the pretext that its Con‐zinc Rio Tinto Australia (CRA) subsidiary was actually a separate, nationally‐based corporation).

We give these corporations hundreds of millions of dollars in order to take irreplaceable high‐grade resources away from Australia forever. We give them these subsidies even though the income back to the government from royalties and resource rents is negligible, compared to the value of the resources themselves. We give them these handouts although they mostly simply ship our resources away, leaving other countries to make the money from processing them, leaving Australia to buy them back as expensive finished products.

We subsidise these companies to dig up and send away our coal, our iron ore, and our energy products. We allow other nations to manipulate the price of these materials so that the value on our exports is minimal, minimising the return in tax, resulting in downward pressure on wages. Anyone who follows the coal‐price negotiations with Japan will recognise this process.

These corporations we subsidise so heavily are also often precisely the corporations that push most heavily to push down wages and conditions of workers. RTZ/CRA and Robe River have been out in front of the battle to break unions, to use individual contracts to create discriminatory hiring, where non‐union workers are given offered considerably greater salaries for identical work, where workers are locked out if they attempt to bargain for even basic rights and conditions. Government changes to industrial relations law will exacerbate this, and this is almost certainly the intended result.

The money to mining giants goes to corporations whose gross income is often bigger than the gross national product of many nations. These are corporations that play nations off against each other to reduce their costs, usually in part through reducing the value of raw materials. These are corporations that are usually vertically integrated, actually going from extraction of raw materials through to the sale of end manufactured products. Alcoa or Reynolds are product names familiar in grocery stores, as well as familiar to those interested in global mining corporations . They are also among the most often horizontally integrated, with oil companies heavily involved in production of oil alternatives; coal, gas, solar and nuclear.

Many of these corporations operate as defacto cartels; for instance, the famous "seven sisters" of oil, or the "six sisters" of aluminium production. The problems of transfer pricing and undervaluing of the raw materials is also well known. OPEC was initially established to try to assure the nations producing the petroleum received a fair share of the value of their resources. Australia became a member of the International Bauxite Association when it tried to end the exploitation, predominantly of developing nations, producing this raw material, by tying the royalty to the final price of Aluminium, rather than the nominal price put on the raw material, which companies in most cases sold to themselves. The nominal price put on raw materials was often so low that very little profit was made on extraction and export, and so very little tax was paid.

To its shame, Australia violated its agreement with other IBA members, undercutting them with royalties of about 60 cents per tonne, and now is the world's major source of bauxite and alumina, although it is still an inconsequential source of aluminium.
