In Victoria, where we do produce aluminium, it is partially because that state has subsidised Alcoa's electricity needs, at an additional cost of about $200 million per year to Victorian taxpayers and power users.

In 1995‐96, the diesel rebate hand‐out to the mining industry was $749 million. In 1996‐97 this was expected to rise to $794 million, although with the government's additional handout to the limestone quarries it is likely to blow out beyond that. By the year 2000, the cost to the public is expected to be nearly $1 billion, approximately what the commonwealth pays for technical and vocational education, and only slightly less than the projected $1.2 billion in basic payment for government primary and secondary schools. It is equivalent to the total amount government pays to ATSIC.
We're talking about giving highly profitable transnational corporate mining giants handouts, from this scheme alone, that are 18 times more than the cost of the Commonwealth Dental Program!

The Diesel Fuel Rebate for mining is unjustifiable. It is a distortion of the price of non‐renewable resources, and a subsidy for global consumption and corporate profit, at a time when we are making Australian consumption more difficult by creating pressure on workers for lower real wages and conditions, and higher costs, especially for those services that used to be universally available for little or no cost. It is a measure which, by subsidising the depletion of our resources without gaining real value from them, undermines the ability of other nations to effectively seek a fair return for loss of their resources.

Our amendment is fairly simple. It takes the level of the rebate indicated in the Acts, and halves it for the 1997‐98 financial year. In 1998‐99 it halves the rate of the previous year, and in 1999‐2000 and afterwards, the rebate is set at $0 per litre. In other words, there is a phase‐out of the rebate over three‐years.

The legitimacy of corporate profits in what are effectively large social activities is contentious, but their advocates argue that they are based on the risks taken. What risks, when we are basically paying people to take our non‐renewable resources away? Even from a market perspective, such massive subsidies can only distort the market and artificially fuel consumption, to the detriment of social justice, since the distortion is paid for by taxpayers who are having services cut as a result. Consumption, constrained by income and need, may involve choice, but there is little choice on tax, and less on deciding that mining giants should be the big winners in competition for the tax dollar.

Environmentally, such distortion of the market through subsidising resource extraction, can only serve to artificially fuel global consumption of non‐renewable resources through creating unrealistically low prices. In development terms, such subsidised extraction and undervaluing of primary products has been identified for over twenty years as a major source of the bias towards the rich nations at the expense of the poor, and which keeps developing nations in poverty.

There are many reasons to end the diesel rebate for mining. I have outlined several. At a time when government is crying poor, dismantling the public sector in pursuit of an ideology which is opposed to the notion that government exists to facilitate the goals of the people and to the notion of universal services provided through progressive tax, it is appropriate to end the massive bleeding of revenue by way of subsidies to transnational corporations to come to Australia, dig up our resources, and take them away.
Debate (on motion by Senator Panizza) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of Appropriation Bills by Legislation Committees

TALK.START.PARA: —I present additional information received by the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee in response to the 1996‐97 budget estimates hearings.

DEBATE.TITLE: BANKRUPTCY AMENDMENT BILL 1996BANKRUPTCY (ESTATE CHARGES) BILL 1996BANKRUPTCY (REGISTRATION CHARGES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996 and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
BANKRUPTCY AMENDMENT BILL 1996

Today I am introducing a package of measures comprising three bills Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996, Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996, Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill 1996 that give effect to the government's pre election announcement in `Meeting Our Commitments' in which it announced that increased cost recovery for the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia (ITSA) would be pursued by this government.

Bankruptcy administration has traditionally comprised three main areas, namely court registry functions, estate administration functions, and trustee supervision and law enforcement type functions. The Bankruptcy Act 1966 provides for statutory office holders and private citizens registered under the Act to perform these functions, and to some extent, the various functions overlap.

The Inspector-General in Bankruptcy, in practice, is the administrative head of ITSA. The principal functions of the office are to oversee bankruptcy administration, to prepare a report to the Minister about the operation of the Act, to manage the Common Investment Fund in which all moneys held by the statutory corporation called the Official Trustee are invested, and to review various decisions of trustees relating to matters such as income contributions, and discharge from bankruptcy. The Inspector-General, as delegate of the Minister, also authorises Commonwealth funding of proceedings and inquiries in relation to bankrupt estates and bankrupt deceased estates.

The majority of the statutory functions performed by the Inspector-General fall into the category of supervisory and law enforcement type functions. As administrative head of ITSA, the Inspector-General is the supervisor, under the Public Service Act 1922, of all the Official Receivers and their staff. With the enactment of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, the Inspector General will take over most remaining administrative functions in connection with personal insolvency from the Federal Court of Australia.

ITSA delivers a number of public interest services which support the personal insolvency system, including the development of policy advice, information and education to debtors and the commercial community, particularly financial counsellors and practitioners, the exercise of statutory Official Receiver powers to assist all bankruptcy trustees, and regulatory and law enforcement responsibilities.

In addition to these functions, the Official Trustee, through ITSA, administers approximately 92 per cent of all bankrupt estates. In many of these there are few, if any, assets so ITSA is unable to recover fees in respect of about 80 per cent of estates. ITSA performs an important public interest function in administering these non-fee paying estates on behalf of creditors. Without proper administration of all bankruptcies the credibility of the personal insolvency system would be jeopardised. Our credit system is reliant upon a credible personal insolvency system.

In the Budget, the Treasurer announced that increased cost recovery amounting to an estimated $3.648M in the 1996/97 year and $6.248m in subsequent years would be achieved in the following three ways:

The current basic charge of 3 per cent payable by all bankruptcy trustees in respect of amounts realised and credited to trust accounts in respect of estates administered by registered trustees and the Official Trustee will be replaced with a flat realisations charge of 8 per cent;
Interest earned on trust funds held in bankruptcies and Part X administrations which are administered by registered trustees will be payable to Consolidated Revenue; and
The flagfall fee charged by the Official Trustee on estates administered by ITSA will be increased.

The combined effect of these measures will place all creditors, whether their bankruptcy is administered by ITSA or by registered trustees, on a more equal footing in terms of contributing to the cost of the bankruptcy administration system. The increased charges and fees will only apply in those matters where there are funds. They will not have an impact on bankrupts.

The legislation that I am introducing today will also produce a simpler collection method for fees and charges that are taken. It will streamline practices for both ITSA and registered trustees and reduce the paperwork burden within the system. For example, registered trustees will no longer be required to open a separate bank account for each estate, nor to issue receipts in respect of each payment into estates.

When a person becomes a bankrupt or enters into an arrangement under Part X of the Act a trustee is appointed. This person may be either the Official Trustee or a private trustee registered under the Act to perform the duties of a trustee in bankruptcy. A trustee is entitled to be remunerated for work undertaken on behalf of creditors in administering the estate of the bankrupt or debtor.

The Official Trustee charges fees based upon the amounts that have been realised for the benefit of creditors. These fees are imposed by regulation under section 163 of the Bankruptcy Act. The fees comprise a flat rate `flag fall fee' plus a percentage of realisations made over and above $2,000. So, if realisations do not exceed $2,000, the fee is the flagfall amount. If they are between $2,000 and $50,000 it is the flagfall plus 15 per cent of realisations between $2,000 and $50,000. Over $50,000 the prescribed percentage is reduced to 10 per cent of the additional amounts realised in excess of $50,000.

The Government intends to increase the flagfall fee from $2,000 to $4,000 to produce increased cost recovery for direct use of the work done by the Official Trustee for the benefit of creditors administering estates. This will be done by amendment to the regulations. The regulations will also be redrafted into a more easily understood and applied form. Fees will only be payable in respect of those estates in which sufficient funds are realised from which fees can be paid.
I now turn to the three bills involved:

Sub rules 179(2) and (3) impose a charge on estates administered by registered trustees and rule 181 imposes a similar charge on estates administered by the Official Trustee. This charge is payable at the conclusion of the administration of estates. The fee is calculated as a percentage of amounts realised at a maximum of 3 per cent reducing to 1.25 per cent for amounts realised in excess of $100,000.

It is proposed that this fee will be increased to a flat percentage of 8 per cent calculated on the basis of amounts credited to trustees' accounts in a six monthly period. The charge is to be imposed in a new Act, the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Act that will impose charges relating to the administration of all bankrupt estates. The charge will be payable six monthly in arrears within 21 days of the conclusion of the particular charge period.
The first charge period will commence on 1 November 1996.

Trustees will be personally liable for payment of the fee which may be paid from funds held in the estate. If they pay late, they will be personally liable for payment of late payment penalty at the rate of 20 per cent per year, for which they are not entitled to be reimbursed from the estate.

If the Official Trustee, that is ITSA, administers an estate all amounts held in respect of the estate are deposited into the Common Investment Fund. These funds are invested in interest bearing investments by the Official Trustee. However, interest derived from the investment of moneys in the Common Fund does not increase the amount payable under the Act in respect of any estate or fund. The interest is regularly paid to Consolidated Revenue.

In contrast, interest earned on monies invested by registered trustees on behalf of estates they administer does increase the amount available to the estate. It is proposed that this be changed to place all estates on an equal footing, whether they be administered by ITSA or by registered trustees.

A registered trustee of an estate will be personally entitled to any interest earned, net of bank fees, in respect of monies held in trust accounts under the Bankruptcy Act. He or she will then be required to pay the amount of the interest, less bank fees, to Consolidated Revenue.
The amount of interest representing bank fees will be payable to the estate to enable the estate to meet the fees.
No amount of interest earned will be subject to income tax as the whole of the amount that would have been taxable will be payable to the Commonwealth as a charge.

Through the two measures in this Bill, creditors who benefit from a credible and effective personal insolvency system will meet a more appropriate share of the cost of maintaining and administering that system.

The Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill proposes the imposition of charges in respect of applications for registration of trustees in bankruptcy, registration of trustees, re-registration and applications to vary conditions on registration.

These charges were previously imposed in the rules made under the Bankruptcy Act 1966. Instead of these charges being imposed by regulation it is proposed that they be imposed by separate legislation.

The amount imposed by the charge is the same as would have been imposed by regulation. The charge is $1500 in respect of an application to be registered as a trustee and $1000 in respect of registration and re-registration. Registration is for a period of three years.
A charge of $500 is imposed in respect of an application to vary conditions imposed on registration.
Amendments were required to the Bankruptcy Act to give effect to the change from imposing fees by regulation to enacting separate legislation imposing charges.
The Bankruptcy Act has been amended to give effect to the necessary changes.

Additional provisions are also proposed to provide for administration of the proposed two Charges Bills, in particular to allow for orderly collection of the charges by the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy on behalf of the Commonwealth.
Provisions are also proposed to allow for extensions of time in which to pay charges and the remission of penalties and charges in appropriate circumstances.

The opportunity has been taken to streamline administration of accounts held by registered trustees by allowing them to consolidate trust account monies into a single account if they wish to do so and they will no longer be required to issue receipts for monies paid into accounts in all cases. They will also no longer be required to furnish accounts to the Official Receiver at the conclusion of an administration.

The Inspector-General will be responsible for ensuring the provisions of the Bankruptcy Act 1996, the proposed Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996 and the proposed Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill 1996 are complied with and appropriate powers to allow this to occur are contained in the bill.
I commend these bills to the Senate.
BANKRUPTCY (ESTATE CHARGES) BILL 1996

Today I am introducing a package of measures that gives effect to the Government's pre election announcement in `Meeting Our Commitments' in which it announced that increased cost recovery for the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia (ITSA) would be pursued by this Government.

The Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996 will replace the current basic charge of 3 per cent payable by all bankruptcy trustees in respect of amounts realised and credited to trust accounts in respect of estates administered by registered trustees and the Official Trustee with a flat realisations charge of 8 per cent; and provide that interest earned on trust funds held in bankruptcies and Part X administrations which are administered by registered trustees will be payable to Consolidated Revenue.
Details of these and other measures are contained in the Second Reading Speech for the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
BANKRUPTCY (REGISTRATION CHARGES) BILL 1996

Today I am introducing a package of measures that gives effect to the Government's pre election announcement in `Meeting Our Commitments' in which it announced that increased cost recovery for the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia (ITSA) would be pursued by this Government.

The Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill proposes the imposition of charges in respect of applications for registration of trustees in bankruptcy, registration of trustees, re-registration and applications to vary conditions on registration.
Details of this and other measures are contained in the Second Reading Speech for the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of these bills be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the autumn sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

The Family Law Amendment Bill 1996 will amend the Family Law Act 1975 to provide a power for the Governor-General in Council to make regulations which provide for fees to be charged for use of the voluntary counselling and mediation services of the Family Court.

The amendment is part of the government's overall budget strategy to reduce the massive budget deficit that this government has inherited. The essence of the government's response to the $8 billion budget deficit black hole has been to make sensible reductions in outlays and increases in user charges to ensure that the burden of the need to reduce the deficit is shared across the whole community. To ensure a fair distribution each area must play its part.

The bill will allow regulations to be made prescribing fees to be charged only for the voluntary counselling and mediation services provided by the Family Court. At present those using these services often make no contribution to the running costs of the court. I remind Honourable Members that the cost of running the Family Court is now in excess of $100 million per year.

One of the major considerations favouring the imposition of fees in this area is the fact that the commonwealth funds the Family Court to provide counselling and mediation services and-also funds community based service providers which provide similar services. The community based sector provides these services for a fee to those who can afford to pay. Those who cannot afford to pay are exempt from fees.

The demand is such that it is not possible for all to have access to the Family Court's services, in these circumstances it is inequitable that a service is provided for a fee to some, often residents of rural and remote locations, but others, purely on the basis of geography, receive a similar service for free.

The issue of making some charge for the provision of these services by the Family Court was actively considered by the previous government as indicated in the Attorney-General's Portfolio Budget Statement for 1995‐96. The proposal was also considered as part of the review of fees and charges in Commonwealth Courts and Tribunals commissioned by the previous government.
While counselling and mediation are important there needs to be an adequate contribution by those who use the services of all of our courts.

In its 1994-95 Annual Report the Family Court indicated that "fifty percent of all cases seen came to the (counselling service) on a voluntary basis to use the Court's primary (alternative) dispute resolution service without having filed any application at the Court."

These people, in particular, make no contribution to the running costs of the Court. It is proposed that the provisions which relate to the waiver of other fees will extend to counselling and mediation fees so that those who cannot afford to the cost of the service can continue to receive those services free of charge. Community based organisations also provide pro bono counselling services for those who are unable to pay.

I wish to assure the Senate that I and the government remain committed to encouraging the use of alterative dispute resolution services. The Family Court's counselling and mediation service is one of the oldest ADR services in existence.

It is not necessary, however, that services be provided without charge. There is extensive use made of community based services where moderate fees are charged. I expect that the services that the Family Court provides in this area will continue to be fully utilised providing that the fees charged are broadly in line with those charged in the private sector.
The power to levy fees only relates to those services used on a voluntary basis. Where the Family Court orders or directs that counselling take place no fee will be payable.
This amendment does not, of course, impose any charges of itself and any such charges would have to be made by regulation.

It is the government's intention to request the Governor-General to make regulations that would impose a fee equivalent to what we understand to be the average fee charged by the community based sector. This would be a fee of $40 per hour. No decision has yet been made on how the fee would be imposed, whether it would be an up front fee or collected at an hourly rate. We are currently examining, with the Family Court, the most practical way of effecting collection of such a fee.

The government estimates that the fee will generate revenue of approximately $1.7 million in a full year. This initiative will make a significant contribution to the cost of providing voluntary counselling and mediation services in the Family Court rather than relying solely on community based services. It will also contribute to the achievement of the government's overall budget deficit reduction target.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the autumn sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

DEBATE.TITLE: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION CHARGES) BILL 1996EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:

BREAK.PARA: That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION CHARGES) BILL 1996

The Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Bill 1996 provides for Australia's international education and training providers to contribute to the costs of regulation of the industry.

Extensive national industry consultations earlier this year indicated universal support for the continuation of current industry regulation arrangements. These arrangements are based on the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 (the ESOS Act). This act provides assurances of education quality and financial protection to international students studying in Australia. It does so by registering providers of international education and training, based on state or territory approval and accreditation, and by imposing financial conditions on private education providers.
The ESOS Act was introduced in 1991 to meet three main objectives, namely:
to ensure that international students in Australia are treated with equity and fairness;
to provide a positive basis for promoting Australia's international reputation as a provider of reliable high quality education and training; and
to ensure that tax payers' funds are not required to recompense international students who may have been let down by individual education and training providers.
These objectives remain relevant. This is not just the government's view, but the universal view of industry representatives expressed in recent national consultations by an independent consultant.

This is an industry which currently earns Australia $1.9 Billion in export revenue annually. The existing regulation of the industry adds value in the market place, with consumers willing to pay a premium for the assurances the regulation provides.

Properly promoted such regulation can give Australian providers a marketing advantage over other international competitors. This advantage is recognised by the Australian providers who in the recent review of the ESOS Act particularly maintenance of the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS).

There are costs to the Commonwealth in maintaining this register. The Australian Government has maintained the CRICOS and related monitoring activities at no charge to the industry since the introduction of the ESOS Act in 1991. The current bill provides for a Provider Registration Charge which will recoup some of the future costs of maintaining CRICOS and the associated industry regulation and monitoring.

The current bill proposes a sliding scale of annual Provider Registration Charges based on the numbers of overseas students enrolled in the previous year. The Charges range from $300 for providers with up to ten enrolments in five steps to $5,000 for providers with over 400 enrolments in the previous year.
For newly registering providers an Initial Registration Charge will be calculated on a pro rata basis from the number of whole months remaining in the registration year.
All these charges will be indexed against the All Groups Consumer Price Index.
In total about $1 million annually is expected to be raised by this bill.

The current bill is complementary to the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996, which establishes administrative arrangements for management of the Provider Registration Charge within the existing ESOS Act. These administrative arrangements include a requirement for payment of the annual charge by the end of February each year and provisions for a charge to reinstate suspended providers on CRICOS and for a late payment penalty. The administrative arrangements also impose an obligation of providers to keep enrolment records and to produce them to the Secretary upon a written request.

The international education and training industry is an important and valuable one for Australia. It is a major part of our growth in the export of services, bringing many intangible benefits, including the development of contacts for future trade and diplomatic links, in addition to the $1.9 Billion in export revenue annually. This industry deserves continuing protection. This bill enables such protection to continue.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996

The amendments proposed in this bill establish administrative arrangements for management and collection of the Provider Registration Charge introduced by the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charge) Bill 1996. That bill provides for Australia's international education and training providers to contribute to the costs of regulating their industry.

Extensive national industry consultations earlier this year indicated universal support for the continuation of current industry regulation arrangements, based on the principal act which this bill will amend. That principal act is the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 (the ESOS Act). It provides assurances of education quality and financial protection to international students studying in Australia. It does so by registering providers of international education and training, based on state or territory approval and accreditation, and by imposing financial conditions on private education providers.

Properly promoted industry regulation can give Australian international education and training providers a marketing advantage over international competitors. This advantage is recognised by the Australian providers who, in the recent review of the ESOS Act, strongly indicated their support for maintenance of the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS).

The Australian Government has maintained the CRICOS and related monitoring activities at no charge to the industry since the introduction of the ESOS Act in 1991. The Provider Registration Charge will recoup some of the future costs of maintaining CRICOS and the associated industry regulation and monitoring.

This bill provides that the annual Provider Registration Charge should be paid by the end of February each year and that 28 days should be allowed for the payment of an Initial Registration Charge by a newly registering provider. The bill imposes an obligation on providers to keep enrolment records and to produce them to the Secretary upon a written request.
The bill also provides for a $100 (indexed) Re‐instatement Fee for providers whose suspension of registration is removed and a late penalty of 20% for an unpaid Charge or Fee.

The international education and training industry is an important and valuable one for Australia. It is a major part of our growth in the export of services, bringing many intangible benefits, including the development of contacts for future trade and diplomatic links, in addition to the $1.9 Billion in export revenue annually. This industry deserves continuing protection. This bill is an important part of such protection.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chris Evans) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (1996‐97 BUDGET MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

The Veterans' Affairs 1996 budget package honours key pre‐election promises to the veteran community. It provides for simpler and more flexible entitlements. It is fair, with better access to services, and more assistance to help veterans help themselves. The government's commitment recognises Australia's debt of gratitude to our veteran community, who served us so selflessly in times of conflict.

The major initiatives cover the areas of health care, housing, rehabilitation, compensation and commemoration. In particular, a number of anomalies will be removed from the system, resulting in more efficient administration and simplified service delivery.
Before discussing the bill in detail I would like to foreshadow a key initiative now under development in my portfolio to improve the delivery of services to veterans.

One group of veterans and war widows we have found to be disadvantaged, simply because of where they live, are those in rural areas. They are remote from the services that many in the city take for granted. Ready access to information and services is vital for all veterans but especially important to those in country areas.

In response to this particular need, I will announce in October a Health Policy for the Veteran Community in Rural and Remote areas. It comprises some innovative, cost‐effective ways to make more information, health and community services available in rural and remote areas. The policy will ensure continuing improvement in the provision of health care and support to the veteran community.
A number of other health initiatives, which do not require legislative action will also be implemented as soon as practicable.
For example, veterans will now have a greater choice than ever before in the range of spectacle frames available to them. Multifocal lenses will also be available to those who prefer them.

Veterans who require special footwear will find it more convenient to obtain their shoes and the necessary repairs. Veterans living in remote areas who need medical grade footwear can be issued with three pairs at one time. This will mean that they will no longer have to regularly travel long distances to get the shoes they need.

Eligible veterans will now also be able to use any footwear repairer contracted by the Department of Veterans' Affairs for repairs to their medical grade footwear. This means veterans will have greater access to repair services in locations convenient for them.

Funding will be made available to provide Australian merchant mariners with access to an asbestos screening program. This is designed to assist in the detection of illness related to asbestos exposure. Our World War II Australian mariners have not been eligible for an existing asbestos exposure screening program which is available to current and past members of the armed services and its civilian employees. This measure will ensure that all eligible veterans have equal access to the same services.

The list of eligible drugs contained in the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will be reviewed. This will ensure the best results from the pharmaceutical treatment provided to veterans and war widows.

A major review of the medication program for high risk veterans will also take place. The aim of this review is to reduce inappropriate prescription and medication use and improve their quality of life and health options.
I turn now to the measures contained in the bill.
The coalition is committed to the fair and equitable treatment of veterans and will continue to ensure that inconsistencies and anomalies in the Veterans' Entitlements Act are removed.

The current asset value of allocated pension investments will be taken into account for the purposes of the assets test. This is how they have been treated under Social Security legislation for some time. It is unfair that some people could gain increased income support by entering into particular investment arrangements. As announced in the budget, these changes will apply to any allocated pension investment entered into after 20 August 1996.
Some of the other income support changes in this bill reflect similar changes being made by Social Security.

The deeming rules will be changed to make them less complex. For money held as cash or on deposit, a deemed interest rate, currently 5 per cent, will be applied to the first $2000 for single pensioners and $4000 for couples. This change will simplify pensioner notification requirements because individuals will no longer need to advise about small interest fluctuations. This has been perceived as intrusive. For some pensioners the change will provide an opportunity to increase their overall income.

We will adjust the way lump sum compensation payments are treated. The calculation for the preclusion period for a pension payable to a person who has not reached pension age is to be changed. The compensation payment will be divided by the maximum amount of income that a pensioner can earn before the pension ceases to be payable. This will determine how long it will be before pension payments can be made. The partner of a person in receipt of lump sum compensation payments will no longer have a preclusion period applied to their pension payments.

I am very pleased that the Victoria Cross allowance is to be increased. A rate of $2700 will now be paid to our three surviving recipients each year. It is to be backdated to 17 August 1995 which was the date from which the British Government increased the VC allowance it pays.

Another anomaly we will correct relates to funeral benefits. A payment will be able to be made for costs associated with the transportation of the remains of a veteran who dies in financial need away from home when obtaining approved medical treatment. This assistance is available for certain other veterans who have died away from home.
This bill makes several positive reforms that correct a number of anomalies in the Defence Services Homes Act 1918.

Veterans who have previously been assisted through the Defence Service Homes Scheme because of their own service, and who are widowers of World War II ex‐servicewomen, are currently not entitled to a second loan based on their status as widowers. On the other hand, World War II widows, who are also ex‐servicewomen can receive this assistance. This anomaly will be removed and these men will now be entitled to a second loan.

The rate of interest for additional advances under the Defence Service Homes Scheme will be reduced. This will allow new borrowers to use their full entitlements over time for purposes such as home repairs or modifications, without having to pay what is effectively a penalty interest rate. This measure will assist eligible persons to maintain their homes and remain in them as long as they wish.

Eligibility for loans under the Defence Services Homes Act is to be extended to those who first enlisted in the Defence Force before 15 May 1985 and have not served more than 6 years but had operational service in Cambodia, the former Yugoslavia or Somalia. To date, this group of veterans has been denied assistance, even though their colleagues who enlisted later and served in the same areas have been able to obtain loans under the Defence Home Owner Scheme.
This bill will make several other changes that will simplify administration of veterans' benefits and improve the service provided to veterans.

A minimum variation rate, initially set at $1.00, will apply to income support payments. This means that variations in a pensioner's income and level of assets will not affect his or her rate of pension unless consequential changes in the rate of pension are at least $1.00 in either direction. There will be no need for pensioners to advise the Department about small changes in their income levels. This will eliminate unnecessary administration and also reduce the level of intrusion into veterans' lives.

Modifications will be made to the pension advance scheme which will also improve administrative efficiency. Applicants will now be able to receive one advance per year but will no longer be required to provide information about how the advance is to be used.

Changes have also been made to correct an anomaly in the advance payment scheme. War widows and widowers who receive service pension or income support supplement at a `frozen' or `ceiling' rate will now be able to obtain the $500 maximum allowable pension advance.

The government recognises the crucial role that veterans' advocates play in the repatriation claims system. Funding will be provided to ex‐service organisations so they can employ more staff. This will be additional to training programs already provided to ex‐service organisations on veteran entitlements and services. By helping to handle applications for review of pension claims to the Veterans' Review Board, these advocates will improve the efficiency of the repatriation claims process.

There are many other items in the Veterans' Affairs budget package that I have not mentioned. Another bill is expected to be introduced later this year. At that time I will provide Honourable Members with further details.

In the meantime, the initiatives outlined above demonstrate the strong and unequivocal commitment of this government to veterans and their families. These Australians sacrificed so much for their country and contributed enormously to the freedom and way of life we all enjoy today.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chris Evans) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that it had agreed to the amendment requested by the Senate to the bill.
Bill (on motion by Senator Campbell) read a third time.
Messages from His Excellency the Governor‐General were reported informing the Senate that His Excellency had, in the name of Her Majesty, assented to the following laws:

PARA.TAB: Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996
States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1996
States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1996
Shipping Grants Legislation Bill 1996
Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996
Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill 1996

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips) (1996) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 206 and made under the Export Control Act 1992, be disallowed.

This is the second time such a motion has been before the Senate in as many months. A disallowance motion on these regulations was first brought before the Senate by me on behalf of the Australian Greens because of the enormous impact that export woodchipping is having on Australia's grand wild forests. The reasons which were pertinent then are as strong as ever, and they remain. I will come back to those in a moment.

Since then the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee has had a look at these regulations and moved, through you, Mr Deputy President, for disallowance of the regulations. It did that for a series of reasons which were clearly laid out to the Senate. Last Friday, Senator O'Chee, on behalf of the committee, sought to withdraw the disallowance motion because he had been satisfied by reasons given by the government. I reject those reasons given by the government. The committee may have been satisfied, but they do not satisfy either me or the constituency which I serve. In particular, the committee found—it would, I think, have done well to have thrown its net a little wider—that these regulations do not allow for third party appeals. They certainly do not allow for adequate third party appeals.

The point I want to make out of this is that, when an export woodchip licence is issued to a company, the woodchip regulations as brought into this place by the current government give no right of appeal to landowners next door, neighbours, conservation groups or general members of the public. They are left completely out. There is no input from the Australian public about the proposed destruction of native forests for the voracious export woodchip industry once the minister has given the go‐ahead. It has been fine for the logging industry to get these regulations drawn up on its behalf by the government, but of course in doing so they have simply shown their lobbying firepower over this government; they are doing it in the face of an 80 per cent disapproval rate by the wider Australian public about the destruction of forests which comes out of the woodchip industry. It is interesting that, in the letter that the minister sent to Senator O'Chee, the first sentence says:
On a general note, the regulations were drafted in full consultation with industry representatives.
Doesn't that say it all? The logging industry, in effect, drew up these regulations in its interest through the good offices of the minister. The public and the conservation groups were left out.

You only have to see recent NAFI publications to see, on the one hand, the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) giving a great wrap‐up in this place to the logging industry and its so‐called responsibility in terms of the way it goes about its business and, on the other hand, outright condemnation by the other minister involved in the handling of logging in this country, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), of the conservation movement. He even goes so far as to brand the Australian Conservation Foundation, for goodness sake, as `radical'. What you have is, on the one hand, a two‐pronged attack by the Minister for the Environment wrapping up the logging industry and, on the other hand, the minister for logging blasting the environment community. We are going to see that pattern set by this government all the way down the line as it pulls the rug from under environmental good sense and the environmental wellbeing of this nation, not least the forest environment.

We just listened in question time to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) bucking the question of the future of the forests of Western Australia—which I visited again on the weekend. Of course, what will happen is that the mining industry will move in where the logging industry has let a very small section of the forest be protected. It is saying, `Well, we want to have a say here. If there's any chance of there being prospective minerals within cooee of these forests, we don't want you to protect them.' The Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, says, `That's okay by me. I'm not here to get in the way of anybody who wants to undertake destructive activities in an area of Australia under my control, no matter what the environmental excellence of it is.'

BREAK.PARA: Senator Hill might get up in question time and beat his chest about how, seeing the government have got some money out of the Telstra fund, they are the world's top environmentalists. But the fact is that money is not going to go within a bull's roar of meeting the repair that is going to be required because of the licensing of the destruction of Australia's forests when it comes to the need for future generations to try to recover from the greatest rate of logging in Australia's history.

We know that, since the issue of the licences, this government has moved to grant the big export woodchip companies licences for the export of 19 million tonnes of Australia's wild forests to the rubbish dumps of the Northern Hemisphere over the next three years. Let us look at the record of a couple of these companies who have been given licences under these regulations, which I submit should be and must be disallowed if we are really concerned about the environment.

I refer to the boycott woodchipping campaign put together by conservationists in this country to give the public a better acquaintance with some of these big corporations. I quote from page 10 of the document on Boral, one of the big operators in New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania. The document says that in November 1995, Forest Resources, that is Boral, said it would be laying 1080 in one of the private plantations near Weegena in northern Tasmania. Preliminary surveys of the area by the Deloraine field naturalist revealed that an important regional population of the small marsupial, the bettong—already believed to be extinct in mainland Tasmania—was located adjacent to this site.

Despite local protests the area was poisoned with 1080 by Boral. The parks service in Tasmania admitted to the field naturalist that it was possible the population of this amazing little creature, extinct on the mainland, could crash by as much as 50 per cent as a result of that poisoning by Boral. So much for their responsibility and so much for their input in designing these regulations which this government wants to push through the Senate.

Then we come to North Forest Products and a quote from the boycott woodchipping campaign on them on page 15. It says that breaches of the forest practices code in Tasmania by North Forest Products are numerous. It goes on to say that only recently contractors supplying North Forests Products Tasmanian pulp and forest holdings woodchip mill at Triabunna violated a streamside reserve, bringing in heavy machinery and building roads and log landings.

Part of the work was done without a timber harvest plan—that is, it was illegal—which should have been drawn up between North and Forestry Tasmania. In August, 1995, North Forest Products admitted the company had obtained pulp logs from two properties listed on the national estate. It had sent its chainsaws into the national estate. These were at Mt Vulcan, Simmond Hill and the Apsley Marshes. The Mt Vulcan forest provided a refuge for three rare and endangered plant species. Never mind, in went the company's chainsaws illegally.

Subsequent to North's admission, Forestry Tasmania—the government instrumentality that is supposed to protect our forests in Tasmania—said it had allowed logging to proceed in the non‐approved Douglas Apsley national estate area. It had given permission to override the illegal logging of national estate Tasmanian forests. The Australian Heritage Commission said it was probable that timber harvesting in any of those areas would have an impact on national estate values, and of course the Australian Heritage Commission is not unknown for its ability to engage in understatement.

Then we come to Amcor. On page 22 of its corporate profile by the boycott woodchipping campaign we read that Amcor sponsors both political parties—Labor and Liberal—but the Liberal Party gains almost 250 per cent more financial assistance than the Labor Party. It also quotes from the Melbourne Age of 23 August, 1996, which says that Stan Wallace from Amcor came out and said he gives more to the Liberal Party than the ALP because Labor has union backing. He said that everybody was now using that line. The story goes on to say that the Electoral Commission's latest report shows Amcor gave the coalition—the party of members sitting opposite—$217,000 and it gave the ALP $60,000.

You can see how influence just might work through companies like Amcor, North and Boral when it comes to—and I state from the minister's letter—the regulations being drafted in full consultation with industry representatives. That is why these regulations are faulty and lock out the public. This committee should have been concerned that there are no third party appeal rights for the public in these regulations. The committee was actually concerned that the regulations were not tight enough in giving the companies appeal rights to a ministerial decision; that is, that a company refused a licence might be able to take action and have its appeal rights strengthened against that decision.

Another matter the committee was concerned about was the ability of the minister to delegate important regulatory functions to junior officers regarding the protection of the environment against woodchipping concerns once a licence is issued. The minister explained that away, saying he would not do that because he would be responsible. He said, `Trust me.' The committee apparently said, `Oh, we do; that drops our complaint there.' It was as simple as that. I submit that is not good enough. The environment does count and senior delegated expertise, and no less, ought to be in charge and supervising the woodchip operations of these corporations that have repeatedly broken the law in Tasmania, at least, in their woodchipping operations.

I remind the Senate that the export woodchip licences which have been granted under these regulations allow for broadscale destructive logging of world heritage value forests in Tasmania—in the Picton, Huon and Weld valleys, in the Tarkine wilderness and in the Great Western Tiers. They allow for destruction of the habitat of rare and endangered species, like the white goshawk, which is down to 100 or 200 breeding pairs in Tasmania, and the Tasmanian wedge‐tailed eagle, larger than its mainland cousin, which is also down to 100 or 200 breeding pairs in Tasmania.

Forestry Tasmania says that it looks after these nesting raptors and that it will stay 250 metres or so away. I have seen a picture of a coupe in the Tarkine wilderness in which an area was set aside because there was a tree with an eagle's nest in the middle of it. Forestry Tasmania allowed the logging of the forest at a distance from this tree, but right around it nevertheless. Then it set fire, in its regulation regeneration burn to the coupe around it, and burnt the whole copse with the tree in the middle of it, and the eagle's nest anyway.

We all shrug that off as the species move closer to extinction, as the forests go and as the wild environment, which is so important to human beings, is eroded every day. We sit here on our hands and, through regulations like this, divest the government of the responsibility, if not the power that it ought to have, to do the best thing by Australia's forest environment. This instead of the bloody approach to destruction of wildlife as well as rainforest, world heritage value tall eucalypt forests in Western Australia, Victoria, New South Wales, Tasmania and now Queensland under the regulations that the minister has put through.

The committee was quite right to pick up on the deficiencies in these regulations—you could float a woodchip ship through them—and moved to disallow the regulations. The government's response to even the committee's circumscribed concerns is inadequate. Each senator who votes against this disallowance motion will be voting against the interests of any third party appellate in the country—that is, any ordinary citizen—who wants to appeal a decision by the minister responsible for woodchipping in the interests of her or his future, the future of their kids or, indeed, the wider future of the environment in this country. Each senator who votes against this disallowance is, in my book, voting in the interests of corporate greed, destruction and shortsightedness, and must shoulder the responsibility for their actions.

I finally make an appeal, having read out Amcor's influence on the parties through the direct putting of money in the coffers of particularly the coalition parties, to the good probity of those senators who have woodchip shares, who failed last time but who might rise to the occasion this time, to consider the conflict of interest that comes through voting for regulations in the interests of the woodchip industry.

There is no getting away from it: to vote for these regulations is to vote for regulations which the minister himself has said were drawn up in consultation with the industry in which they have shares. There is no doubt that voting for these regulations is voting to enhance the value of those shares. There is no doubt that voting for these regulations is voting to line one's own pockets, if one has shares in woodchip corporations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be offensive.

—The parliamentary secretary opposite says, `Don't be offensive.' We have a different view of what is offensive. I find it offensive that members would even consider getting up and voting for woodchip regulations which enhance the share value of corporations in which they have parcels of shares. I find it offensive that senators would get up and back shoddy regulations, drawn up under the influence of those very same corporations, to enhance the destruction of Australia's wild forest domain.

BREAK.PARA: I find it offensive that senators opposite like you are not influencing the government to move across to the plantation alternative, which is there and available to sustain this industry in total right now. I find it offensive that we do not have the commonsense and sensitivity in 1996 to look after the forests in which Senator Harradine and I and others go camping and which so many Australians find so much an important part of the heritage of this country.

I make that appeal again to senators opposite who have a direct pecuniary interest in the outcome of this vote on the disallowance of the woodchip regulations to have the probity—senators opposite might snigger—to think again, to do the right thing for once, to do the honourable thing by standing aside from voting on this disallowance motion, which, if it fails, will further the interests not only of the woodchippers but of your pockets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make the position of the government on this very clear. We do not accept the suggestion that the regulations that create these licences should be disallowed. We have heard from Senator Brown for some 20 minutes. In that period of time, his speech has been notable for an absence of fact. Now I wish to provide the Senate and those listening to this debate with the facts because we are pretty fed up with the sort of nonsense we have heard from Senator Brown. I will start with a press release issued by Senator Brown on 12 November 1996. This is really good. The press release starts with the words:

SPEECH.PARA: `The discovery of errors made by the government in drawing up regulations has cast doubt over the validity of woodchip export licences issued last month,' according to Australian Greens Senator Bob Brown.

The facts are that there was no question of invalidity. There were no errors. That was made very clear to Senator Brown in the media release issued by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on 19 November. This is some 2½ weeks before he sought to prevent the protective notice of motion for disallowance over these regulations being withdrawn.

The committee, to my knowledge, has only issued two press releases in the 6½ years I have been on this committee. The reason why the committee issued a press release is that it was disgusted with the distortion of the facts contained in Senator Brown's press release. I quote from the media release issued by the committee. It says:
In fact this is not the case and the committee has never stated there were doubts about the validity of the woodchip regulations. The committee considers that the regulations are clearly valid.

You would have expected after that that Senator Brown would be too ashamed to continue with the nonsense that he did. You would have expected that if Senator Brown had any decency—and he lectures us on this side of the chamber about decency—he would have come into the chamber and apologised to the Senate and apologised to the committee for distorting in such a heinous fashion what the committee had done. But, of course, Senator Brown could not be bothered.

BREAK.PARA: There were some other outrageous distortions contained in Senator Brown's press release of 12 November. I want to get on to those as well. I think it is important the Senate really understands that this is just the most deplorable political stunt. It is also important that the Senate understands that what Senator Brown is doing actually undermines the ability of this committee to work in a non-partisan fashion.

The Senate regulations and ordinances committee is charged by Senate with the oversight of regulations and ordinances. What Senator Brown is doing in politicising the work of the committee is making it harder—I will tell the Senate as chairman—for government senators to act in a non-partisan fashion because they have to start wondering what is going to happen if they put a protective notice of motion on a set of regulations. Is Senator Brown going to get up and pull another stunt again? That is what is happening.

Senator Brown is not improving the scrutiny of regulations in this country; he is undermining it. But Senator Brown has a special regard for the truth. He saves it for special occasions. I do not believe that 12 November was one of them. He said:
In their haste to please the woodchip industry, Ministers Anderson and Hill have bungled.
Meanwhile the government has allowed a massive escalation in export woodchipping to a record 19 million tonnes based on flawed regulations.

We have already seen that there were no flaws in the regulations. There was never a suggestion that there was a flaw in the regulations. The only reason why the committee put a protective notice of motion over this was to give them longer to correspond with the minister. If this is going to happen all the time, I will tell the committee and the Senate that I am going to have a lot of reluctance to put on a protective notice of motion because it undermines our capacity to deal with ministers in a fair, honest and transparent fashion.

The truth is that if these regulations are disallowed that will probably lead to an increase in the export of woodchips from this country because what these regulations do is in fact limit the right of appeal of companies seeking woodchip export licences. So if these regulations are disallowed it will be open to the companies to appeal to the AAT if they are an aggrieved party; that is, if they do not get their licence they can apply to the AAT. So the AAT would be in a position to issue licences over the objections of the minister.

Senator Brown says that he is concerned with the massive escalation in woodchip exports. This would increase the amount of woodchips exported from this country. That is what Senator Brown's motion of disallowance would do today. I find it particularly strange that Senator Brown should come in here, wring his hands and say how concerned he is about the environment. The facts are that Senator Brown's motion would have a deleterious effect on the management of the environment and Senator Brown's motion would undermine the environmental integrity of what we are trying to do because Senator Brown would have an open door to the woodchip export companies.

Then came the most offensive remark of all. Senator Brown said that if honourable senators who had interests in woodchip export companies voted against this they would be voting to line their pockets. In fact, if one had an interest in a company that exported woodchips and one voted against this motion of disallowance one would be voting to prevent those companies having a wider right of appeal. Senator Brown has cast a despicable slur over the integrity of this Senate. That is what Senator Brown has done. But Senator Brown could not be bothered with the facts. He just could not be bothered. That is why I find it appalling that Senator Brown comes in here and lectures us on morality.

Some of the outrageous statements in Senator Brown's last speech really deserve to be repeated. He said that the woodchip industry was involved in the destruction of world heritage areas. He proceeded to talk about the Tarkine region. The Tarkine region is the Arthur‐Pieman region. It is the region, as Senator Calvert knows, between the Arthur River and the Pieman River. It is not a world heritage area. Of course Senator Brown might like it to be but it is not. That is just a little matter of fact, and fact has never been a big factor in the way Senator Brown makes political decisions. Nor is it a big factor in what he says to this chamber.

Then Senator Brown says that there are hideous things happening in forests. The facts are that forest management practices are the responsibility of the state governments. Senator Brown could have played a part in forest management practices in Tasmania but Senator Brown decided to do a runner from the Tasmanian parliament and come to the Senate. So Senator Brown has abrogated his chance to play a role in responsible forest management by coming here and now he wants to do this stunt.

What I cannot understand is why Senator Brown has to be like Pavlov's dog every time it comes to an issue about the environment. You will recall that Pavlov trained a dog to salivate every time he rang a bell. All you have to do with Senator Brown is bring in woodchip export regulations and he starts salivating like Pavlov's dog in shirtsleeves and wants to move a motion of disallowance. This is just silly.

Senator Brown has already had one chop at these regulations and he was knocked back. So now he comes back for a second chop. When is the lunacy going to end? When is Senator Brown going to apologise to the Senate for all the things that he has said? Senator Brown has wilfully misled the Senate. He knows that he has wilfully misled the Senate, and I am quite disgusted.

Then we had other suggestions, such as those in his media release of 5 December 1996. It states, `The regulations have cut the public out from proper appeals.' If Senator Brown disallowed these regulations, it would do nothing to allow third party appeals. It would do absolutely nothing. The only way in which the public could appeal against the granting of a woodchip licence—and these are merely mechanisms to deal with the refusal to grant a woodchip licence—would be if they applied for a licence and were knocked back.

If Senator Brown can indicate to the Senate any environmental group that has applied for a woodchip export licence and has been knocked back, then I will happily consider what he has to say. But I do not know many environmental groups who have made applications for woodchip export licences. What the regulations really deal with is curtailing the right of exporters to seek to appeal if they do not get their licence. So what Senator Brown is doing is making it easier to export woodchips.

Then there was the slur on the committee in Senator Brown's final paragraph of his press release of 5 December 1996. It states, `My move will force the matter to be debated properly rather than simply withdrawn after unspecified government assurances.' There were four pages of ministerial assurances provided to the committee. Senator Brown is obviously unaware, but most of the time the responses to this committee run to about one to 1½ pages. This was one of the most detailed responses the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has had since March.

Senator Brown says in his press release `unspecified government assurances'. He almost but not quite goes so far as to suggest that there was some sort of improper influence applied to the committee. That is not the case. Honourable senators from both sides of the chamber are members of this committee. They look at the matters on a non-partisan basis. They felt that their concerns had been adequately answered. Senator Brown's response to that was, `The committee may have been satisfied but they don't satisfy me.'

Senator Brown is now the self-appointed guardian of the conscience of the Senate. I hope that he is happy. Unfortunately, I do not think many environmental groups will be terribly happy with him when they realise what he is trying to do today, which is increase the avenues of appeal for woodchip export companies by disallowing these regulations.

Maybe Senator Brown did not even bother to read the fine print or maybe this was just another exercise from Pavlov's dog. Whatever it is, I urge the Senate to maintain the environmental integrity of what the government is trying to do, not to increase the avenues open to woodchip export companies to appeal licences, not to destroy these regulations and not to impugn the integrity of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

For all those reasons, Senator Brown's motion needs to be thrown out. Finally, I believe that Senator Brown ought to apologise to the Senate and the committee for the outrageous things that he has said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind honourable senators that the terms `wilfully misleading' are not permitted under the standing orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of old codswallop from Senator O'Chee. He was puffed up with all his bombastic self-importance and plum in the mouth, making that sort of contribution. I think he should be absolutely delighted that it is not a broadcast day today.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say that I think there is a sense of deja vu about this motion for disallowance. It was only a few weeks ago that the Senate debated a motion from Senator Brown to disallow the government's woodchip regulations. Back in October the opposition supported Senator Brown's motion, and we will support this motion today. We outlined our reasons for opposing the regulations in that earlier debate. We oppose these woodchip regulations because, firstly, they represent a major broken promise of the Howard government. Secondly, they seek to implement a seriously flawed and negligent forest policy. Thirdly, they are technically deficient in a number of respects.

Our concerns about the technical deficiencies of the regulations were later raised by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which I understand through its chairman indicated a willingness to disallow the regulations. In fact, it was Senator O'Chee who wrote on behalf of the regulations and ordinances committee to Mr Anderson, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, outlining the committee's concerns. The letter outlining those concerns along with the minister's response were tabled in the Senate on 5 December.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to refer senators to my comments on Senator Brown's earlier disallowance motion. Because of my rather extensive contribution to that debate, today I will keep my comments to the technical flaws in those regulations. I will be brief, because I am conscious of the significant amount of work before the Senate in this last parliamentary sitting week for 1996. I hope others who are contributing to the debate can show similar discipline.

The government's response to the committee has not allayed the opposition's concerns about the technical deficiency of these regulations. Even though it took the government three months to draft the regulations, they still simply could not get the regulations right.

There is no definition of `degraded forest' and the environment minister is precluded from the process which will determine what constitutes a degraded forest. As the opposition has said before, we consider this to be a very serious flaw. Back in July when the policy was announced, the environment minister was to be consulted on what constituted a degraded forest. However, these regulations include no reference to the environment minister whatsoever. I think the environment minister's omission from the process really does illustrate the lack of balance in the Howard government on forest policy matters.

There is also no guarantee that forests which provide important habitats for native fauna will be protected. The regulations limit the classification criteria for `degraded forest' to the floristic composition of the forest. There is no acknowledgment in the regulations that a forest which could be judged degraded from a floristic point of view might be an important habitat for native fauna.

The government's approval for unlimited woodchipping on privately owned land has significant biodiversity implications that the government is ignoring. The conversion of such forests to plantations, instead of regrowth forests, is a backward step in terms of biodiversity. Plantations are normally seen as additional to existing native forests, reducing pressure on them in forestry production terms, not physically replacing them.

The opposition voted against these regulations in October. The concerns originally raised by, I assume, Senator O'Chee in the Regulations and Ordinances Committee—that is not entirely clear to me, but I assume that that is the case—which were subsequently picked up by Senator Brown, further confirm that we made the right decision at that stage.

In conclusion, I would say that this government's environmental record sinks to a new low each week. This week, of course, the government is seeking to open up important areas of forest reserves for mining and mineral exploration. I assume that the definition of what constitutes `an informal forest reserve' under the government's proposed new two‐tiered forest reserve system will be determined by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

This development, along with the implementation of these woodchip regulations, represents a serious threat to Australia's native forests. For these reasons, and the others I have outlined on a previous occasion, these regulations will be opposed by the opposition. So I indicate to the Senate, again, that we will support Senator Brown's motion to disallow these regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats welcome the opportunity to have this issue raised in this place again. It is not raised frequently enough. It is one that the previous government liked to see, and certainly this government obviously would now like to see, swept under the carpet somewhere and not raised and not discussed and debated.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go through all I said on 14 October when we originally had an opportunity to vote against these regulations. But I simply will state again very clearly, particularly for Senator O'Chee's benefit, that what we are looking at in this regulation is undoubtedly an escalation of the clear‐felling of woodchipping. In particular, I point to those parts of these new regulations that allow the movement now on to private land. I think, particularly for Tasmania, that will prove to be one of the nastiest aspects of these new regulations.

BREAK.PARA: But today I would just declare a personal interest I have in these regulations. As a mother of two daughters, I believe that we should be preserving—indeed we have an obligation to preserve—these forests for future generations, the generations to come. We have an obligation as a developed nation, as a relatively well‐off country, to make sure that we do not continue the wholesale clearing of these unique forests. We have a responsibility to protect them.

We have an obligation to future generations to stop wasting money propping up the industry in native forests. We have an obligation to actively encourage the move now to the plantation sector where this industry will be viable in the long term. We have an obligation to ensure that native birds, mammals, frogs, insects—all those animals that rely on these native forests—are protected.

Where, Senator O'Chee, do you suggest that the long‐footed potoroo, the powerful owl and many of those species, particularly those which are endangered in East Gippsland, go after their area of forest is clear‐felled? Some who obviously have never moved or walked around in these forests suggest that they simply move to another area of forest. I would suggest that those people take another look because already territory is well and truly marked out either by other species or other members of their own species in adjoining areas of forest.

If we look at bird counts in particular, we see a steady decline in all areas where open‐ and clear‐felling is allowed. Therefore I would state very clearly, yet again, that the Democrats will be opposing these regulations and supporting the motion to disallow them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I have found the situation difficult to believe today. We have seen Senator O'Chee, as the Chair of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, outlining what appeared to be a threat to the Senate—a threat to act in a partisan way if anyone questions the decisions of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee.
—That's appalling; that really is appalling.
—I am sorry, but that is exactly what Senator O'Chee has said.
—That's not what I said, Senator Margetts. Just be honest for once.
—I took this quote—through you, Mr Acting Deputy President—`I will tell the committee not to put a protective notice'—
—That is appalling and that is untrue.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, me thinks he protesteth too loud. I wrote down the words that were mentioned. If there was a challenge for very good reasons of a committee and it was announced in the chamber that the proper advised actions of that committee would change or if there were directions for that committee to change their way of dealing with protecting motions, protecting the good decision making process, then that would be unacceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator O'Chee should resign from that committee because of those statements. It is not good enough for there to be a situation where, if the Senate made a challenge for very good reasons, a statement could be made that threatened the way a committee operated in protecting the ability to disallow motions or that directed the way a committee was to act. I feel very strongly about this. It is not proper that this could be a response to the Senate challenging any decision or just picking up the ball in relation to something a committee has thrown away.

In this sense there is no representation of the minor parties on the Senate ordinances committee. This may be the only opportunity minor parties have of participating in such a debate and I do not think the Senate should be threatened in any such way. It is disgraceful. In support of Senator Brown's motion, I would like to say that there is not just one, or two or even nine senators in this chamber who are concerned; there are a great many people in the community who are concerned.

The role of committees is to make sure that proper processes take place. The role of committees is not to avoid things that are difficult, or political or may be seen to be controversial in the community. The role of committees is to engage in proper process and to make the best possible decisions. I would like to think that any committee will continue to do that, even if they are rightly challenged in their action. That is the process and that is what we are all elected in this chamber to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 191, I wish to explain a comment that I made. Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Margetts has suggested that I threatened the Senate. That is a very serious allegation. It is also grossly untrue. Senator Margetts, had she been paying any attention at all, would have heard me say two things. The first of those was that I was concerned with what Senator Brown was doing because it might make it more difficult for me to get government senators to put a protective notice of motion on a regulation if they thought the protective notice of motion was going to be misused. It is quite clearly the case that to characterise that as my threatening to prevent—
—You said you would direct them not to do it.

—Senator Margetts, you have had your go. To characterise that as saying that I was threatening the Senate is in fact grossly defamatory.
