The only reason I would be seeking to persuade government senators to agree to put a protective notice of motion over a regulation would be to use the enforcement procedures available to the committee. The other thing I said was that I, myself, would have grave difficulty putting a protective notice of motion—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This is a contribution to the debate by Senator O'Chee, who has already spoken.
—This is under standing order 191, you dunce.
—I know exactly what you are trying to do. The problem is, as Mr Acting Deputy President knows, you are out of order.
—There is no point of order. It is not a personal explanation; under section 191, Senator O'Chee is making an explanation of his speech.
—You are clean‐bowled again, Senator Faulkner.
—I remind Senator O'Chee that he cannot debate the issue.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The other statement I made was that I personally would have a lot of difficulty putting a protective notice of motion on something if I knew it was going to be disallowed. The simple reason is that there is a requirement that the committee act in good faith and the ministers have to know that the committee is acting in good faith. All this does is increase the likelihood—and this is my concern—that ministers will seek to circumvent the committee. But there is absolutely no foundation to Senator Margetts's suggestion that I have threatened the Senate. I have sought to use this mechanism under section 191 to explain it to Senator Margetts, who was obviously not understanding what I had said in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Having had the Senate threatened by the contribution of Senator O'Chee, and his having failed to in any way ameliorate that threat as outlined by Senator Margetts, I want to let him know that I am one of those—and I suspect there are a lot of others over here—who are not going to be shut up by his attempt to say that, if we come out against what a committee finds in this place, we in some way or other will be put in our place by him.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice the shifting ground that this senator moves across. On his behalf, a disallowance motion was brought into this place. Senator Colston said:
At the request of Senator O'Chee and the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that 15 sitting days after today Senator O'Chee will move that . . .
the regulations on woodchipping—
be disallowed.
It is pretty clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a protective notice of motion, Senator.

—Suddenly Senator O'Chee now explains that it is a protective notice of motion. It is a device. The stipulations in this place are that, if he, as chair or in any other capacity, wants to withdraw a disallowance motion, another senator can take it over. So the device does become a genuine disallowance motion. What we have before the Senate now is a genuine disallowance motion, but his was not. This is genuine because there are senators here who are concerned that the export woodchip regulations have been part of a series of moves allowing the record destruction of Australia's grand and ancient wild forests. Since the regulations went through, 19 million tonnes have been licensed by this government for destruction—to be sawn down with chainsaws, taken to the woodchip mills and exported on ships through the paper process to the rubbish dumps of the Northern Hemisphere.
—Sounds good to me.

—The honourable senator opposite says it sounds good to him that Australia's grand forests end up on the rubbish dumps of the Northern Hemisphere. I guess that is the level of concern on the benches opposite for the heritage environment which 80 per cent of Australians want to see protected.
—You had your chance for Tasmania and you blew it. Senator Harradine trumped you.

—We have from a senator opposite the interjection that Senator Harradine, who, if he follows form, will vote for the woodchipping that these regulations represent, has in some way or other taken a lead that I should follow. Not on your life.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming back to Senator O'Chee, you said, Mr Acting Deputy President, that he breached standing orders while he was up on his soapbox opposite lecturing people on this side about probity and accusing me of wilfully misleading the Senate over world heritage values in Tasmania. I do not need to be told that we cannot use the word `ignorant' in relation to a senator in this place. We heard about that a little earlier today.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's debatable.

—I do not want to argue whether or not truth is not allowed to be out under that rule. The fact is that this senator is talking through his hat when it comes to the environmental values that the majority of Australians hold dear.

SPEECH.PARA: What I said in relation to Tasmanian forests—and Senator O'Chee was not listening; he got himself into a mess yet again because of his lack of attention to detail—was that forests of world heritage value in Tasmania are going to the woodchippers because of this government's activities and these regulations. Those forests of world heritage value are in the southern forests of Tasmania, south‐west of Hobart, in the Great Western Tiers, and in the Tarkine. They are not in world heritage areas, but experts who know what constitute world heritage values have pointed out that these forests would be given world heritage listing if they were nominated.

But it is not in the interests of the government opposite to recognise the world heritage value of Tasmania's rainforests—the eucalypts, the tallest flowering plants on the face of the planet, the vast array of wildlife, including marsupials, bird life, all nine species of bats in Tasmania, 15,000 to 30,000 species of insects, many of them as yet unidentified, whose stronghold is in those forests and who, without those forests, cannot continue to exist. These are the very forests which Senator O'Chee and his mob have targeted for roads, for clear‐fell logging, for fire bombing and then for 1080 poisoning in a process which destroys every living cell where these great untouched ecosystems currently exist. That is the process we are talking about.

Senator O'Chee comes in here and accuses me, quite wrongly, of wilfully misleading the Senate when he does not know what he is talking about. He should be ashamed of himself, and so should other members opposite, for putting their stamp of approval on the destruction of world heritage value forests in Tasmania which do not have the protection they should be getting but instead, under these regulations and through this government's policy, will be fed to the chippers in the coming months and years against the interests of every future generation of Australia, who will want that heritage as part of their life experience, as part of their variety of life and as part of their repository of inspiration, adventure and relaxation in an even more hurried, anxious and troubled world, devoid of more of its forests, devoid of more of its biodiversity, devoid of more of its naturalness as the years go by because of the actions of the woodchippers and the resource extractors who are currently plundering the planet at the greatest rate in history.

No, Senator O'Chee, I do not resile from bringing forward this disallowance motion. If he, as chair, has had reason through government correspondence to retract his disallowance motion, I am quite happy to take it over and to put it to the Senate to test once again whether there is not the commonsense and long‐sightedness in this place to make some sort of move, however small and however desperate, to protect our wild forests and to move this destructive woodchip industry across to the plantation base, which is, right now in 1996, already there and available to take its full cutting rates. We can have our forests and we can have our wood production too, but I suspect it is going to take a great deal more wisdom, sensitivity and commitment to future generations than we have heard from that contribution opposite before we get to that stage of enlightenment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Senator Brown's motion be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no. As a division is called for, the bells will be rung.
—Before the vote on this matter is taken, I declare that I have an interest which I disclose similar in terms precisely to that which I disclosed on 15 October.

—I wish to indicate that I have an interest in some shares I own in Boral, which could have an indirect interest in the matter of the debate. When the vote was taken previously in October, I had shares in North. I declare that these have now been disposed of.
—I declare to the Senate that, as was the case last time, I have a small holding of shares in Boral company.
—I declare that I have an interest in 16,000 eucalypt trees, planted on my farm property, which will be ultimately destined for the woodchip market.
—I declare my interests to be the same as declared on the last occasion this matter was considered.
—I declare that I have all the shares that I declared in October regarding woodchipping. I intend to vote and I still intend to hang on to them.
—I declare an interest in this matter similar to that which I disclosed when a similar vote was taken in October.
—I wish to declare that I have a shareholding in Boral.
—I declare, as I did last time, that I have shares that are relevant and, as last time, I am voting against my own best interests.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Before question time, when we were debating the sale of Telstra here in the committee stage, I was raising the issue of how the $250 million telecommunications infrastructure fund would be allocated between the states and the territories. I pointed out the ludicrous allocation based on a per capita arrangement. As I said before lunch, it is about $10,000 per capita for the 800-odd identified rural people in the ACT down to $16 per capita for people in rural New South Wales. I would certainly like to hear a justification for such an extraordinary inequity on the allocation per capita from the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston).

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to hear from the minister in the committee stage how the lump sum figures for each of the states was arrived at. Although it is said that the money is allocated in each state for the non-metropolitan and non-capital area, that does not explain how, for example, New South Wales gets 14 per cent and Queensland gets 21 per cent of the $250 million. Is that in some way related to the rural population? On that basis, it still seems a bit odd that the ACT could get $4 million for a percentage of its population, which is extremely minute in the non-capital and non-urban areas. I presume that in the ACT, all the known urban area, which is the Canberra urban area, is not included in the calculation. That is the first area of answers we would like from the minister.

The second area relates to the $250 million, which, as I pointed out to the minister before question time, is spent over five years. In the same five-year period Telstra will spend $20 billion on capital works in Australia. Can the minister assure us that where the $250 million will be spent is not already in the Telstra business plan that he has had before him for at least a month or so.

Could the minister also provide information to the Senate in relation to how the $250 million will be spent once allocated to each state. Is the money going to be in the control of the Department of Communications, his own department, under ministerial direction or is it going to be provided to Telstra, and they will spend it and report to the parliament? Whichever way it is spent, will the parliament have an opportunity to review how the $250 million is spent over the next five years, particularly through the estimates procedures?

If the $250 million a year is provided to this fund and it is to go towards the developing of infrastructure in the regional area, will that money be paid to Telstra, as the predominant carrier in Australia, as a cash payment? If it is a cash payment, will that in any way affect the universal service obligation cross-subsidy that at the moment Telstra is paying at around $230 million a year?

It is ironic that here we might have the beginning of the government starting to pay the universal service obligation of the carriers. Under the current legislation, the carriers pay the full universal service obligation according to a predetermined formula, according to the percentage of the market. There has been a great debate on this issue for several months now about the possible threat to universal service obligations.

If Telstra does get most of the $50 million for infrastructure expenditure, will it be possible for it to deduct that from, or put it into the pot to pay for, the cross-subsidy. At the moment that is around $230 million, so in effect it is paying a cross-subsidy of only $180 million. I do not know whether this is true or not—I am speculating about this. Because the minister's statement as of last Thursday night is so unclear and imprecise, I think these are naturally reasonable questions the Australian public would want to ask.

I also ask the minister: is there any consideration that some of the money will go to pay for a subsidy to reduce the cost of charges? The minister mentions in his statement the internet and the ISDN. He also mentions that some of these are issues for educational institutions. Does this mean that some of the money will be spent to subsidise the cost of those charges or is all the money going to be spent on providing telecommunications facilities in either hardware or software? If that is the case, can we in the Senate please get some indication today of what that equipment is, what that software is and how the money will be spent? Again there was no indication of that in the minister's 1½‐page statement last Thursday in which he announced the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund.

As I mentioned before, we would certainly like to know from the minister if he will personally administer the fund. Will Telstra administer it? Will the Department of Communications and the Arts administer it? That is an area where it is all very indistinct. It is very troubling that, at the very moment when the bill is being voted on, we still do not have those details for this proposal that the government has now been working on for nine or 10 months. Any other government proposal to spend $250 million in any other area of government activity announced in a very cavalier way like this was and with no detail would certainly be open to considerable criticism from the public about these arrangements.

BREAK.PARA: Minister, in relation to your statement about the special needs of Tasmania and Queensland that deals with the lobbying of Senator Colston and Senator Harradine to get their vote, will we get any details of the arrangements you have reached and will those details be tabled?

TALK.START.PARA: —Details of what?

—Put simply, Minister: you put two statements out on Thursday night—one on the infrastructure fund itself and one on the special interests of Tasmania and Queensland, some of them dealing with infrastructure and some of them dealing with employment.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Colston in his speech during the second reading debate mentioned that he was still in negotiation with you regarding the employment arrangements. The statement deals with the employment of 40 extra people at a new operating centre at Toowoomba. If that is the only detail on the arrangement for Queensland, we would like to know how that is going to be announced and how it is going to be guaranteed.

Has Senator Colston or Senator Harradine sought some sort of contractual arrangement to hold you and the government to the promises you have made about these jobs and about the funding? If you do not have some other arrangement which has not been yet announced in a contract, in legislation, in regulation or in a memorandum of understanding, I would be astonished that those two senators would provide their support on really a stab in the dark that this would come to fruition.

Once this legislation to sell a third of Telstra has passed, has been proclaimed and put into operation, how does Senator Harradine and Senator Colston hold you to what you promised them in your statement on Thursday night? If you or Telstra moves away from it, what remedy do they have to enforce the promise you made in this rather tawdry deal? If there is some arrangement, then surely the Australian parliament has the right to know what that deal is, how it is going to be enforced and what sort of contractual arrangement it is because this is public money that you are handing out of a rather large war chest to get the support of these two senators to sell one‐third of Telstra.

So I put those questions to the minister. I hope he can respond in some detail during the committee stage of this debate on the partial sale of Telstra. Those questions related to the infrastructure fund, but now I want to turn to the promise of jobs.

The minister said in his statement that the National Call Connect Centre in Hobart would be established and the operator assisted centre in Burnie would be expanded. He said that, in total, that would create 140 new jobs in the period 1997-98 to 1999-2000. Can you assure the Senate and the Australian people that those 140 jobs are not being transferred from some other already existing Telstra centre, particularly in a regional area, to Tasmania?

Minister, is it not true that you had already had to admit to the chamber that you had misled it? You are already getting rid of 126 jobs in Tasmania. Therefore, all up, you are creating 14 jobs. A 14‐job increase for Tasmania is the best way you can look at this at the moment. I have to say to Senator Harradine: I do not think that is a particularly generous outcome for you. At the moment all you have are 14 extra jobs for Tasmania when you take away the 126 that the minister had to admit to the chamber.

So what we want to know is: were these jobs transferred from another state, not just Tasmania? Some other regional area may be suffering to pay-off Senator Harradine. Again, in Toowoomba in Queensland, I think there were 45 jobs for the second National Directory Assistance Call Connect Service Centre. The title is a bit of a mouthful, but that centre is to go to Toowoomba with 45 jobs.

If I remember correctly, Minister, Senator Colston was particularly concerned about jobs in Roma. Were any of the jobs in Roma transferred to Toowoomba—or from anywhere else, particularly elsewhere in regional Queensland—to allow for these 45 jobs? How long will these jobs last under the arrangement? Are they there forever and a day? Once Telstra is sold and the management comes in, once you lose the power to direct the Telstra board, do these jobs just go and then you wash your hands and say, `Sorry, Senator Colston, sorry, Senator Harradine. I can't direct the board. The whole world has changed in the operation of Telstra. The deal is all off. I can't do anything about it'?

TALK.START.PARA: —The parliament has power legislatively.
—Not if it removes the power to direct. It is all over red rover. The minority shareholders will probably insist it is all over red rover to improve their profit.

BREAK.PARA: My second lot of 15 minutes is now nearly up. I have put a lot of specific questions to the minister. Subject to some of those answers, I have several more questions to ask. This is unfortunate. I do not want to waste the chamber's time, but the statement that was issued on Thursday night, trying to give some detail of the arrangements that the government entered into with Senator Harradine and Senator Colston, is totally unsatisfactory. It is not in any way transparent for the Australian people to see whether this deal is worth anything or whether the government is actually taking Senator Colston and Senator Harradine to the cleaners to get their vote for the second reading of this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am obliged to enter this debate ever so briefly, because some remarks have been made during this debate in regard to the National Party and our representation.
—The doormats.

—I will take up that interjection, because that is what we have been accused of. The previous speaker, Senator Schacht, who is normally quite fluent, has had two goes at trying to present a case. After speaking for fifteen minutes on both occasions, he just kept going around in circles.

SPEECH.PARA: So now you are into the filibuster stage. Just admit that that is all you are doing here in this parliament. You are filibustering, and you do that very well. As far as constructive argument is concerned, you have not brought it to the chamber. Every speaker, from Senator Ray to Senator Schacht, has absolutely—incredible as it may seem—begrudged any help in maintaining the standards of the rural and regional parts of Australia. You have utterly begrudged the attempt to maintain the standards and to strengthen the universal service obligation. Instead, all you have done is dub this as a sleazy backroom deal when, in fact, it is nothing of the sort.

It is a very false argument that you happen to have built up to sell the proposition that the regional areas were ever on a par with the city regions. The regional areas were never, and have never been, on a par with the city areas. In fact, during the last 13 years, when you were in government, they were on a sliding scale to the regional areas—and this is not just in the area of communications. Senator Ray talked about the poor old people, I believe, of Clayton in Melbourne—along with other speakers—equating the services in Melbourne and Sydney with those in rural and regional areas. It is a joke. It is a false argument.

The rural and regional people are far from advantaged when it comes to comparisons with metropolitan areas—not just in the area of communications but in every way. For example, look at the prices they have to pay for petrol and simple shopping requirements. They do not have the types of shops and access to the larger shopping centres that those in the city have. Look at the prices of water. Look at television and communications in every sense of the word—mobile phones and faxes.

So do not come in here and try to equate the services of the rural and regional areas with those in Melbourne and Sydney, particularly over the decline of those services over the last 13 years. It really is an indication of just how hard it is—and it has been over the past 13 years—for the rural and regional areas to get on the agenda of the opposition. When they were in government, they certainly forgot about these particular areas.

There was nothing more evident of that than quite an infamous and notorious article in the Bulletin by a former senator of yours—Senator Richardson. This needs to be said. Honesty has overwhelmed him now he has to write a weekly article. Nevertheless, he said that, when in cabinet, cabinet knew only too well that they were only ever going to get, at best, one per cent of the vote from the rural areas by the farmers. So cabinet summarily dismissed any genuine concerns that the rural and regional areas had when presenting their concerns to the previous government.

We know that only too well because we had a four‐year drought—the worst drought this country has ever had. A major metropolitan TV station aired the disaster of that drought. It came to the stage where farmers were eating off the generosity of charities. It took all of this to happen before Paul Keating, the former Prime Minister, and his cabinet came to the aid of the farmers. Didn't the former Prime Minister say this? He said:
I notice the National Party running around saying I should be standing in a paddock in some drought affected area.
Drought is around now in Australia all the time so we have said let's try and cover this as a normal recurrence of rural life.

That is how he dubbed the worst drought in this country. It was only a month or two later that his own minders got him out into those paddocks. It was just as the National Party requested that he have a look at the drought first hand. That is when the cabinet finally turned around. They only turned around when Melbourne and Sydney started to respond.

I make that point because the opposition has no credibility when it comes to speaking for or protecting the rural and regional areas. It takes others in this chamber to do that, particularly as far as Tasmania is concerned. Tasmania is a predominantly rural area. It has faced the downturns in commodity prices equally as much as the mainland has. Tasmania has had political decisions go against it; decisions that could have greatly enhanced its rural and regional areas. The Wesley Vale pulp mill, for example, would have been tremendous for employment.

As for my state of Victoria, we welcome the final draft of the legislation. We welcome the benefits that will come directly to Victoria through the National Heritage Trust for the areas in the Murray‐Darling project. There is $163 million there, Senator Sherry. Victoria will be the greatest beneficiary of that. The national vegetation initiative and the coasts and clean seas initiative are both $100 million projects which would never get off the ground unless we have the benefits of the one‐third sale of Telstra. Victoria will benefit from that.

Just as Victoria welcomes the final draft of the legislation before the Senate, the National Party welcomes the improvements foreshadowed by Senator Alston. Clearly, the National Party is unashamed and unabashed. It is a sectional party. We represent the rural and regional areas. That has been our mission statement for some 76 years now. We are the second oldest party in the parliament. We have that mission statement and we have stuck to it in that 76 years, so why wouldn't we utterly support the final draft of the Telstra one‐third sale?

It has been utterly impossible to reconcile the rhetoric of the speakers from the opposition side against their actions. When the opposition was in government, weren't they the ones who sold the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas? More so the Commonwealth Bank: they made commitments that they would not sell it, and they did. Where were the great defenders of the Commonwealth Bank from the socialist left faction when the Commonwealth Bank was put up for sale? I do not think one of them came into this chamber and made a speech on the final sale of the Commonwealth Bank. The difference between your privatisation—which we supported—and ours is that there is a strategy with our privatisation. We are not going to waste the billions of dollars like you did. Where did the money for the Commonwealth Bank go? Up in smoke in deficit and debt. Our strategy is to use the sale of one‐third of Telstra to reduce debt and to establish the National Heritage Trust.

Then there are the attacks upon the two Independent senators—not that they can't look after themselves. They have been in this chamber for a very long time—both of them for over 20 years. The accusations of sleazy deals is emotive rubbish which is unbecoming of the reputation the senators have. Quite frankly, the discussions have been transparent. They have been open—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they haven't!

—They have been, Senator. They are utterly transparent so that the Australian public can see them and judge them. The government has accepted the moves that were put forward. `Slush fund' was another emotive term used in this debate. Nothing could be more false when you consider that, when the opposition were in government, they were the masters of the slush fund. The most infamous of them all, of course, was the sports rorts incident. It will go down in political folklore in this parliament. When we are long gone the sports rorts incident and the whiteboard incident will stay as examples of the greatest slush funds of all. There are others. There was the better cities program—hundreds of millions of dollars, a lot of which ended up on Lower Plenty Road in Melbourne. That road just happened to be in the electorate of the former Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, the man who oversaw the better cities program. Lower Plenty Road is now a much‐improved road. There was something very sectional about the divvying up of the better cities program.

SPEECH.PARA: The big loser here, of course, is the Greens party. Senator Margetts, sooner or later you are going to have to shake off Senator Brown. He really is bringing you down. I see that, from time to time, when you sit in front of him. He can't see the look on your face half the time. Sooner or later you are going to have to shake him off. You missed the perfect opportunity. When Christabel Chamarette was here she would never have allowed this opportunity to slip by. But, because you have been caught up in Senator Brown's net—it is almost Senator Brown's dominance of your faction—you have allowed the most perfect opportunity to slip by you. You can't continue for the rest of your term—your last and final term, it seems—to be hell‐bent on just running a political agenda. Sooner or later you are going to have to vote on the environment agenda. You lost a perfect opportunity here because you listened to Senator Brown, who has delivered nothing for the Tasmanian environment. You missed a perfect opportunity.

I want to make some final points as far as the government strategy for the one‐third sale of Telstra is concerned. It is part of a strategy. It is linked with a balanced budget. It is linked with the privatisation. It is linked with the national Heritage Trust. All of it benefits the rural and regional areas. Nothing seared the soul of the rural area more than the damage done by the previous government during the eighties and nineties in regard to high interest rates. You absolutely bashed the living daylights out of the rural and regional areas through your high interest rates program. The one‐third sale of Telstra, linked with a balanced budget, will have a downward pressure on debt and deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come off it!

—We have already seen the results of it, Senator Sherry. The downward pressure is there already. So allow us to implement our strategy for the sake of rural and regional areas. You cannot just pull one lever and fix the rural and regional areas. There has to be a strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: We are into the emotional and filibustering stages of the committee stage, and we are going to hear the same old rhetoric, the same old emotive words like `back deal' and `sleazy'. The truth of the matter is the Australian public supported this government and its policy for a one-third sale of Telstra. To that end, the Independents have endorsed the public's endorsement of our policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not spoken in the Telstra debate to date, so I am pleased to have this opportunity to bring to the debate what I believe are some thoughtful comments. I earnestly hope Senator Harradine will take notice of them. I know the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) will not take notice, and Senator Colston will take some notice. There are some aspects of both the national deal that the Liberal and National parties presented to the electorate and the more recent deal that Senator Harradine and Senator Colston have entered into that I want to draw to their attention and highlight to the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I do that, I want to touch on a couple of matters that Senator McGauran, on behalf of the National Party of Australia, raised. He maintains that the establishment of the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, with $1.1 billion, is great for the Australian environment. Senator McGauran, I hope you are listening. You said that $163 million out of this $1.1 billion would be committed to the Murray‐Darling Basin. I hope that Senator Alston can confirm whether or not that is true.

Senator McGauran, you said that the clean‐up of the Murray‐Darling Basin would never get off the ground. I would like to draw your attention to Budget Paper No. 1, page 3‐142, which gives the primary industry forward estimates. It says:
Murray-Darling Basin Initiative—cessation of additional funding to improve natural resource management

Senator McGauran, in the last Labor budget—obviously in your National Party hype you are not aware of what occurred—the Labor government committed some $98 million to the cleaning up, in part at least, of the Murray-Darling Basin. This is but one area where we see quite significant reductions in expenditure for the environment to be offset through the partial sale of Telstra and the establishment of this National Heritage Trust Fund.

So, Senator McGauran, when you said that funding for the Murray-Darling clean‐up would never get off the ground, it was already off the ground. It is your government, in your Budget Paper No. 1, that will cut $98 million out of that program over the next four years. You can smile. It is the old pea and thimble trick: you take the money out of one area and switch it over into the other area. I would suggest that next time you read the budget papers a bit more closely. What we have here is a con.

One of the aspects I want to comment on is how the government has redefined recurrent expenditure as capital expenditure in the guise—it is really only an excuse or a dressing up—of selling one-third of Telstra. Before I get on to that, I refer to the contributions of Senator McGauran and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Senator Boswell), who is without a ministerial portfolio—we know why that is. Look at the contributions you have made to an analysis of why Telstra is being sold and what the benefits are. You talked for some time about drought. That is an important issue, but it really has nothing—very little—to do with the sale of Telstra. You talked about a range of other issues, like the poor provision of services in rural and regional areas and about petrol, shopping, water and TV. But that just highlights the reason why we are 100 per cent committed to 100 per cent Telstra ownership.

Telstra is one of the few commercial operations in this country which has delivered, in a very effective way, a very decent level of telecommunications service to all over Australia. Telstra has delivered a telecommunications service to the outback, to rural and regional Australians, to almost everyone in this country who has wanted an effective and efficient telecommunications system. Here you are supporting the one-third sale of Telstra—inevitably it will be all of Telstra—and you are arguing that it has not delivered an effective service to those areas. It has.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, Nick!

—Senator Alston, if we consider the enormous size of Australia—it is the same size as continental Europe and the US, excluding Alaska, and we have a much smaller population with a much lower urban density—generally, Telstra's efforts at delivering an efficient, modern telecommunications system at a reasonable cost to the vast majority of people in this country, particularly those in rural and regional areas, is second to none in the world. Yet here you are advocating a position where over time that effective, cost efficient delivery of telecommunications throughout the entire continental Australia will be eroded. Senator McGauran, that is the position you are supporting.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McGauran said he would speak ever so briefly. He did speak ever so briefly about the sale of Telstra. I note with some embarrassment that the National Party Whip had to try to wind him up twice, either because the content was so poor or because your own Whip is getting concerned about the time you have been wasting in contributing very little to this Telstra debate.

BREAK.PARA: It is a very sad reflection of the modern‐day National Party when you and Senator Boswell, in your contributions to this debate, are nothing more than a doormat. It is follow‐the‐leader. You are the real tail, but you are not the tail wagging the coalition any more. You are the real doormat in policy terms of this government. You really are.

Senator McGauran, you have had no major wins and no major, great new policy initiatives on behalf of the National Party, and you are devoid of any influence in this government. If that is the best you can do, if you cannot maintain any more relevance that you displayed today, then you will not be the second oldest political party in this country but you will certainly be the party that will disappear very quickly over the next decade.

I wish to deal with the issue of the broader package. Up to the announcement of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) following his holiday, when he hit upon this magic repackaging of using part of the proceeds from the one-third sale of Telstra, it was very clearly Liberal-National parties' policy to use all income from the asset sale to reduce debt. That was your policy very clearly up to that point in time. As shadow finance minister, I would have to say that that is a policy perspective I agree with. So long as I have any input into that, I will maintain that.

But, Senator Alston, you redefine capital expenditure in recurrent expenditure terms by devoting just over $1 billion in recurrent expenditure. In the budget—I have already highlighted one area—we had allocated $98 million of recurrent expenditure off the budget in the primary industry portfolio, which you have cut. You have cut recurrent expenditure, yet you make it up by selling capital and calling it an investment.

If you can get away with that, you can get away with selling anything, any part of Telstra, and redefining it as capital expenditure. You could come up with $1 billion worth of road funding on this principle and say that it is an investment. You could even fund the dental health program on the basis that money from the sale of Telstra is capital investment in people's teeth! If you follow that logic through, you can sell any capital asset and redefine it as an investment, decrease recurrent expenditure and offset that in part or in whole, which is exactly what you have done here.

That is wrong in principle. It is particularly wrong in principle when it is little more than a bribe to the environment movement in the context of the package that was announced at the election: sell one-third of Telstra and take $1.1 billion over four years in order to try and minimise the opposition of environmental groups at the last election. That is the national package. I will come very shortly to the bribe at the regional level in respect of Senator Harradine and Senator Colston, who, regrettably, is not here.

The only other point I make in relation to the danger of using what is effectively money from an asset sale for recurrent expenditure is: what happens in four years? Senator McGauran, even on your figures of $163 million, what is to happen in four years? I understand that the Murray-Darling basin will need billions of dollars to repair the environmental damage there. Where is the money going to come from in four years time?

Senator McGauran, I would suggest to you and to Senator Harradine and Senator Colston that when the Prime Minister said in relation to the sale of the remaining two-thirds of Telstra, `We will consider our position much further down the track,' that time will be in about four years. When the current government says that it will not increase taxes—it has in a number of areas, but that is another argument for another day—when it comes to the election in three or four years time, it will have to look around and find other areas of money and it will sell the remaining two-thirds of Telstra and redefine that in terms of redirecting the money into some sort of capital expenditure, whether it be highways, dental health or any number of other areas.

I draw to the attention of Senator Harradine and Senator Colston to page 3142 of the forward estimates. The Murray-Darling basin was not the only area of environmental expenditure that was cut. That was cut by $98 million. There was a cessation of the national landcare program—$201 million taken out of the forward estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Robbing Peter to pay Paul.

—That is not the only area where environmental expenditure was cut. If we look at the portfolio savings of the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, we see that the vast majority were on environmental expenditure—$165 million over four years. If you add that up, you have got about $450 million of environmental expenditure cut out of the next three years forward estimates, not including this current budget financial year. It is robbing Peter to pay Paul, as Senator Schacht makes the point. There will be $450 million of environmental expenditure cuts over the next four years and we are going to get $1.1 billion back, apparently, through the one-third sale of Telstra.

BREAK.PARA: I have always respected Senator Harradine. He knows that; we go back a long way. I have always respected him as an astute deal maker. I would like to comment on the article that appeared on page 1 of the Examiner of last Friday. It is headlined `Harradine's bonanza'. I have learnt from long experience that you do not condemn someone from a newspaper clipping, because often it is not accurate. As I look through `Harradine's bonanza', one of the points made is `Telstra jobs saved that were earmarked for the axe'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't—

—I am not saying that you said that, Senator Harradine, but I would like Senator Alston to tell us whether the Telstra jobs that are `earmarked for the axe' are in fact going to be saved, whether he has given a categorical undertaking, because I do not believe that has been given.

BREAK.PARA: All we have here, Senator Harradine, is the creation of 170 new jobs and, at the same time, the loss, I understand, of 160 to 180 jobs over the next two years. I put it to you that at least some or perhaps all of these jobs were probably in Telstra's forward plan for the next three years anyway. So what is the net gain?

The other point I would make, Senator Harradine, if we look down this list of the alleged bonanza—a $10 million tree planting program, $10 million on revegetation and fencing, $6 million on threatened species program, $5 million on land for a wildlife integration scheme, $5 million for the heritage track upgrade—is that all of those areas of expenditure were in the forward estimates anyway under Labor, at least in part if not in whole. Some $450 million worth of expenditure on the areas, Senator Harradine, that you argued for were already commitments of a Labor government four years ahead of time.

We have really got a situation here where you rob Peter to pay Paul in selling off one‐third of Telstra and, inevitably, Senator Harradine—and I think you know in your own heart of hearts this is true—the total sell‐off of Telstra in three or four years time. That will be to Tasmania's detriment in terms of jobs, the environment, investment and phone charges and calls. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I felt I needed to answer some of the statements that Senator McGauran has made and to talk about the sheer cheek of suggesting that he knows that former Senator Christabel Chamarette would have voted for the sale of Telstra. She was never ever hoodwinked in that way. The reality is that the bill was never about the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry has indicated, and Senator Kernot and I made this statement very early in the piece, that this never was a big spending package. The indications were that the rug was being pulled out from under the environment even faster than you were putting up this false front of care and concern. In fact, what is happening is a shifting of resources from the environment portfolio, some of which are going to the primary industry portfolio and out of the control of the environment portfolio. The whole thing has been a ruse from beginning to end, but a vast number of people were aware of this all along.

I resent any indication that I need to take directions from any other senator in relation to the way I place my vote. I certainly made my own mind up in relation to whether or not this bill stinks. I believe, quite frankly, that this bill stinks. Therefore, whether or not there are concerns about the link to the environment package—and I mentioned that right from the beginning—it was my own decision. I resent being patronised in that I have to take somebody else's direction to work out what is the right and wrong thing to do about the sale of an asset like Telstra.

Senator McGauran said—and I thank Senator McGauran for giving me these extra points; I am sure the government really does want to speed along the debate on this bill but that is not going to happen when you have Senator McGauran winding people up in this way, but I am happy to oblige—that I should vote for environment not politics. What a load of hypocrisy! If anything has been a political ploy, an ideological ploy, a cynical ploy in this place it has been the link between the sale of Telstra and this shoddy package, this shoddy connection that we have seen.

If we want to talk environment, let us talk environment. Let us talk about each of the issues of concern in terms of ecological sustainability in Australia. Let us see where the coalition has stood and see where the Greens have stood and then judge people on their performance and what they should be doing for the environment. What the coalition has been doing is cutting programs and divesting themselves as fast as they can of their responsibilities on the environment. In the end the community knows that this is happening because they can see it. They can see it in their own sphere.

The Western Australian government is making every opportunity count. When responsibility is divested from the federal government they take every opportunity to put planning and corporate concerns ahead of the environment. In the end what it means is that nobody ends up with the ability to look after the environment. You have federal government pulling money off the states. You have federal government divesting itself of responsibility and pulling money out of the states or not giving any extra resources so the states can take that up even if they wanted to and, in the case of Western Australia, they do not.

We do need in the end to be looking at these responsibilities—and I have mentioned this on several occasions—in terms of a full community debate about having a constitution which makes ecological sustainability the right of every citizen of Australia, so you do not have this handballing of environmental responsibility from one level of government to the other. It should be the responsibility of every level of government.

I think Senator McGauran's contribution today is a nonsense. Certainly the statements that he has been making in the chamber can only serve to get other people in the chamber wound up and standing up to respond to such nonsense. It is not worthy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a contribution at this stage of the debate. In particular, I want to pick up on some of the arguments that have been used to justify the vote of those who have supported this proposal to sell one-third of Telstra at this stage. I listened to Senator Harradine this morning as he tried to justify the fact that he has not done a deal. There is no other way to describe what Senator Harradine has done. He has done a deal. The more he protests, the sillier and the less convincing it sounds.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine says, `I had to take mandate into account. I had to take into account a mandate of what the people of Australia said in my deliberations.' I understand that you might have taken a lot of things into account, Senator Harradine, but what part of what mandate?

As I understand it, the government went to the people promising, in an area in which I have a particular interest, that they would not in any way remove the operational subsidy in child care, that they would not in any way cut back public child care, that they would not reduce child care assistance, and that they would not means test the child care cash rebate.

Every single one of those promises they broke almost immediately. Where is the mandate in that argument, Senator Harradine? Why were you not assisting the opposition in holding the government to what it promised to do? What is different about the mandate in Telstra from the mandate in other areas of government policy? I would like to hear your words on that, because I find that your argument that `I have a mandate; therefore, I have not done a deal' is totally unconvincing.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Schacht has just explained, I think very persuasively, that the deal Senator Harradine has done is for about 14 jobs in Tasmania. It might be 30, it might be 16, or it might be 15. As for the infrastructure, Telstra was already going to spend that money. So it is a very small deal that you have done. I would like to ask what else is part of your deal. Is it part of further reductions to the family planning funding that this country spends? Is it your view on IVF, which you so curiously publicise at exactly the same time as the Telstra deal goes through?

The people in Australia are very concerned. Thousands of us are very concerned about what it is that you are negotiating with this government and how much of it is related to your done deal in Telstra. You would not really want to do a deal for just a few jobs, would you, Senator Harradine? I will come back to the issue of family planning in a minute.

Senator Harradine says that he is very concerned about jobs in Tasmania. What is the difference between a Telstra job and a child‐care job? Why do you seem to have no regard at all for the way this government is cutting back its funding to child care and dramatically reducing the number of people employed in it? Or is it that there are women working and you would prefer to see them at home?

Why are you prepared to support 14 miserly jobs in Telstra as part of a done deal but you are not prepared to stand up and support jobs in the child‐care industry, for example? Do you not know about them, or do you not think they are as real or as important as Telstra jobs? Or is it that some other package of agreement between you and the government does not come if you defend child care but it does come if you defend Telstra? Perhaps that gives the government more to manipulate with, more promises.

I find your argument very unpersuasive. It is a deal. There is no other word for it. Some people might want to say that it is a sleazy deal. I think it is a pretty unattractive deal. But there is no doubt that it is a done deal. Your arguments in putting your case today are totally unconvincing. If you go the mandate argument, then there is a very good case to ask, `Why this bit of the mandate and not any other bits?' Why are you not holding this government up to honour its promise to continue and totally protect its commitment to public child care?

Why, when you so often speak about the importance of family, do you not support the maintenance of that tier of child care which has done so much to establish adequate and important quality standards for child care? If those are not important issues for you, then it is a very hollow argument that you make about mandate.

I would like to hear you explain what it is about a Telstra job that matters as compared to a child‐care job that seemingly does not matter. It cannot be that it is associated with a very big contribution by the government, can it? Or is it that it is part of a broader package and that you do not want them associated? In the minds of lots of people, they are associated. You write letters to this government, which you leak or have publicised, about your preference to see family planning funding, a contribution under the aid budget, reduced—and so it has been.

I have just returned from a visit to New York, where I was able to have a number of appointments in the United Nations, including with the United Nations family planning authority. They are enormously disappointed at this government cutting its contribution to family planning by one-third. This means that thousands of women around the world are going to get pregnant when they do not want to, are going to be denied adequate contraception and are going to have to resort to abortion.

TALK.START.PARA: —For Telstra—what else?

—Precisely, Senator Kernot. I think you say it very well by interjection. It is a done deal, and it ties these things together. I have to say that, for many of those women who will resort to abortion—
—That's going a bit far, isn't it?
—Not at all.
—That's what happens.

—That is what happens. This is an independent senator who is prepared to negotiate and do a deal with the government of the day. He is not only doing a deal for 14 jobs in Tasmania. Nobody would do a deal for 14 jobs, but they would do a deal for a few other bits and pieces that matter very importantly to that senator.

BREAK.PARA: I cannot be persuaded by Senator Harradine's arguments in this place today. I listened to them very closely. What were his arguments to justify why, having opposed the sale of Telstra, having been a speaker in favour of public sector involvement, he would now change his mind? `I have to consider the mandate,' he says, but apparently not the mandate that the voters voted for when it came to this government's commitment to maintain all their promises in child care. They went out the window, and they seemingly did not trouble Senator Harradine one iota.

This government lied to the people of Australia about what it intended to do in child care. I have letters from the then shadow minister, Mr Kemp, dated 28 February, getting pretty close to election day, promising in writing to not attack or do anything to the operational subsidy and to do nothing to reduce their commitment to public sector child care. They immediately reneged on both of those promises. So what is the mandate? Only a selective mandate, I would say, and I say that to Senator Harradine. I have to also say that it is not persuasive in his arguments to me. I am very concerned that Senator Harradine's deal on Telstra is part of a broader package. It is part of a package that has seen a reduction in funding to international family planning by this government by one-third of its aid budget. That is a matter of great concern.

If you are looking at the economic development of countries, if you are looking at what is proven already to be the best advantage of those countries, then it is providing opportunities for the women as well as the men in those countries. You cannot talk about advantaging families if you do not talk about advantaging women. That is exactly the same as what the Labor policies were in terms of child care, education, training and family support—all its policies for families also took account of the importance of assisting women.

Again, that is true of our commitment through the aid budget to assist women through development programs, through contraceptive advice and through provision of services to assist women in Third World countries to make those choices. Senator Harradine has actually persuaded this government to dramatically reduce its funding and to deny women those choices. Was that a mandate?

Did this Howard government go to the people of Australia saying, `We intend to cut funding to family planning.' Did they intend to rearrange the provision of in-vitro fertilisation programs or any of those things that Senator Harradine now puts out into the public airways as part of the Telstra deal—part of this sordid little exercise that Senator Harradine has brought into this place? That is what it has to be: a done deal, because Senator Harradine is not persuasive. His arguments are not convincing.

You should be distressed and uncomfortable, Senator Harradine. After having tried to take the high moral ground over the years in this place, you have just brought your own reputation significantly into question. Senator, the blood of the women of the world who might have to seek abortion instead of contraception will be on your hands in relation to Tasmanian telephones. That is how it will be. As part of the deal with the government, you will be responsible for that revolting choice.

You cannot possibly justify this deal with the argument that you have put in this place. It is a deal much broader than the Telstra deal. We know that from what has been spelt out by opposition speakers on this bill and by a clear analysis of what Senator Alston announced by way of the final arrangements. With a grin on his face, he stated, `We've fixed it, we've stitched it up, we've got the deal done—$350 million is all it took to buy the votes we needed.'

Senator, I do not know what feedback you got over the weekend; perhaps you speak to people who are pleased about deals like that. But everywhere I went on the weekend—from the fruit and vegetable shop to the butcher, to Coles, to the supermarkets—everybody I met, very ordinary Australians, were at pains to tell me that they thought this was a done deal, a bribe, a buy‐off or a payback, whichever: $350 million to get the votes of two Independents.

Senator Harradine, the high moral ground that you might have established in the past is gone for all time. Senator Harradine, if you are going to argue mandate, argue it with consistency. You have not done that. You are not voting with consistency. I am not persuaded by what you say. I am extremely disheartened and disappointed that you should stoop to this public betrayal of your own principles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to return to answer some of the points Senator Harradine made in his speech when he said, `This is not a deal'—and I do not think there is a single person in Australia who would think this was not a deal. I would take this opportunity to read just a small number of the huge selection of editorials and commentary which use the word `deal'. They say absolutely and more clearly than you might expect—or Senator Harradine might like—how this deal was viewed.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin with the Sydney Morning Herald editorial on Friday. It says:
Pork‐barrelling is not unknown in Australia, but the purchasing of votes has never been quite as blatant as that which took place yesterday in the Senate.

It goes on to make some critical comments about the Labor Party's record on privatisation and about the opposition of the Democrats to privatisation. But it concludes by saying that Mr Beazley should have taken a more realistic attitude before yesterday. It says:
He could have ensured that Senator Harradine and Senator Colston were not in a position to blackmail the Government.
That is a pretty serious accusation. The Sunday Age editorial from yesterday says:
Mr Howard concluded a costly deal—
there is a that word again—
with the two independents

What is significant about the support of the two independent senators is that it had to be bought at taxpayers' expense. Not in the reprehensible sense of personal bribes or preferment (although the Coalition had helped Senator Colston secure his coveted post of deputy president of the Senate), but in extra spending commitments of their respective states.
It goes on to say:

Pork‐barrelling is not new to Australian politics. All governments and would‐be governments offer inducements to marginal electorates, influential interests and troublesome politicians to secure their votes or support. The latest Senate deals—
once again there is that word—
are something else again.

In the Australian today there is a simple paragraph in an article by George Megalogenis, which says, `Under the deal which is skewed towards Tasmania and Queensland'. In the Age of 7 December, Laura Tingle says:
After eight months of threats of double dissolutions, Government abuse and debates about mandates, the sense of confrontation between the coalition and the Senate had dissipated.
In its place, a rather tawdry smell of pork‐barrelling and seedy deals—
d‐e‐a‐l‐s—
which left even Brian Harradine clearly feeling uncomfortable.

Nothing can beat this one—the front page of the Mercury in Tasmania: `Tassie deal swings sale'. I bet Senator Harradine enjoyed reading that—that terrible d‐e‐a‐l word. In the Weekend Australian , page 4, George Megalogenis states:
The Federal Government revealed yesterday the final plank of its Telstra sale deal with the two Independent senators . . .
The Herald‐Sun editorial from last Friday says:
Thanks to some unashamed horse‐trading, the Telstra partial sell‐off seems certain of final parliamentary approval next week.

Another article was headed, `Dial D for deal done'. Senator Harradine does not like to hear this allegation of a deal, but nothing he has said has been able to convince most of us listening that it was anything but that. The Sun‐Herald `Candid Comment', by Peter Robinson, says:

. . . Mr Howard deals in pragmatism and not principle. He worked out a deal with the two independent senators, Tasmania's Brian Harradine and Queensland's Mal Colston, which will ensure their States get special benefits from the $10 billion or so which the Telstra sale will bring in.
Somewhat lost in all of this is the little matter of national benefit.

That is what a deal is. A deal is when you make some special arrangement to advantage a few people in Australia at the expense of the rest of Australians, and in this case Australian workers. I really hope Senator Harradine, whatever he is doing, can listen to some of these comments, not because I think they are brilliant but because I would really like him to answer some of the comments being made.

Beyond what is now publicised, I have not lost sight of the fact that when we were all asked to vote on this matter on Thursday we knew practically nothing. We knew nothing about the terms of reference for the committee. We were told, `Oh, but have faith. I'm going to delay the proclamation date of this bill.' We knew very little until Senator Alston's second reading speech, but even at the end of that we knew a great deal less than what we found out in the press release late on Thursday night, well after we had voted in this place.

I do not call that a transparent deal or arrangement, which was what Senator McGauran was referring to. In relation to however many pages were in the document that was published in the arrangement between the Democrats and the government on the industrial relations bill, everything was up front before the debate began and every detail of the change was tracked.

When is an unspoken deal a deal? When is influence or things hanging around in the ether part of a current deal or a future deal? Senator Harradine expressed some surprise when Senator Crowley raised the issue of family planning and linked it to Telstra. I think the reason she did that is the article from yesterday's Sunday Age by Paul Daley, which certainly came to my attention. It says:

BREAK.PARA: Independent Senator Brian Harradine, who last week indicated crucial support for the Federal Government's bill to sell one-third of Telstra, has made a new bid for restrictions on IVF technology.
It is the next part that I think is interesting in terms of answering the question of whether or not deals have to be overt and clearly linked with the issue in question. The second paragraph says:

`The Sunday Age' has established that, in the lead-up to the Senate's vote on Telstra last Thursday, Senator Harradine met or otherwise lobbied at least three senior ministers—the Attorney-General, Mr Daryl Williams, the Science Minister, Mr Peter McGauran, and the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tim Fischer—about challenging the legal status of patients on key IVF technology.
It goes on to say:

Well‐placed Government figures told `The Sunday Age' that Senator Harradine's concerns were being treated seriously from the office of the Prime Minister down. They said he could expect to get concessions on tighter rules for couples entering the IVF program, and on the patenting issue.
I would like Senator Harradine to tell us whether or not it was just a total coincidence that this was raised last week in the final stages of negotiations on the Telstra sale bill.
Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —These issues I was just talking about, Senator Harradine. Is it total coincidence that these issues keep getting raised at crucial times; always hanging around in the ether; this government pussyfooting around all the time, afraid to upset Senator Harradine and afraid to dismiss any of his concerns, no matter what their policy on these matters might have been over time? There is more than one way to make a deal.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Harradine also relies on the mandate argument. Senator Crowley has already talked about how that argument was certainly applied very selectively with respect to child care. I would like to raise the issue of selective application of that principle to industrial relations reform. How come you could vote against all of that, Senator Harradine, when that was quite clearly a very important part of the coalition's election campaign?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because I applied principle.
—Oh, you applied principle to that. So it was okay to vote against that, even though under your argument this government would have a mandate?
—No.
—Oh, it wouldn't have a mandate. Where was that measured?
—Because you apply principle, as I said.
—Senator Kernot, address your questions to the chair, please.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I assert again: what is the different principle here? You say, `A mandate is a mandate. They took this issue to the people.' They took the industrial relations reforms to the people as well, but for some reason you can find a distinction between the mandate as applied to industrial relations and the mandate as applied to the sale of Telstra.

BREAK.PARA: I do not care how many times any person in the government ranks wants to get up and quote `mandate' on Telstra to me, I will always draw from what I know was measured in the campaign. Not much in specific detail was measured, but, my goodness, the issue of Telstra was measured and it was measured as it was being debated. On 31 January, straight after the election was called, an AGB McNair poll was reported on in the Sydney Morning Herald. It stated:

In a Herald AGB poll conducted last weekend nearly two-thirds of voters said they opposed the sale of any part of Telstra. Only seven per cent of those polled said they supported selling all of Telstra to private investors. Only 22 per cent said they would support the coalition's idea of selling a third of Telstra. Sixty-one per cent said they opposed the sale of any part of the corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that, Senator Kernot?

—That was 31 January 1996. The point I want to make by reading out more polls is that they did not change significantly throughout the entire election campaign. The government can bleat all it likes about mandate. On this particular issue they are wrong, and that is why they have not rushed into a double dissolution on the sale of Telstra. They know how the Australian public feel about the privatisation of Telstra, of one-third or the lot of it.

BREAK.PARA: The second poll I want to quote is a Newspoll conducted on 14 February, two weeks later. A newspoll survey conducted for the Australian found 39 per cent in favour of the policy of linking the $1 billion environment program to the sale of a third of Telstra, 48 per cent against and the remainder undecided. On 20 February, deep in the heart of the election campaign, a Morgan poll in the Bulletin stated:

An overwhelming majority of electors in the Bulletin Morgan survey decided that, when asked if the Senate should have the right to prevent the coalition from selling part of Telstra, 64 per cent agreed and 29 per cent did not.

I repeat: 64 per cent. That is a figure which held firm throughout the campaign. It was not something the government liked. I recall headline after headline talking about how this was the big dud in an otherwise successful election campaign. This was the big dud. The article about the poll of 20 February goes on to say:

John Howard cannot even claim support for the sale amongst coalition voters. Fifty per cent of coalition voters believe the sale should be blocked, while 44 per cent believe the Senate does not have the right to stop it.
It goes on to say:

The coalition is facing an uphill battle with the community even to get the proposal to the Senate at all. Sixty per cent of electors do not want Telstra sold, while 33 per cent of people believe it should be.
On 26 February, not long before election day, the Sydney Morning Herald stated in relation to another AGB McNair poll:
The coalition's plan to sell a third of Telstra and to use some of the proceeds to fund a $1.1 billion environment package has lost support during the election campaign—
that is the point; do not talk about mandate—
and is now opposed by a majority of voters, including a significant block of coalition voters, according to an AGB McNair poll.

If this was just one of the little details, the fine print, of the 55 policies released in 35 days, we might be able to say that there is a mandate in there somewhere. But it was not an obscure detail. It was measured. It was debated passionately, and the government did not win its case. So it is very dishonest to stand up on election night and every day afterwards and say, `We won the election. Therefore, we have a mandate to do every single thing we said we wanted to do.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this debate on the partial sale of Telstra more in sorrow than in anger. I must admit that last week I was pretty angry and a number of people on this side of the chamber were extremely angry about it. One of the major things the Tasmanian non-government senators had been arguing was Tasmania's special case. I say to Senator Harradine with respect that I do not believe this is a good deal for Tasmania. I genuinely mean that: I do not think it is a good deal for Tasmania. I appreciate the difficulties that Senator Harradine found himself in, but in the long term I do not think he will get many accolades from Tasmanians in relation to this.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kernot and others have adequately covered the issue of mandate. Certainly in relation to the campaign that the Labor Party ran for the election of Tasmanian senators, our opposition to the partial sale of Telstra was made very clear. Senator Bob Brown's campaign was similarly clear. Senator Harradine was not up for election this time.

As has been previously indicated, the job gains in Tasmania that appear to have been made in relation to this deal, arrangement or whatever people wish to call it—I think `deal' is still the most appropriate word—are largely ephemeral. That is the reality. Telstra has already confirmed eight per cent job cuts in Tasmania; that is, 116 job losses in Tasmania so far. With the deal came the announcement of the creation of 140 jobs—clearly a net gain of approximately 24 jobs—by the year 2000. What happens after the year 2000 is anybody's guess.

PARA.BREAK: As every Tasmanian senator would have read in the Mercury, the CPSU has already predicted approximately 500 job losses. The CEPU in Tasmania has predicted a similar figure. So I do not believe it is a good deal job‐wise for Tasmania, which has an ailing economy that requires remedial action, genu ine planning, a genuine industry plan and, above all, a viable communications infrastructure.

SPEECH.PARA: How can these jobs be guaranteed? I do not think we can get away from the fact that when the one-third sale of Telstra goes through—and we have had indications from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that within five years we will have the full sale of Telstra—there will be no guarantee that in the long term those jobs will remain. As has been alluded to by previous speakers, under the Corporations Law majority shareholders cannot make decisions that will disadvantage minority shareholders. If minority shareholders do not agree to jobs in Tasmania because it is not economically viable or the underpinning infrastructure is too difficult, then those jobs simply would not happen. They would be located somewhere else. So we cannot guarantee for the long term, or even for the short term, those jobs in Tasmania.

Other than the jobs aspect, there are several very fundamental questions that I want to talk about in relation to my home state and they go to the issues which have been raised consistently by Tasmanian senators. The first one that I want to talk about is cross‐subsidisation. The amount of money that Tasmania gets because it is the most ruralised state in Australia is approximately $9 million per annum. The cross‐subsidy actually assists people. I could go through all the figures but I will not. For example, most people in Launceston get a subsidy of approximately $730. There are subsidies in most places in Tasmania. To refresh people's memories as to what they are—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we talking about telecommunications here?
—Yes, we are. We are talking about cross‐subsidy, Minister. If you were listening, you might have understood that. The cross‐subsidies in Burnie—
—He does not hang on every word.
—I was hanging on every word.

—Yes, that's right; I am sure you do. The people in Tasmania will be pretty interested in this in the long term. The cross‐subsidy in Burnie is $850; Devonport, $600; Flinders Island, $4,930; King Island, $2,220; St Marys, $910; Queenstown, $1,250, and so on. There is no guarantee in this legislation that that cross‐subsidy will remain. There's not!

SPEECH.PARA: The words used in the legislation under the universal service obligation are `as efficiently and economically as practicable in terms of the application of the USO, in relation to that cross‐subsidy.' As the minister has said, and as the Prime Minister has clearly stated, what we are looking at now is not a one‐third privatisation of Telstra. We are looking at a three‐thirds privatisation of Telstra. If you can do something to strengthen the USO in terms of the cross‐subsidy that applies to Tasmania, I think it will make it a lot clearer to everybody.

There is no doubt in the long term that areas like Tasmania, which are largely unprofitable for privatised telcos, will not get those sorts of services. The subsidies will not remain and we will leave ourselves open to the vagaries of the market. That is what will happen. With respect, Senator Harradine, as Senator Sherry said before me, I think that you know that. That is the case. It has happened in the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not, it hasn't.

—It has happened in the United States; I have just been there; I have spoken to people there. It has happened in the UK and that is exactly what is going to happen in Tasmania. If it was not, Minister, then why did you bother cutting the deal with Senator Harradine in the first place? If it was not a concern in terms of technological backwaters, why did you bother cutting the deal with Senator Harradine in the first place?

SPEECH.PARA: In the long term, we will leave the Tasmanian economy further exposed, as I said before, to the vagaries of the market, we will have the situation where those cross‐subsidies cannot be guaranteed and we will have timed telephone calls. The Herald‐Sun today said, `Telstra is set to offer widespread timed calls next year as it battles Optus for the $6 billion local call market.' Let us cut the rhetoric here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let's get off the second reading and on to the committee stage.

—Let's do that. This is not a second reading speech. I am representing my state of Tasmania, and I am entitled to get up here and say what I want to say. I tell you that we will see timed local telephone calls in this country and I tell you that, when you have a fully privatised Telstra, you will see those subsidies to Tasmania go. In relation to jobs, as I have indicated before, we have a net gain of about 24—140 jobs by the year 2000. What happens after that we do not know.

BREAK.PARA: In terms of the mandate, I agree entirely with Senator Kernot. If the argument in relation to mandate that Senator Harradine has put to this chamber held, we would have support for the opposition parties in relation to higher education. What we have instead is 160 job losses at the University of Tasmania.

There is another debate which I think Senator Crowley referred to earlier, which is coming up this week, which has a deleterious effect on the Tasmanian economy and families in Tasmania and that is the one in relation to child care and the subsidy in relation to community based child‐care centres. I genuinely hope that Senator Harradine supports us in relation to this because it is going to have an enormous effect on family lives and working‐class Tasmanians.

To move on: the bottom line is that the reason that none of these things can be guaranteed in the long term is the lack of ministerial control in relation to the privatised telco, which has been talked about a lot. There is no ministerial direction, so the profit bottom line, and this casts no aspersions on anybody, is for the shareholders—and I have already talked about the provisions in relation to Corporations Law and minority shareholders.

To sum up, my contribution is more in sorrow than in anger. I do not think you needed a crystal ball to predict—certainly, Senator Alston let the cat out of the bag several months ago—the inexorable movement from the sale of one‐third to the sale of three‐thirds of Telstra and the effect that is going to have in Tasmania. I do appreciate the pressures that Senator Harradine was under in relation to negotiations with regard to our home state. But I think in the long run the only way to guarantee the technological innovations that we have talked about—the cross‐subsidies, the retention of untimed telephone calls and a genuine state‐of‐the‐art communications infrastructure in an island state which is desperately in need of that communications infrastructure—was to keep Telstra in public hands. That is the only way that that could have been guaranteed. The jobs issue, whilst it is not a bad try, is ultimately ephemeral and, in terms of social justice initiatives and the needs of the state of Tasmania, in the long term it is a bad deal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the problems I have with this legislation is with the provisions that have been inserted to help with the consumer protection, which is already there. You may think that perhaps it could be done better. Schedule 1, item 5, amends section 38 of the Telecommunications Act. That, in turn, has some fairly severe enforcement provisions—civil penalties, not criminal ones.
