SPEECH.PARA: If the government are putting in item 5 at the end of section 38, I was wondering why they were not putting in the matters that are set out in clause 87E. New division 6 talks about the customer service guarantee. A new section 87 has been suggested. That deals with the periods which will be taken to connect customers to specified kinds of telecommunications services, the periods that carriers may offer to customers when making those arrangements, the keeping of appointments and so on. There have to be standards made in relation to those matters, which Austel will make at the direction, as I understand it, of the minister.

I think it is a reasonable proposition that timed periods should be given for providers to make arrangements to connect their customers and so on. The provision whereby the customers can enforce those seem very clumsy indeed. Those provisions are set out in proposed new section 87F. To enforce what the government proposes in 87E, a person will have to take a common law action—they will have to go off to a court of competent jurisdiction. Yet he or she can recover no more than $3,000, and perhaps less than that. Even if he or she recovers it, they cannot recover it in terms of money, only as a credit. That would mean that to make any use of proposed new section 87F, a customer could not effectively change the supplier because the only way he or she can recover anything under 87F is through a credit given in the account that the customer has.

It seems to me that you do have the makings here of a regime which could help customers. But I think the effect of it as it now stands is that it will make things very difficult for a customer to enforce, unless you are willing to provide legal aid or to provide aid in the same way as the Employment Advocate is treated under the new workplace relations act. At some stage I would like the government to outline why this new division is set out as it is. It is clearly aimed at helping customers but it is divorced from other sections of the act, such as section 38, which tries to deal with customer protection. A discrete part of the act is made by 87E and 87F. Why that is so, I am not sure. Why it is so clumsy would be very interesting to know.

If any of those provisions are breached, it is not a criminal offence as set out in 87M. The only thing left to a customer is to go to some court of competent jurisdiction to get an amount of money, which might be quite small, and certainly no more than $3,000. It might well be thought that, if that is the position, nobody is going to take that sort of action, and you begin to wonder why division 6 is put in.

While I am on that subject, I look at 87H of proposed division 6 and notice that an evidentiary certificate issued by the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman is to be taken as evidence in the courts. I would be interested to know what opinion you have about that, given the Brandy case and other such cases. It seems to me that the provisions that you have here for customer protection are not as suitable as they could be. You might want to do something about that.

I now go to the issue of the Commonwealth ownership of Telstra. I ask how the government is going to keep the sale of one-third of Telstra to that level. The amount of Telstra that is to be sold might well go beyond one‐third. I notice proposed section 8BX states:
An Act is not invalidated by the fact that it constitutes an offence against this Part.

If the wish is to reduce the amount of Telstra sold to one‐third should it get beyond that, you will have to go through a whole series of actions, involving injunctions and other proceedings, which again is quite clumsy. I am interested to know what the government is going to do about that.

The next thing I would like to know is: what will the prospectus that will be issued for the sale of one-third of Telstra contain about future matters? It has been much debated here today whether one-third or, ultimately, three-thirds of Telstra are to be sold. I would have thought that that was a vital issue, particularly in the preparation of a prospectus, because someone who is going to buy a third of Telstra now might be very much affected by the knowledge of whether or not the whole of Telstra or even two-thirds of Telstra will be sold in the future.
I think the point Senator Margetts raised in this context does need looking at. What are the minority shareholders, the people who hold the one-third of Telstra, going to be able to do?

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 8AA on page 12 of the bill says that.
—Clause 8AA talks about a simplified outline and says:

SPEECH.PARA: The following is a simplified outline of this Part:
. The Commonwealth may sell one-third of its equity interest in Telstra, but must retain the remaining two-thirds.
I was on a separate point, but that brings to light what I was formerly talking about. If more than one-third is sold, what is the machinery by which it is taken back to one-third?

TALK.START.PARA: —If it accidentally sells more?
—Yes, if it floats beyond. What happens in those circumstances?

BREAK.PARA: If you look at clauses 8AB, 8AC, 8BH and 8BI, then the sorts of things that Senator Harradine is talking about do become interesting. Clause 8BI says that, if Telstra contravenes subsection (1), it can be fined up to 500 penalty units, but there is nothing there that says that what they have done is invalidated. Clause 8BI creates an offence, but the offence itself does not invalidate anything that is done under the relevant part—part 2. It seems to me that, at the very least, there is some tightening up to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about 8BJ?

—Yes, that was what I was saying before. The only way you can do it is to go through what may be a very protracted exercise and make use of injunctions and other proceedings to see whether you can redress the balance. Clause 8BK says:

BREAK.PARA: (1) The object of the section is to allow the regulations to reduce the ownership limit percentages in the event that the Commonwealth's one-third equity interest in Telstra is transferred in 2 or more tranches.

It then goes on to talk about regulations being made. So there are regulatory provisions. But, if you look at the whole scheme, it is very hard to see how this scheme presents a fairly expeditious and inexpensive way of keeping the Telstra sale down to one-third.

These are the sorts of things that ought to be looked at if a prospectus is going to be issued—as it must; it will have to be issued within the next few months. What is the future of Telstra? What rights will minority shareholders have? As Senator Margetts said, are you going to deny these minority shareholders the rights that other minority shareholders have in other companies? If you are going to use Telstra to perform community service obligations or if you are going to use it to fill in an area where no other carrier will go, are you going to tell the people this when you put it out for shareholders to purchase? I think that is a real problem.

You will also have a position as to the winding up of Telstra. Telstra could be wound up by 8BY. So there is a contemplation here that Telstra, in fact, might be wound up. In other words, it is not guaranteed that this company will continue into the future.

The other point I want to raise is the expenditure of money that will be allowed under these provisions to discharge Telstra's debt to get it into a better position than it presently is. That should be exercised by the minister, but that operation can be delegated to others. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address a particular issue in relation to the telecommunications infrastructure package that we heard about last Thursday for the first time and that we are now beginning to see leaking out in dribs and drabs. There is an article by Lenore Taylor in today's Financial Review entitled `MPs question rural Telecom fund numbers'. It explains that the breakdown for this telecommunications infrastructure package has been done by working out the percentage of each state's population that live outside the non-capital areas. That is fine, but it is not as though the state populations are equal and it is not as though the size of the states is equal.

SPEECH.PARA: The article quotes one of my National Party colleagues, the member for the electorate of Parkes, Mr Michael Cobb, who is very upset about what is going to happen here. According to the figures, funding per capita in New South Wales is going to be $15.99. Mr Cobb's electorate of Parkes is bigger than the state of Tasmania, yet the constituents in his electorate are going to get $15.99 a head. People living in Tasmania are going to be worth $208.41 a head.

Something is not right here because we know—according to the figures from Lenore Taylor's article—that about four per cent of the non-capital city population of Australia is accounted for by Tasmania. New South Wales has a non-capital city population of 2,399,000‐odd people. Tasmania has a non-Hobart population of 278,300. You are not measuring apples with apples.

In New South Wales, the most populous state—one of the bigger states; a state that does have rural and provincial areas and remote areas—we are being ripped off. There are no other words to use but the words `ripped off'. We are not getting a fair deal out of this. Not even the National Party members are getting a fair deal out of this. They have been walked over by their Liberal Party colleagues. It is an appalling state of affairs that this should be allowed to happen. Why? I am not going to go into the whys. There have been plenty of newspaper articles as to why.

Let us look at a few of the communities in Mr Cobb's electorate. Let us look at Tibooburra. It is about four hours drive from Bourke. It is about four hours drive from Broken Hill on unsealed roads—some of the worst roads in this country. They have a population of about 1,000. On occasions their electricity still comes from generators. They have a distance education centre. They are actually servicing the education needs of children who come from the far north‐western corner of New South Wales. It includes children in Queensland in the Nappa Merrie and those areas, and it goes across into South Australia and its upper reaches. That is the closest area for those children to get education from.

So Tibooburra has a population of about 1,000. It might be 1,200, but let's say it is 1,000. Because it is in New South Wales, that community would be attracting $15,999. If it were in Tasmania, a community of that size would attract $208,410. I am talking about a community that, in driving time, is almost further away from anywhere than anywhere in Tasmania is from Hobart. Maybe if you have a snow storm up the Midlands you will not be able to get through in four hours.

I am also talking about an area that does not have all-weather roads. It has to rely on the Royal Flying Doctor Service for its medical emergencies and for its medical services. I am talking about a place where children who require education in secondary school have to go away and board. These people are going to be attracting less than $16,000 for their telecommunications needs. Do not tell me they do not have telecommunications needs, because they do. I have been there. I am one of the few members of parliament who have actually been to Tibooburra—

TALK.START.PARA: —Me too.
—And Senator Murphy has been there as well.
—Hang on.

—There are not too many who have been there, Senator Harradine. If you have been there, I apologise. because there are not too many who have been. It is jolly hot and dusty in summer and it is pretty chilly in the middle of winter.

BREAK.PARA: You can go out to another area in Mr Cobb's electorate—the central Darling shire based on Wilcannia. It is almost as big as Tasmania in its own right. It has a population of not much more than 4,000. What would a population of 4,000 in New South Wales get you on these figures for their telecommunications needs and upgrading? In New South Wales it will get you about $64,000. In Tasmania, a population centre of that size will get you $825,640. How can anybody stand here and tell me that that is fair and just—a fair go to everybody?

There is no justice in that, Minister. You cannot justify the shonky figures, the shonky deal you have done. You cannot justify the implications of this and the discrimination against my state of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —The rural people.
—The rural people of New South Wales. No wonder your National Party colleagues are not in here. No wonder some of your National Party colleagues are going mad.
—It has all been spent in Sydney.

—Senator Harradine, you do not care at all about what is happening to the rural people of New South Wales. Sydney city has a large population. It is the size of international cities and it is competitive with international cities of large standing. Let us not regard that. We are talking about the telecommunication needs of non‐metropolitan areas in this country. You are letting New South Wales down in a huge way.

BREAK.PARA: Broken Hill is out in this area. That is an area that gets in excess of $3,000 per year per phone line in universal service obligation payments. This is the sort of area that you want to criticise and crucify. It is the only word to be used. You are crucifying the telecommunications needs of rural New South Wales for those of other states. I do not mind sharing. As a good socialist I think sharing equitably is a very good thing to do. But the formula that is being used in this is as shonky as can be. It has to be. It takes no cognisance of terrain. It takes no cognisance of demographics. It is just a shonky deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes note of the votes you have to get in the Senate.
—Yes, Senator Schacht. I think that is a very appropriate interjection.
—How much did the government spend in Sydney per head?

—Let us talk about the rural areas of this country. Some of us here have a great concern for and spend a great deal of time in the rural areas of this country. Let us not look at the city areas. Those city areas are international hubs for business industry. Of course they have to be competitive and have to have services that are the equivalent of and better than overseas places. What I want to push and want people to realise is that there is this huge discrepancy in the funding that is going to be available to different states in the way it has been worked out.

BREAK.PARA: New South Wales will get $37.4 million for its telecommunications infrastructure package. Victoria will get $28.5 million. That is only $22.21 per head, but Victoria does not have the same distance problems that New South Wales, South Australia, Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory have. Yes, I know that out in the Mallee there are major problems. Queensland will get $53.1 million, with $29.70 per capita funding. They do have a lot of decentralised communities up the coast—I recognise that—and that poses a problem. South Australia will be getting $26.5 million. Senator Schacht, your area gets $67.60 per capita. There are non‐metropolitan areas in South Australia that are a challenge, but they are really not much more of a challenge than those areas—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are right next to it—the Flinders Ranges, the area you have just described.

—Yes, out at Camerons Corner. I am not sure where the corner store is at Camerons Corner. Two or three people live there. Actually, it is not in New South Wales. They have some pretty significant telecommunication needs, because that is now becoming quite a popular tourist area. It means that people are driving through in four‐wheel drives. They are in danger of having accidents or whatever. But, if it is actually in Queensland, they will only attract $29.70 each. If it is in South Australia, they will attract $67.60 each. It does not make sense. It is ludicrous. The words that I want to use to describe this are either unparliamentary or I can't think of them. I just find it appalling.

BREAK.PARA: Sixteen million is going to be spent in the Northern Territory. Per capita the amount will be $168.42. With the very sparse population there and the huge telecommunications needs, one has to question whether that is going to be anywhere near adequate for the provision of a telecommunications service to the out‐stations and remote communities. There are a lot there. The ACT will get $4 million when 0.4 per cent of the population lives outside Canberra itself. That is $10,000 per person. I do not begrudge the people in the Brindabellas an adequate telecommunications service because they can be cut off by snow or by floodwaters. Senator Harradine wants to have a go at me about the cost of providing a telecommunications service in Sydney. I would suggest you look at the cost of providing a telecommunications service in Canberra in the ACT. It beats Sydney hands down. You have got all the embassies, for which you have got to provide secure lines in and out. There is the hire of that technical equipment, and research and stuff.

I cannot get away from the fact that the per capita model for per capita funding in New South Wales is going to be so low. I think it bears repeating again and again that a place like Tibooburra, with a population of 1,000—it might be 1,200, but I will say 1,000 for ease of maths—will attract $15,999 because they are in New South Wales. We may as well say $16,000. If the same community of 1,000 people were outside Hobart in Tasmania it would attract $208,410. The Central Darling shire, because it is in New South Wales, attracts $64,000. If it were in Tasmania, it would attract $825,640. This is a shire that is struggling to provide a sewerage service for the residents of Wilcannia. They are having difficulty providing basic needs. Because they live in New South Wales, they will not even be able to make the most of this infrastructure program to make sure that they have at least a telecommunications service which is second to none. They are being discriminated against because they actually happen to come from New South Wales and not from one of the other more privileged states. I think that is an absolute atrocity in this day and age. The government is to be condemned for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The committee is considering the Telstra bill as a whole. The question is that the bill stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I particularly want to address my remarks in the second reading debate on the Telstra bill to matters specific to Tasmania. The Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) has made much of Tasmania's situation. The deal that is supposedly so great for Tasmania as a result of the government getting support for its legislation has been reported to varying degrees.

SPEECH.PARA: I read with interest a letter that Senator Harradine circulated earlier tonight in the chamber. It is addressed to the editor of the Australian Financial Review. In the last two paragraphs, he makes two pertinent points:

That is why I am unwilling to see the economic development of my State prejudiced by anything which could leave its people stuck on a telecommunications dirt road. That is why I am interested in universal service obligations.

I have not made up my mind on the Telstra sale legislation and I do not propose to do so until I have heard and considered all the arguments and have been satisfied that all options and all implications have been carefully examined.
I expect the Government to consider carefully anything raised in the Parliament or in public discussion, including the use of hybrid securities as a financing tool for Telstra.

They are very interesting comments. I do not necessarily disagree with any senator striving to get a better deal for their state. In fact, it is something that we all do. Whether we are in opposition or in government, we have an obligation—most of us, if not all of us, carry out that obligation—to lobby on behalf of our respective states, and always with an overriding view to the national interest and to equality throughout this country.

I would be the first to agree with Senator Harradine that Tasmania suffers. I find it very interesting that the minister has made some comments to that effect. It suffers from some rather unique problems, not the least of which is the 200‐odd kilometres of water that separates it from the mainland. As to telecommunications, I do not think we suffer any greater inconvenience or lack of service than do a lot of other regional areas throughout Australia. That is not to say that Tasmanian senators should not lobby for something better.

To me, it really raises the question of why we need to sell Telstra to get a better deal in telecommunications for Tasmania. I would have thought that, no matter what the persuasion of the government or the opposition, we all—in this place, at least—have a responsibility to ensure that communications and the application of services relating to communications are meted out equally throughout the country.

We know that that in part has not been the case. We certainly know it is a fact that in the past the now government when it was in opposition argued and pursued very strongly the issue of the treatment of rural and regional areas. It said that Telstra, and, indeed, all other public enterprises, ought to be free from government interference. Take a look at what has happened and what the minister, in his press release of 5 December, announced:
Over the past few weeks I have been working with Telstra to identify some of the implications of their current three year business plan for Tasmania and Queensland . . .
He went on to say:

Some $12 billion has been allocated by Telstra over 3 years to create a world class telecommunications infrastructure and to improve its level of customer service. This upgrade will include full digitisation of the network, expansion of GSM mobile services and improved Internet access.
That says it all as far as Telstra is concerned. Then I thought about their plans. Further, the minister said:

As part of its Australia‐wide plan to speed up network modernisation and ISDN availability, ISDN services in Tasmania will achieve a 70% customer penetration by June 1997 and 90% by December 1997, creating an additional 30 jobs.

Minister, I would be interested to know whether that was part of their three‐year plan prior to your coming to some arrangement with Senator Harradine and Senator Colston involving their support for your legislation on the partial sale. You continued to say:
In addition local call access to the Internet will be provided for all Tasmanians and Tasmania will benefit from an Internet for Schools package to be offered nationally early next year.
I come back to the national context of this whole issue. Of course we want Tasmanian schools, people and businesses to have access to the Internet. There is no doubt about that.

I say to you, Minister, that there are a lot of other telecommunications services that Tasmania would like to have fixed up. We would like to have telecommunications technology as it comes on stream, as it advances, as quickly as possible, which is not unlike all other Australians. You are one of the people who in the past had acknowledged that there has been a tendency for the major competitors in telecommunications to provide services in the most profitable areas. That is why Telstra has been able to provide the cross‐subsidies that it has provided to rural and remote areas. That is a fact of life. Further in your statement you say:
In the case of Tasmania, Telstra is planning to establish a new national call connect centre in Hobart.

Minister, when did they plan that? The impression you get from your statement is that it was part of the deal you came to with Senator Harradine and Senator Colston. If that is the case, then I think what Senator Ray said is very true. What we have here is not government in the interests of the people but government by the political power that you can come into this place with.

I would like to put something to Senator Colston and Senator Harradine. If there were two other Independent senators from other states and they were the ones who came to this arrangement with the government with regard to support for Telstra, and they were the ones who were able to attract to their states a greater portion of the benefits that might be derived from this sale, what would the view of Senators Harradine and Colston be then? I know what Senator Harradine's view would be: no different from mine; that is, you should treat the people equally. Senator Harradine has been a strong advocate of that. Senator Alston said in this place:

But significant problems remain, and I acknowledge today the particular difficulties faced by Tasmania. Not only does Tasmania suffer from all the isolation problems arising from being divided from the mainland by a large waterway, but also it has more than half its population located outside the capital city.

There is probably no other state that sits in that same position, but a huge portion of the Australian population lives outside of capital cities and I think they deserve to be treated equally, as much as I will support and push for everything that I can get for my home state. The minister went on:
It has suffered for too long from the problems of an inferior telecommunications infrastructure.

I say to Senator Alston: I remember sitting on a committee that looked at telecommunications services throughout Australia. I remember distinctly your colleagues Senator Panizza, Senator Ferguson and Senator Crane arguing very strongly. We went to King Island, and there they said, `King Island's problems are no worse than those in other areas in Western Australia, South Australia or somewhere else—maybe the Northern Territory.' They were the arguments that were presented then, so why are you taking such a different position now that you are in government? I will deal more specifically with something you said in relation to the extra $100 million to the environment package. You said:
Rising water tables, salination, erosion, degraded creeks . . . so much so, we have decided to increase the contribution to the fund—
the Natural Heritage Trust—
by another $100 million. The capital contribution from the sale to the environment will be $1.1 billion.
The minister also said:

Responding to Senator Harradine, we accept his argument. Tasmania is pre-eminent in natural heritage. One third of Tasmania has been committed to national parks or conservation reserves, a much higher proportion than anywhere else in the country. To maintain this to the standard that all Australians expect is very expensive.

That is dead right, but there are two walking tracks alone that desperately need repairs costing somewhere in the order of $11 million. If we got even 10 per cent of the $1.1 billion—I assume that is over five years—that would not be anywhere near sufficient funds.

If you look at the commitment of the government to the environment on a national level, you really have to ask yourself: where is it? There is no commitment outside of this potential $1.1 billion. There are no ongoing funds. What happens after the five-year period expires and the $1.1 billion is gone? Where is the ongoing commitment to the environment in terms of budget measures? If you cannot fit it into the budget now, how will you fit it in the budget later? The minister said further:
We can therefore assure Senator Harradine that these special issues which apply to Tasmania—
talking about Tasmania's special issues—
will be taken into account in the distribution of trust funds.
I remind Senator Alston of the Tasmanian package launched by the now Prime Minister, John Howard, on 7 February 1996. In that you said very similar words. You said:
Tasmania has a unique place in the Commonwealth.
I think we do, too—
The federal government has a special responsibility to achieve equality for Tasmanians in developing opportunities for their state.

You go on to outline a number of things that we took as promises, but they did not quite fit into the core promise category, because we did not get them. You said, `We had this black hole,' of some unknown figure that you claim to be $8 billion. The reality is that the sale of Telstra had nothing to do with the budget. You made these promises on the basis of the budget and the dollars in terms of that being there as they were.

Even with the sale of Telstra, you have not committed anything like what you promised. If we added up what you took away from Tasmania per the last budget, we would see that it is somewhere in excess of $140 million. I do not know how much you intend to give back. You said, `We need to look at some infrastructure development for Tasmania.' You are going to flog the railways and flog the airports, and you promised nearly $50 million in a ferry subsidy but we will be lucky to get $22 million. You took away $15 million from the AMC/AME. You took away $10 million from the university. You took away $3 million in the wheat subsidy and possibly $13 million in terms of our freight subsidy. And you have the audacity to come in here and speak about the difficulties that Tasmania confronts, let alone the rest of Australia.

I just say to Senator Harradine, if he is listening, that I hope he will reconsider his position because this is the greatest con of all time. There is no need to sell Telstra to get a better communications service for Tasmania. If he combines with opposition senators we ought to be able to get a better deal for the whole of Australia from one of the biggest profit making public enterprises Australia has. That is what we should be doing. We should not be flogging it off to put a few million bucks into this or that. That is not even a short-term solution; it is no solution. That is what we have to change. I hope Senator Harradine will reconsider his position. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Chair.
—They must be filibustering if you're speaking.

—I take that interjection that we must be filibustering. I remind you, Senator, that this is an important bill. I also say for the record that the Labor Party should not have that accusation made of it. I pulled my speech on the second reading and now in the committee stages I intend to refer to the appropriate parts of that speech that relate to the committee stages of that bill. I think it is important that some of these things go on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Since you have reacted to my accepting the call, perhaps I should start with the theme with which Senator Murphy concluded. This is a states house. The Senate is made up of people elected from the states. Senator Murphy was rightly raising issues as a consequence of the carriage of the second reading of this bill that affects Tasmania. Senator Murphy is a very strong advocate for his own state. There are some matters that affect my state as well. Some of those need canvassing too.

My state, Western Australia, is particularly interested in what the federal government's view now is as to how the $1.1 billion package will be disbursed for the environment. The chamber may well know there is a state election campaign going on in Western Australia at present. The incumbent Liberal government, under the leadership of Richard Court, has made several promises on the environment. The most significant promise is that he will institute a $300 million program aimed at redressing the problem of salinity—a problem that is encroaching upon the eastern wheat belt of Western Australia more and more and a problem that is attacking the basis of one of the best agriculture crops the state can export.

There is no doubt there is a problem there. There is some argument as to the best way of handling it but that argument should be set to one side in favour of getting on with the job rather than having an academic debate about which is the best way of getting on with the job. Premier Court has made this undertaking, were he to be elected next Saturday, as part of his commitment to the Western Australian community about how he intends to get on with the job.

PARA.BREAK: The key issue here is though that he has not got $300 million to pay for it. The key issue is that he believes that the Commonwealth government is going to pay for it and that it is going to come out of the proceeds of the sale of one-third of Telstra. In fact I understand that he has written a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) which specifies this specific point. He believes that the under standing he reached with the Prime Minister about funding, or shall I say in the true sense of the word pork-barrelling his election commitments in this case, means that the Commonwealth will fund that salinity remediation problem for the state of Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We do know that if it is in the $1.1 billion package, as the package has now grown to be, then other areas of the package that are promised will have to be reduced or cut out. We know that if this undertaking were to be honoured by the federal government then the cost of the package would be $1.4 billion not $1.1 billion. If it were to remain at $1.1 billion, commitments made by this government to various other states for pressing environmental problems in those states would have to be cut back.

I would like a comment from you, Senator Alston, confirming that the understanding of the Western Australian Premier Richard Court is right, that the agreement that he did reach with the Prime Minister, John Howard, confirms that out of the $1.1 billion to be set aside for environmental works $300 million is to go to the state of Western Australia to fund the election promise that the Liberal Party in that state has made. That is the first question I would like a comment from you about. I do not want a vague comment and one of ambiguity and maybes but rather one that actually answers the question.

The second question is: can you please confirm if the package then becomes $1.4 billion? But if the package remains at $1.1 billion, can you tell us then in which other areas of that package that have been publicly committed by the government are there to be amendments and changes and what other programs in that package will be reduced accordingly? I think that is an important question. I think it is a question that Australians generally want to know. It is certainly a question that Western Australians, in particular, want to know the answer to.

I think it is incumbent upon this government to dispel the argument and to put clearly and openly on the table exactly what the deal is. Otherwise what you are trying to do in the state of Western Australia is creep to electoral victory under the guise of ambiguity. What you are trying to do at the federal level is not answer the question and keep all of those who were told they are recipients believing that they are and dud them at the end of the process if the funds come out, as I suspect they will.

This is, by any measure, a bill that has gripped national attention for some time. It is an important issue. I want to say this though: when you take a public authority like Telstra and you privatise part of it you introduce into a corporation that exists to provide a service to the community a new motive and a new direction—a new motive of making a profit. When it comes to conflict, the conflict is obvious. You cannot provide a high quality service of communications in a nation like Australia with far flung cities and towns fairly and equitably within reasonable degrees of tolerance while at the same time trying to make a profit for your shareholders.

Those two concepts sit in mutual antagonism to one another. That is basically at the bottom of all of my concerns about this bill. I know that the government has pat answers for this and, to the uninitiated, those answers are convincing. To those of us who have had experience in running statutory authorities or government business organisations, they are as shallow as a puddle. They are not convincing.

For example, I cite the case of the AIDC, the Australian Industry Development Corporation. Under the former Labor government, we made a decision to partly privatise that instrumentality, which we did—up to about 18 per cent of its shareholding. As soon as you do that, you confer on the majority shareholder and on the minority shareholders exactly the same rights. On this occasion you will say, `We will cover that by putting them beyond the reach of the Corporations Act so that the standing of the minority shareholders and their entitlement to access information and their participation in the decision making as it stands under corporate law in Australia for all other organisations won't be the same in the case of Telstra.' That then sounds a warning bell to those who may invest that, if they do, their rights are different.

BREAK.PARA: I suggest that in the practical world their rights will not be different, nor could the government reasonably expect them to be different. When minority shareholders insist, as we found in the case of the AIDC, the government can be refused by the corporation overall not to be told relevant information. If you want then to conduct a due diligence study to realise your ultimate dream of selling the whole lot, unless the minority shareholders approved of that, you would not be able to carry it out.

So in the case of the AIDC, because we had partly privatised it—which is almost an oxymoron; it is a bit like being partly pregnant—what the Commonwealth had to do was buy back the private shareholding in order to take control of the whole organisation. It had to become the single shareholder, then have access to a due diligence study and then consider the whole of the authority for sale. This will be a similar situation that will occur.

It arises because under corporate law, quite rightly, after the corporate crooks of the eighties ran riot in this country, a revision of corporate law was needed to prevent the Bonds, the Skases and et al doing what they did then. So we encoded the rights of shareholders quite explicitly. Those rights stand as fundamental rights. As soon as you introduce a minority shareholding here, shareholders who are entitled to a return on their capital investment—that is, to make a profit—will assert their rights. Whatever flimsy barriers or Chinese walls or paper partitions you put between them and their rights, they will find a way around it, over it, under it or through it.

I do not think the explanation that the government has given the Australian community about that is at all satisfactory, nor do I believe that it stands up to scrutiny. If it is to be the case that there is to be a part sale, much more work needs to be done to ensure that the commitments that the government has made can be delivered on.

Let me turn to another matter which is central to my concern, dear to the hearts of many Australians and fundamental to future prospects for employment. The fastest growing industry in the world and now the biggest industry in the world after the motor car industry is the information technology and telecommunications sector. It is the fastest growing. It is one set to grow at a much more rapid pace with convergence. When we talk about the superhighway, about electronic shopping and all the rest of it, we are talking about the sort of thing that Bill Gates is on about in the future: the convergence of various technologies to create a virtual world.

Telecommunications is central to that. If Australia does not manufacture its own inputs into that new technology, it will import foreign made goods to provide those technologies to the Australian system. The telecommunications industry that we have in Australia is by world standards a small industry but which, despite its size, is also a refreshingly imaginative and innovative industry; a strong industry and an industry which from time to time has given Telecom—in its former guise before it became Telstra—a market edge.

We do things differently here and often we do them better, although you would go a long way frequently to find Australians ready to admit it. But that is the truth of it. Under the privatising proposal, the same monitoring and the same encouragement will be given by the government for Telstra, as indeed it will be for Optus, to continue to source in Australia. But, once again, what has occurred is that you have fundamentally changed the direction of the enterprise. You have made it into a profit maker as well as a service provider. Those two things are mutually contradictory.

By loading the new enterprise with community service obligations, as you are bound to do, in order to answer the profit making part of the equation as well, Telstra will be forced more and more not to invest in Australian industry, not to develop the technology onshore, not to encourage the many fine examples of Australian communications companies and companies that are to do with the new virtual world—that is, to contribute new technology, new inventions, new ideas, new ways of doing things to the frontiers that are emerging in communications and information science—and will be forced offshore to source from the majors overseas.

Once you do that, you take intelligent jobs out of Australia. You take jobs off people who are highly skilled, highly trained professionals. You also take out of Australia the ability to produce our own needs in telecommunications equipment, and you provide those jobs to foreigners, to other economies and to other companies offshore.

Telstra is such a big corporation that it requires positive encouragement to make sure that those jobs are kept here. In the present environment of changing from being a service provider to a service provider/profit taker—no matter what I think about the contradiction in those terms—more than monitoring is required and more than encouragement is required. Positive commitments are required from the government to all of those small‐ and medium‐sized Australian telecommunications companies with their thousands of employees and the major regional and rural centres of Australia where they develop their operations, employ people and are central to the local economies. A real message needs to be given to them that Telstra, as a first priority, will be directed to source its equipment and supplies from Australian companies.

If that means a slightly higher charge in order to get the economy of scale in those companies to produce, through a long run of production, goods at the end of the process more cheaply, so be it. We can then start selling overseas. We ought to become an exporter of this technology. We are so damn good at it, we can export it and make a quid for this nation and provide better jobs for Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —What came out of the public inquiry that we all spent months working on? Many things came out of that inquiry. Despite grand efforts by the government representatives on the Senate committee inquiring into the partial sale of Telstra, some very useful information came forward. Some of that useful information related specifically to jobs and what Telstra had in mind for jobs in the context of impending—or what they hoped was impending—partial privatisation. Now they have got it or have just about got it.

BREAK.PARA: We heard during that inquiry and during the second reading debate that jobs will go. Those jobs will now go. The reality now is that 22,000 jobs—200 of them here in the ACT, but many of them from regional Australia—are now at risk. Despite any of the cosy deals that have been done in this place to secure the passage of this bill, with a few jobs here and there perhaps being saved, it means that the general path down which Telstra now will go is one of downsizing, rationalisation, squeezing the last possible cent out of their profit margin and increasing their dollar bottom line. That will become the prime motivation for this company.

It is a sad time for not only the people who will lose their jobs but also the people in Australia who have relied heavily on the services which have been provided by Telstra. First of all, I will dwell on Telstra as a mechanism for government to institute sound social policy, whether it be with respect to access to and equity of telecommunication services or whether it be to the standard universal service obligation that takes as basic a simple phone to families right across the nation.

It did not take someone like Bill Clinton to come here and raise the importance of telecommunications to Labor. I think we have always known of their importance, and our views were vindicated by the outcome of the public inquiry report which stated quite clearly, based on evidence from the witnesses, that the majority of Australians were not comfortable with the sale of Telstra. Also, we did not find the substantive evidence, whether on an economic basis or a service provision basis, to justify its partial sale.

My colleague Senator Cook touched upon research and development in the telecommunications sector. Australia really is at the forefront of development of this technology for the whole Pacific region. I believe that it is quite important for Australia to develop its technological base—and not only in industry. If you look at some of the studies that have been carried out, it is quite clear that if you have a high standard of technological uptake within the community, that trend reflects the ability of that economy or society to be to the fore in developing industry and technologies.

What I am saying to you, Minister, is that there is a direct link between the uptake of those technologies within the community and a country's ability to be able to establish itself as a leader in the export and the industry development of those particular technologies. Unless those bases are covered now, we will lose what I believe is quite a strong position in this area. Also, unless those bases are covered in a way that will foster future growth, it will be an opportunity lost—and it is too important an opportunity for our economic future to allow it to go by.

Minister, with respect to that opportunity, despite many of your quasi policy statements of recent times, I do not believe that this government is doing enough to ensure that all Australians have access to that high level of technology. By partially privatising Telstra, you are giving away the opportunity to further enhance the ability of the community to take up new technologies.

Whilst I have been listening very carefully to your numerous statements and to your responses to questions during question time from your own people about what you are doing as a government in this regard—whether it is Internet access for rural people, expanding the band width generally, or whatever—all I see is a Telstra business plan being rehashed and reworked into government policy. I do not think that is good enough. It is not good enough because Telstra will be motivated not by what they can bring the Australian society; they will be motivated by the fact that they need to provide a greater return for their investors.

Minister, I can hear you asking, `Well, isn't that a good thing?' I do not believe it is a good thing. Unless there is some gain or some benefit to the Australian community per se and unless there is a mechanism for governments to be able to influence the direction of our dominant telecommunications carrier, those opportunities will be lost forever. As a policy tool, whether it is partial privatisation or full privatisation does not make a scrap of difference. You only need look at some of the areas of the bill, particularly 8AX and 8AY which show the fiduciary responsibilities of directors, to see that it makes no difference whether it is partially or fully privatised.

Minister, I would like to know whether it is true that a partially privatised Telstra, by virtue of clauses 8AX and 8AY of the bill, renders the responsibilities of the directors to being no different from that which would apply to a fully privatised Telstra and what distinction, if any, exists by virtue of the fact that it is only a partially privatised Telstra as opposed to a fully privatised Telstra. These questions are quite important.

In the past certainly, one example comes to mind in relation to the responsibilities of directors of a former publicly owned asset becoming a privately owned asset and the role of Commonwealth government representatives on the boards of partially or otherwise privatised corporations in guiding, directing and steering some of the policy issues that might be close to the government's heart. Minister, I put those issues to you. Hopefully I will get a response as to what distinction there is or in fact, as I suspect, whether there is no distinction whatsoever between the responsibilities and roles of the directors of a partially or fully privatised formerly publicly owned corporation.

Another aspect of the report that I would like to touch on in the context of this committee debate is the services through telecommunications that are provided to people. One thing that becomes painfully clear, and which became very clear through the inquiry process, is that at the moment there is a lot to be desired with respect to services and there is real concern in this current context that those services will be further downgraded. It is not that in some areas the services are not terrific. With all due respect, the FMO project and some of the strategies that have already been outlined by Telstra in improving ISDN access, Internet access, data access, high speed data transmissions and so forth are all well and good; but they will be applied in a way that gets the greatest return.

My concern through all this process is that it will not just be this path of deregulation that this government has embarked upon in the hope that competition and privatisation will deliver the outcomes of equity across the level of service provided to users of these telecommunications carriers. It will be driven by where the greatest returns are. The only way the government will be able to ensure equity and access to the higher grade services will be by re‐regulating—and re‐regulating in a way that tightens up the consumer service guarantee and redefines the universal service obligation to pick up the new areas and regulate to a greater degree.

We have seen it already in this bill, with the restatement of the consumer service guarantees. That is the clearest indication that all of those things are at risk. It is quite paradoxical that this government on the one hand talks about deregulation and competition coming to the fore in providing these services, but on the other hand finds it very necessary to restate, or redraft or introduce new regulations to achieve that equity of service.

Again, let us look at the US. Some recent statements by the just re-elected President, particularly during his campaign, made it quite clear that they were the directions precisely in which they were moving in the US. They have been down the path of massive deregulation, obviously with privatisation of the national communications carriers. You have seen a fracturing of those services. Now the US government, because of the inequities in provisions of services, is having to step back into the picture and re‐regulate to make sure those services are accessible to all Americans.

We can learn from this. This government should not trip down the merry path of where the US has been and get to a point down the track where it finds out that we have telecommunications haves and have-nots and information technology haves and have-nots. The government should put in place a structure that can deal with that now. My argument is that privatisation—partial or otherwise—is not conducive to achieving that equity of access, particularly to the faster services, the higher grade bandwidth and so forth that are required to have effective information technology services within the home.

The other area I want to touch on relates to where Telstra is going. In the first instance, the role Telstra played in this campaign to get itself privatised is quite concerning. It is worth stating quite unequivocally that it was unusual in the least that Telstra almost led the debate. If you heard the submissions put before the inquiry, you would know that the Department of Finance and the department of telecommunications were floundering around with dubious arguments with respect to World Bank studies which were certainly not comparable to the situation in Australia. Telstra were the ones that obviously put in the resources and prepared the arguments for their privatisation.

Who are the beneficiaries of privatisation? One document that we got during the inquiry shows that certainly the chief executives of corporations are major beneficiaries. Certainly the workers on the ground aren't, because most of them, or a fair proportion of them, will lose their jobs.

You can see through that whole inquiry process that Telstra, playing the role it did, is moving in a direction that squeezes the research dollar, the long-term investment dollar and the dollar that is not going to provide a great return to the company within the immediate future. It is moving to investments in projects that turn a quick dollar. That is a very short-term vision by this telecommunications carrier, which has a reputation of being very far-sighted. It has positioned itself to reap the benefits in five years or 10 years time. The investment that occurred with optic fibre technology has now positioned Australia at the very forefront of the development of that technology globally.

Why is the government prepared to give away what little policy control or involvement they have in steering Telstra in a direction that at least provides some benefit to the community? I think this point has been lost in this debate, whether it is in the context of what we have heard about the environment or what we have heard about what the government is going to spend the money on. It is a shame that in this whole argument the value of Telstra in private hands has almost become a non-issue. What is more important is how many dollars the government are going to squeeze out of it and pump into this bit or that bit of the environment.

Let us not forget that this was a bad strategy to start with. It is one of the most cynical, political ploys that has ever been invented. The saddest irony of all is that the people it was targeted at, the Greens, who had the balance of power at the time, were rendered impotent in this argument, and this government got away with this strategy with the help of two Independents. That is the saddest irony of all, and it is quite a telling moment in relation to this government's approach not only to policy but to public assets that have the ability to deliver a sound social access and equity strategy on telecommunications. That has been given away in this process, and the credibility of this government has gone with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I want to deal with part 2C of the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill. Clause 8CN, headed `Re‐affirmation of universal service obligation', reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Parliament re‐affirms its intention:
(a) that all people in Australia, wherever they reside or carry on business, will continue to have reasonable access, on an equitable basis, to standard telephone services and payphones; and
(b) that the universal service obligation described in section 288 of the Telecommunications Act 1991 should be fulfilled as efficiently and economically as practicable; and

(c) that the losses that result from supplying loss‐making services in the course of fulfilling the universal service obligation should be shared among carriers on an equitable basis, namely, in direct proportion to each carrier's share of the interconnect time between those carriers' trunk and international networks and all local access networks; and

(d) that the information on the basis of which, and the methods by which, those losses and those carriers' respective shares in those losses are determined should be open to scrutiny by those carriers, and by the public, to the greatest extent possible without undue damage to a carrier's interests being caused by the disclosure of confidential commercial information.

That passage in the legislation was referred to by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) on 10 October in an answer to a question which I think has been noted in earlier debate in this chamber. It is the two per cent answer, where the minister said that the reduction in employment by Telstra in Tasmania would be two per cent. Subsequently, some 42 days later, he had to correct the answer.

Somewhat cheaply the minister suggested that Senator Schacht was going to move an amendment to this clause, implying that the opposition was somehow opposed to the universal service obligation. Of course, that is nonsense. In relation to that, the minister said on page 3819 of the proof Hansard of 10 October:

Anyone who has read the Telecommunications Act—I suspect that not too many have—would know that there is already a provision entrenched in that legislation which guarantees that, to the extent that services in rural and remote areas are uneconomic, they must be cross‐subsidised out of a universal service fund contributed to by all the carriers on a pro rata basis.

That will continue unless, of course, the Labor Party is proposing to move an amendment to open the system up. I am not aware of that. Maybe Senator Schacht has it up his sleeve for later on. But I would not support it . . .

Of course, Minister, the Labor Party does not support it, and that is inconsistent with the position that is put. The element of the debate that the minister referred to is further referred to on page 3827 of the same proof Hansard . In answer to a question by Senator Panizza, the minister said in referring to broadband services:
There is more good news because, from July 1997, 93.4 per cent of customers will be able to—
he is talking about Tasmania—

obtain an ISDN service within 90 days of request. That will mean that both business and domestic users will be able to dial up fast digital connections as easily as making a phone call. Those sorts of new services will include multiple phones and faxes on the same line; much faster access to fax machines; fast EFTPOS links; fast access to the Internet for educational, cultural and information services; small‐screen video conferencing; shared screens; and virtual production groups, so that people in different locations can collaborate and produce high fidelity sound and fast text and graphics.
All of these will be available only because of the actions that the government has taken.

I will repeat the minister's words: `only because of the actions that the government has taken'. Isn't that the very point that the opposition has been making in this debate about the expansion of services beyond the very basic universal service obligations that the legislation lays down? This bill does not give any guarantees beyond the provision of standard telephone services and payphones. The minister has made the point on the record that expansion beyond those services in the state of Tasmania, particularly for ISDN services, which, I must say, most households would never access—the minister shakes his head, so I look forward to a response to that—
Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, ISDN is not required for Internet connection, Minister.
—If you want fast speed access, it is.

—As the minister says—and I am happy to engage the minister in debate now—perhaps some will require that service. I will go on because the Labor Party has been strenuous in its opposition to this bill and, from the state of Tasmania, Labor senators have been strenuous in their opposition to this bill because there were no guarantees beyond the basic services. The only guarantee that the rural and remote areas have is the fact that the government owns the major provider and is currently able to direct.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to what might happen to these services without direction, in the earlier answer the minister said, talking about broadband services, on page 3820 of the same proof Hansard:

It is basically the suggestion that Tasmanians will lose access to broadband systems. The fact is that there are already a number of regional carriers that are providing these sorts of services—Paynet Telecommunications in Cairns, Northgate Communications in Ballarat. Austar is very keen to cable up rural areas and Optus has indicated an interest that will extend to Tasmania. I have no doubt that if Tasmanians are interested in the service Telstra will be looking at it as well.

Naturally, of course, the minister made no guarantees and it is very interesting, in the context of what we have learned since this time, that the government is putting forward $250 million on a curious basis to deal with concerns about the provision of these sorts of services. If that is not an admission of the deficiency of the bill, then I do not know what is. There is nothing in the bill that deals with the issue of the extension of services beyond those basic standard telephone and payphone services. There are no assurances and no guarantees.

When you look across Australia—and the Senate inquiry looked at this very issue—you look at the question of existing cross‐subsidisation of regional areas. I had a look at appendix 8 in the report and that indicated the federal electorates within each state which attracted no cross‐subsidy. The situation was that in Tasmania every electorate—obviously some more than others—attracted a cross‐subsidy. In the minister's own state of Victoria, 21 of the 38 electorates attracted no cross‐subsidy; in New South Wales, 24 of 50; in Queensland, I think only seven electorates required no cross‐subsidy; in South Australia, eight electorates required no cross‐subsidy; in Western Australia, six; in the Australian Capital Territory, two out of the three; and, of course, the Northern Territory, the only electorate, required cross‐subsidy.

So, in the context of the present parliament, a majority of the seats require a cross‐subsidy, which is probably similar to the coalition's current numerical strength in the House of Representatives. If they require a cross‐subsidy in relation to standard telephone and payphone services, as is provided for in the bill, what is the case going to be in relation to services that are not dealt with by the legislation? What do we have to deal with that? We have $250 million over five years allocated in a way which is advantageous to my state, but extremely disadvantageous to the more populous states.

One might say that it is strange for a senator from Tasmania to make this point, but I really do not believe that any state wants to be seen to be garnering favour in the way that my state will appear, to many people in this country, to have garnered favour in this debate. In any case, I do not believe that $58 million over five years or $11.8 million per year is, in any way, going to address the needs of the state in relation to the provision of the services required.

Does anyone seriously think that the extension of the broadband cabling services to all the people in Tasmania can be achieved with $11.8 million per year? Bear in mind that the most profitable routes for this sort of service will be in the areas of the country where there is no cross‐subsidisation required. The majority of Australia is in a situation where a cross‐subsidy is required. And how unfair is this package in these circumstances?

So 8CM of the bill is deficient and maybe, Minister, we ought to be moving an amendment. Maybe we ought to enshrine in that provision in the bill something more than the basic cross‐subsidisation of telephone and payphone services. Maybe it would be more equitable to put the whole box and dice in there and to talk about a cross‐subsidisation of that nature.

There will definitely be a disadvantage to all parts of Australia, including Tasmania, arising out of this bill, just as we have been saying all along. To the extent that the deal that is being done ameliorates the position for Tasmania, one would have to say that Tasmania is very fortunate. To the extent that it deals with the real need, we would have to say that this package of measures is inadequate.

If the minister is suggesting that we should throw in the extra $100 million for the environment, I thought that this government was committed to the environment. I thought that that is what this package was about and there was a case to be made, as Senator Harradine said, for an additional payment to the state of Tasmania, bearing in mind the sacrifices that the state has made in relation to setting aside important parts of the wilderness areas of the state for preservation and the restriction of the logging industry and the mining industry. Those are the issues which I understood would be compensated for in regard to this measure. So I exclude those. I would be interested to hear from the minister whether he thinks I am unfair in not counting that $100 million.

All in all, we have a pretty shabby and inadequate package. I am pleased that the minister is here because I will be very interested to hear his comments. I suppose I could very cheaply say that perhaps he should be very careful this time because the last time he responded to one of my speeches, he did not quite get it right. Minister, I do look forward very seriously to your comments on these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is common ground in this debate that it is vital to Australia's economic future that we have an efficient telecommunications sector. Telecommunications is Australia's second biggest business input, so by lowering costs, we make our businesses more competitive. However, it is also common ground that cost is not the only factor. By providing a quality telecommunications sector which takes full advantage of, and even promotes, innovations, we can make our businesses more productive.

SPEECH.PARA: Telecommunications is the fastest growing sector in our economy, with revenue increasing from $9.5 billion in 1989-90 to $20.3 billion in 1994-95. The sector grew by 17 per cent in real terms in 1994-95. The telecommunications industry has undergone rapid growth in employment and size since micro-economic reform started back in the early 1980s. The market has grown so fast, in fact, that Telstra's business has actually grown, despite Optus gaining a sizeable slice of the market, with revenues of almost $1.5 billion. This growth is due to lower prices, new products, value adding, better service and increased marketing—all results of competition. It is evidence that the introduction of competition stimulates growth.

Also, a Bureau of Industry Economics study has shown that since competition was introduced to the international call and mobile telephone markets, they have risen rapidly and they are currently just below world's best standard. However, another study from the Bureau of Industry Economics showed no association between performance and the type of ownership of the main enterprises in the market. The world's lowest telecommunications prices were in Iceland, which has a state monopoly, and the highest revenue per line and per employee was in Switzerland, which also has a state monopoly.

There was evidence to indicate that corporatisation and the introduction of a competitive environment provides efficiency and cost benefits of the same level as privatisation of a state‐owned telecommunications carrier. It is therefore wrong to say that simply because an enterprise is privately owned, it is going to be more efficient and deliver cheaper prices.

It is also important to look at Telstra from an industry policy perspective. The Australian electronics industry is one of our growth industries, particularly important when one considers the global growth of telecommunications. The electronics industry has gone from $50 million worth of sales 10 years ago to over $1 billion now. By the end of the century it is estimated that the industry to be worth $1.5 billion. That sort of growth simply will not occur with a privatised Telstra. Telstra is vitally important to the Australian electronics industry because it invests more in research and development than any other company in Australia. When Telecom New Zealand was privatised, the electronics industry practically vanished overnight.

Telstra purchases over 70 per cent of its equipment, materials and services from Australian companies. This is a deliberate policy set by the government and is of major assistance to the development of our own indigenous electronics industry. It also has the added benefit of allowing the government to assist this industry without having to provide any direct funding. The result of this assistance is that a number of companies have been established in the electronics sector. With high growth, exports and value adding, this is a strategic part of our economy. The government could not tell a partially privatised Telstra where it could purchase its products, nor should it.

PARA.BREAK: The Community and Public Sector Union conducted a study of the effects of privatisation on state‐owned overseas telecommunica tions carriers and found that a vast majority of them made significant cuts to their research facilities. Telstra has already shown that it is heading down this path, with 44 per cent of employees at the Telstra Research Laboratories to be made redundant in preparation for part-privatisation. This will obviously have a major impact on innovation in Australia. Telstra Research Laboratories, or TRL, is a world-class research facility. To quote from the Australian Financial Review:

SPEECH.PARA: It has fostered intellectual vigour and know-how in telecommunications, helped spawn generations of outstanding engineers and allowed for cross-fertilisation of ideas.

TRL have a strong record of research and development success. Last financial year alone they developed a video‐on‐demand system for the Internet, `watermarks' for video images to ensure their security, and a new device which enables higher bandwidths in optical fibre. They have also developed a number of products which are either about to enter the marketplace or have already found export markets. These include: mobile network performance monitoring software, which Telstra is negotiating to license to Ericsson; radiation hazard software, which has been licensed to Motorola; electronic directory software, which was chosen by IBM from an international field for its Eurescom X500 international directory assistance trials; a distributed traffic monitoring system that has already been sold to Thailand; and an optical fibre fault‐finding technology that is expected to return up to $2 million in exports this financial year alone. A number of international companies have expressed interest in this product, including AT&T, Sprint, MM Cables and Alcatel.

Last month the Economist Intelligence Unit released a report which said that the major factor preventing foreign investment was the lack of a consistent industry policy. A good example of an effective strategic industry policy is the US government's fostering of the telecommunications and information technology industries. This policy directly benefited companies such as AT&T's Bell Laboratories. Over their history Bell Labs has invested the first transistor, solar cell, laser, light-emitting diode, communications satellite, electrical digital computer, cellular mobile radio and artificial larynx. It made the world's first long-distance television transmission, brought sound to motion pictures and invented stereo recording and digital switching.

Since Bell Labs was founded, it has received over 26,000 patents, an average of one per day since it was established. Seven researchers from Bell Labs have received Nobel prizes and five are recipients of the USA's National Medal of Science. This outstanding research and development record would have been severely limited without a decent industry policy.

If Telstra is sold—which, as I have already outlined, is likely to lead to significant cuts in research and development—what innovations and inventions will Australia not develop? Since innovation is a major contributor to productivity growth, what effect will this have on Australia's standard of living in the long term?

A post‐budget study by Deloittes found that 34 per cent of companies were considering taking their research and development offshore as a direct result of the R&D tax incentive reduction. With no industry policy and with the part‐privatisation of Telstra, one has to ask if there will be any research left in this country.

At the global level, as put forward by a number of speakers already, the large telecommunications carriers are undertaking mergers and acquisitions and are entering into strategic alliances to strengthen their competitive position. This is resulting in a small number of very large mega‐alliances. The foreign telecommunications companies are competitors to local firms. These foreign companies will want to supply Telstra from within their own companies or alliances, not from independent Australian companies. These alliances are also active in telecommunications overseas, making their competitors Telstra and other Australian companies. This would result in these companies attempting to make Telstra and its Australian suppliers reduce their exports.

Studies cited by US Secretary for Labour, Robert Reich, indicate that, when foreign companies take a controlling interest in an overseas firm, the strategic parts of that firm are moved to the home country of the foreign company. Telstra has entered into research alliances with overseas companies. This was fine for a public enterprise which had an interest in ensuring core research stays in Australia. But, if Telstra is privatised and Reich is correct, the core elements of this allied research will be done overseas. We can prevent this from happening whilst Telstra is in public hands, but, unfortunately, there is nothing we can do to stop a privatised Telstra shifting core research overseas.

If one-third of Telstra were sold, it would represent around three per cent of the total market capitalisation on the Australian Stock Exchange. Due to the size of the Telstra float in relation to that of the Australian capital market, the government has no choice but to allow overseas investors to acquire a key stake. If the investment in Optus, other privatised carriers around the world and German Telecom within the last two weeks is an indication, plus the recent tendency towards mergers and acquisitions in a global telecommunications market, these foreign investors will primarily be telecommunications companies.

The coalition accuse us of only arguing against the sale of Telstra because we are in opposition and point to the privatisation which occurred under Labor as evidence. There are two fundamental differences between the privatisation of Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, and the proposed part‐privatisation of Telstra. The first one is the share of the market. The Commonwealth Bank services around 20 per cent of the Australian banking sector. Qantas has about 50 per cent of the domestic air travel market and under 40 per cent of the international air travel market. Both are in sectors where there are strong competitors, ensuring market forces prevent anti-competitive practices. Telstra controls almost 90 per cent of Australia's telecommunication services with no strong competitors.

The second difference is the provision of capital. The Commonwealth Bank and Qantas used governments funds to expand their businesses. I agree that it is more beneficial for the government to pass this risk and expense to private investors. However, Telstra raises its own investment capital.

Although Optus is making a substantial investment in building a subscriber network through its broadband roll-out, it still uses the Telstra network for the majority of its local calls and extensively for long distance calls. This puts Telstra in too powerful a position for it to be privatised. In telecommunications, overseas experience has taught us that competition is determined almost exclusively by access to the main carrier.

Telstra has a far stronger asset backing than other telecommunications carriers. This will allow privatised Telstra, which is—rightly for a private company—concerned more about profits than industry development, to lower prices and start a price war. Due to its size, it could sustain losses longer than its competitors, forcing them out of the market. This would then leave Telstra with an absolute monopoly.

The government often uses world's best practice indicators to show how poorly Telstra performs and how overstaffed it is. For example, in terms of lines per employee, Telstra ranks 26th out of 30 countries, almost 25 per cent below the average and around 50 per cent below world's best practice. This is the most common measure of efficiency, but it does not take into account the CSOs of Telstra and our unique geographical situation in Australia.

We have a very large and sparsely populated country with long distances between major population centres. This means it takes more employees to look after phone lines than a telephone company which deals only with the highly profitable sectors, does not have to concern itself with servicing pay phones or answering free directory assistance calls, and covers a large population in a small and defined geographic area.

One suspects the current valuation of Telstra is far too low. It would see our most profitable public asset sold for a price far below its real worth. If one assumes Telstra's cash flow will be in line with current GDP growth—around 3½ per cent per annum—until 2001 and steady thereafter and then applies a discount rate of six per cent, Telstra's value would be around $37 billion. These assumptions are highly conservative.

Since competition was introduced to the telecommunications market, Telstra has managed to increase both its profit and market size. Every major economic forecaster is in agreement that telecommunications will grow rapidly over the next decade. Therefore, the assumption of cash flow growth at 3½ per cent for five years and steady after that is highly conservative.

At the same time, the US inflation rate is expected to be two per cent per annum over the next decade, making bond rates six per cent per annum and interest rates four per cent per annum. This again makes a six per cent discount rate a most conservative estimate. Even this conservative valuation figure of $37 billion is still almost 50 per cent more than the government's valuation of Telstra.

Arising out of those points on research and development, industry policy and valuation of Telstra, I have seven questions to direct to the minister. I will seek a response in due course. Firstly, what guarantees are there that the core strategic research that Telstra undertakes will be retained in Australia?
