Secondly, what will the government do with any surplus of up to $4 billion or $5 billion that arises from the one-third float? Thirdly, will that surplus be used to retire debt or will it be allocated to recurrent expenditure? If so, in what areas?

Fourthly, what long-term programs and policies will be put in place to assist mendicant states like Tasmania? Fifthly, will the government offer similar subsidies to regional Western Australians as in Tasmania? If not, why not? Sixthly, will the government offer identical job guarantees to Western Australian Telstra workers as in Tasmania? If not, why not? Finally, will the government offer $300 million to assist the proposals of the Western Australian government to recover land degraded by salinity? If not, why not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments this evening and ask some similar questions of the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. Since the announcement of the deal that was made between the government and Senator Harradine and Senator Colston, my phone in Queensland has certainly been running hot with people asking precisely the same kinds of questions that Senator Bishop was asking about Western Australia. When we come into this place, we assume that there is an equity about the way in which decisions will be made. We come in specifically to represent our states, but we do so in the interests of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: My concerns relate specifically to jobs and to the universal service obligations, particularly as they impact on my state of Queensland. Queensland, as I am sure honourable senators know, is one of the most decentralised states. We have a very large population living outside the capital city. Yet, apart from some mention of a few extra jobs in Toowoomba, I have not heard the minister speak about any aspect of the deal that has been done with Senator Colston, who is a Queensland senator, to recognise the special needs of Queensland and to guarantee rural services and to ensure jobs in all those decentralised towns and cities right up the coast and in inland centres.

I am particularly concerned about jobs for women in Queensland. The minister is shaking his head. I know we get a lot of paper in this place, Senator, but I have not seen any guarantees of the kind that were offered to Senator Harradine and Senator Colston about the jobs of women in Telstra. Queensland women working in Telstra in regional centres from Cairns to the Gold Coast and inland fear that they will suffer disproportionately.

We are aware that there have been ongoing rumours. Maybe they are only rumours, but that does not assure the women who are relying on Telstra for their jobs when there are documents that reveal that a partially privatised company hopes to export many of its jobs to the Philippines. A partly privatised Telstra wants to establish operator assistance services in places like the Philippines. Philippine workers, who would be on substandard wages and conditions, who could speak acceptable English would replace women in regional Australia. If that is still nothing more than a worrying rumour, would the minister please categorically, in writing, give the same kinds of assurances to women workers in Telstra that he has been quite happy to give to Senators Colston and Harradine?

Similarly, I note and I am surprised that Senator Alston is able to be with us tonight, because I understand that he had to meet with his own backbench communications committee to seek guarantees about the universal service obligations on the Telstra sale legislation. I understand that Mr Bob Katter, a Queensland colleague, is understood to be concerned that the USOs—cross‐subsidies to ensure continued services in rural and regional areas—are not watertight. The deal with Senator Harradine and the deal with Senator Colston appears to be absolutely watertight. Minister, are the deals in relation to the universal service obligations absolutely watertight? Have you been able to assure that backbench committee or have you perhaps not been able to meet with them yet? An article from the Financial Review written by Lenore Taylor reports:

National and Liberal Party backbenchers from rural areas plan to raise questions this week about the State breakdown of the Government's $250 million regional telecommunications infrastructure fund and about the effectiveness of universal service obligations in the Telstra sale legislation.
What we find when we do some analysis of the deal that was done last week is that the deal actually does this:

This gives independent Senator Brian Harradine's State, Tasmania, where around 59 per cent of the population live outside Hobart, more than 20 per cent of the money, despite the fact that Tasmania's non-capital city population represents only about 4 per cent of the non-capital city population of Australia as a whole.

Minister, are you happy? Can you go to sleep at night knowing that you have disproportionately favoured one state merely because you were so determined to get your legislation through in the form that the government has chosen? I find it totally unacceptable.

All senators would be very happy to go to individual ministers and do deals on behalf of their regions. I am sure Senator Gibbs would be very happy to do some deals in relation to jobs in Ipswich. I am sure Senator Schacht would be happy to do deals on jobs in South Australia. We on this side of the chamber do not have the luxury of being able to persuade you, Senator Alston, that we can have this kind of disproportionate funding, which is just as necessary in North Queensland, Central Queensland, southern Queensland or any other part of Australia.

Of course, my first loyalty lies with Queensland. As a senator, I see the important thing about policy making in this country is that all areas of Australia are treated equitably: when it comes to jobs, all Telstra employees should have equal access to the retention of their jobs and, when it comes to service delivery, all Australians should have equal access to a sound communications system.

Continuing with these concerns that have been raised within your own ranks, I am advised that, based on the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics population figures, the allocation to New South Wales of $37.4 million represents about $16 per rural residence—$16, Minister—and that Victoria's $28.5 million equates to around $22 per person living outside Melbourne. This compares with Tasmania's allocation, which represents more than $200 per non‐Hobart resident. This is not acceptable. It is not fair. I think that you should be re‐examining the terms under which you have been able to attract the votes of the two Independent senators. In the ACT, where $4 million is to benefit the estimated 400 people who live outside Canberra, the per head allocation is around $10,200. This is policy making on the run. There is no consistency in the manner in which the minister has guaranteed to give certain assurances to people in rural and regional Australia, because it is on an ad hoc basis. It depends purely on the necessity to do deals in order to get the legislation through.

So, Minister, I am extremely unhappy with your public comments to date. I can assure you that, throughout regional Queensland, people are asking why it is that the minister has chosen to offer a few jobs in Toowoomba. That is fine for Toowoomba, but what about the jobs in other parts of the state? I am sure that I am not the only person who is concerned from a Queensland perspective. I know that other honourable senators are very disturbed about the impact of your decision making processes on jobs and the guarantee of services for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak again because I did not finish what I was saying last time. I ran out of time. There was a lot more to say on this notion of mandate. I heard Senator Alston say from his seat that my interpretation of mandate is unique in the world. And yet I have been able to put on the table the only measurements that have been taken in this country, in an election campaign, of an issue which was an important election campaign issue. All of them show that around 60 per cent of Australians do not like the sale of Telstra, do not like the way it was linked with the environment, and believe the Senate has a right to block it if it wishes.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not regard that as some `unique in the world' interpretation. But let me add to it. I have heard so many members of the government claim that the Lindsay by‐election gave them another definitive measurement. I refer to the Bulletin poll of 5 November 1996. Again, the voters were asked exactly the question that we wanted to know the answer to. They were asked whether the Lindsay victory gave the government a mandate to sell part of Telstra.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right—the right, it said.
—They were asked—
—They were asked if we had the right, and they agreed we had the right.

—They were asked whether it gave the government a mandate to sell part of Telstra. In response to that, 33 per cent of respondents agreed and 54 per cent did not. They were asked specifically. Having denied the reality of what the voters said when their views were measured all the way during the election campaign, we then had the assertion, `Well, here's the definitive test.' They were asked specifically whether this gave the coalition the right—on the back of this Lindsay by‐election victory—to sell Telstra and whether this meant they were endorsing its right to sell Telstra. Fifty‐four per cent said no and only 33 per cent agreed.

BREAK.PARA: I love the way you twist this notion of mandate. I love the way you think that because you can assert and assert and assert what you think Lindsay meant, you are right. But here is another measurement: it is exactly the same as all those polls which measured the Telstra issue and its connection with the environment fund all the way through the election campaign. That does not happen very often. I do not think you can just dismiss out of hand what we read into how people voted on 2 March.

The other thing I would add is that three per cent of people who voted Liberal in the House of Representatives on 2 March also voted Democrat in the upper house—a huge number of those specifically because of views on Telstra. When you look at the balance between election to the House of Representatives and to the Senate, you will see that 56 per cent of those who were elected in the Senate had a public anti‐privatisation of Telstra position. Australians knew what they were doing. They wanted a change of government—there was no doubt about that. But they were not saying to this coalition government, `And you can do everything you want to do.' They were specially saying, `You can have government, but you're not going to sell Telstra.'

I was really interested in Senator Harradine's interjection when I asked him what his interpretation of mandate was. His explanation was that they went to the people on the issue of Telstra; therefore they have a mandate. I said to him, `They went to the people on the issue of industrial relations, too. But for some reason, Senator Harradine, you did not interpret that as mandate.' He interjected, `It was a matter of principle.' He might say that about the migrant waiting periods, too—a different principle but a matter of principle. For some reason, the issue of principle does not loom large with respect to Telstra and its future.

I might remind Senator Harradine, on the matter of principle, of some of the things he has said in the past about privatisation and public monopolies. A lot has been mentioned about the example of the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. Senator Harradine can probably recall when 30 per cent was sold. Then they said, `It is not private or public. We need another 19 per cent.' We remember the Treasurer and the government of the time telling us that it would remain majority owned by the Commonwealth. `Be assured,' they said. Senator Harradine voted for the first sale of 30 per cent and the second sale of 19 per cent.
But then in 1995 the Labor government decided to sell the rest of the Commonwealth Bank. Senator Harradine kicked up a bit of a stink. I was quite impressed by what he said at the time:

You might say that I have failed to recognise that the Commonwealth Bank is operating as just another bank. I do not fail to recognise that but I had hoped that whilst ever the Commonwealth was the majority shareholder in this enterprise the principles upon which the bank was founded by Andrew Fisher might have been enforced upon the bank and might have prevailed. It is obvious that the representatives of the major shareholder, the Commonwealth, have not pursued these principles for a long time.

The Labor government of the time hoodwinked a great many people about what majority Commonwealth ownership means. It told everybody that it would make a difference. It did not. As we know, it had to be run under the law and in the best commercial interests of all shareholders. Then history says that the government—contrary to all assurances—said, `We are going to sell the rest.' And it happened.

The point of remembering a little bit of this history is that I do not want to see history repeated. I do not want to have the assurances of how you balance majority and minority shareholders' interests. We all know that if the sale proceeds, the floodgates will be opened—one per cent, two per cent, 33per cent. We know—I do not care what assurances are made—that that inevitably means that the rest of Telstra will be sold. That is why we resist this sale so strenuously. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is on the record as saying that it will be fully privatised within five years.

The other matter that I want to refer to, which has a history and evidence of selective application of principle and understanding of mandate, is accountability. I believe that enormous accountability problems are created within AIDC by having a private minority shareholding. Perhaps Senator Harradine is aware that directors of public companies are required to act in the best interests of all shareholders and that, from a commercial point of view, you could probably argue that it makes very little difference, then, whether a company is 10 per cent or 90 per cent privately owned.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is honoured in the breach.

—We will see. Perhaps Senator Harradine is aware that, even with 67 per cent public ownership, the government can have no influence on company policy, other than in relation to appointing or removing its directors. Perhaps Senator Harradine is aware that, given the enormous market power of Telstra—the natural monopoly powers that he has so often talked about—the company directors will be required by their fiduciary duties to use these to the fullest extent possible to maximise shareholder returns.

BREAK.PARA: The AIDC instance was very instructive. The board of AIDC was 81 per cent government owned, and it awarded increases in salary of 200 per cent to its senior managers. We all asked the Labor government, `Why aren't you doing something about it?' The government said it opposed the decision but it went through. The government's appointed directors were not even present at board of directors meetings at various times. At other times, they were the government's own directors, the majority shareholders' directors. They were forced to leave board meetings because the board perceived a conflict of interest between their role of representing the government and their role of representing the shareholders, even though 81 per cent of the shareholders was the government.

What is going to protect us from a repetition of this? That is why I say that a third is as bad as 100 per cent. You are not going to exercise that majority shareholder control that you ought to. I want the minister to be able to answer this in the committee stage: what guarantees can he give that this is not going to be repeated?

The accountability problems of AIDC have a likelihood of being repeated on a grand scale. There is no ministerial direction. We do not even know what responsibility this government is prepared to take on behalf of majority shareholders. Are they going to ask board members representing them to leave the room every time they think there is a perceived conflict between a government decision and a private decision that they do not want to face up to? Minister, it has happened before. Why should it not happen again?

I say to Senator Harradine: are you absolutely, 100 per cent convinced that the regulatory regime that the government is putting in place is strong enough to restrain a privatised Telstra and strong enough to manage properly the competing interests of a complex identity that I call the `two-thirds, one-third board'?

I just finish by saying that we ought to be looking at the future here as well. We are not just talking about one-third; we are talking about the lot. We are talking about enormous economic power, just like the banks. We are talking about the possibility of a huge telco, a privatised telco with huge economic and political influence. You tell me how a government of the day is going to say no to timed local calls or to directory assistance charges.

Senator Alston, you can shake your head all you like. You can put anything you like in legislation. It is only as good as the numbers. It is only as good as your political will to honour what is in that legislation and not come back here and seek to change it, like we have seen in media ownership policy in this country—a little bit of a representation here, a little bit of a private meeting there and we get a change in policy.

You can assert to the Australian people all you like: `Oh, this is okay. We can protect against foreign ownership levels. We will not have timed local calls or directory assistance charges because we have guaranteed it in the legislation.' I do not think people have a great deal of confidence in the political will of any government to maintain those things indefinitely. Because you do not have ministerial direction in your model, then we are all the less entitled to have confidence, in my view.

What has been won and what has been lost out of this deal? What has been won? The passage, perhaps, of this bill. A couple of hundred jobs. Mind you, we cannot discount the jobs that are being lost through privatisation and downsizing, and we do not yet know whether these really are new jobs or whether they are jobs that are being shifted from some other section within those states or from other states.

But what is being forgone here is a future profit stream which in the past has been invested for the benefit of all Australians. We did not trade that off across Australia, saying that Tasmanians are more important in this instance than are Western Australians or South Australians. Also, what we are giving up in the long term is a guarantee of Australian ownership because you and I know that we do not have the pool of capital in this country to be able to afford for Australians to buy all of Telstra when you get around to privatising it. Senator Harradine cannot guarantee that the other 66⅔ is going to be kept in public ownership either, because he may not have the balance of power. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I just indicated privately to Senator Alston that we would be very keen for him to respond to the many questions that were asked in contributions from the opposition and other parties. There are many more questions that we would want to ask, but to cooperate with the passage of government business those questions, I think from the opposition at least, will be left until we deal with specific amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason many opposition members spoke today in the committee stage, and in many cases used their full 15 minutes, as they were entitled to, is that, other than in the minister's summing up speech at the conclusion of the second reading debate, there was nothing in the second reading speech or the explanatory memorandum about the arrangements reached with Senator Harradine and Senator Colston. Many members of the opposition felt that all of that material contained in the minister's summing up speech was germane to the debate in the broadest sense, not just in relation to the particular amendments and clauses of the committee stage. That is why today many senators took the opportunity to speak. Some of us even spoke twice about it because many issues have subsequently been raised.

I say to the minister: we would appreciate it if you could respond to the many questions that all of us put. As we start dealing with actual amendments, I suspect that there will be further questions, as we seek that information. I think the first amendment is actually from Senator Harradine, so maybe Senator Harradine could also respond to some of the questions that have been put because they do refer to his particular involvement in the agreement reached with the government and with Senator Colston. I look forward to the response from the minister to the many questions put to him during today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am in many respects responding to a majority of what have been `second reading' speeches, so I will be making comments that attempt to effectively deal with issues in the broad because I do not think there has been anyone yet who has actually addressed a clause of the bill.
—Senator Cooney talked about the clauses of the bill.
—He asked a couple of quasi legal questions, but he did not address any of the amendments. I am sorry, he did address his remarks to clauses in the bill. I accept that.
—There will be no amendments from the government to this legislation to take account of the arrangements reached with Senator Harradine or Senator Colston?

—No, the government does not propose to move amendments. The first point was in relation to the national interest. I think several speakers did cover the issue that somehow it was improper to not treat all Australians the same, to use Senator Ray's language. The fact is, of course, that we spend about $40 billion a year on social security entitlements on the basis that not all Australians are the same. In other words, we recognise people of particular disadvantage. We do—
—That is to assist them, not disadvantage them.

—Can I say that none of what we have in mind is designed to disadvantage anyone. It is designed to assist those who are currently disadvantaged either by location or by their lack of access to services.

SPEECH.PARA: I will come back to that point in a minute. Let me give you a classic example. Every capital city except Hobart is looking at either having received the cable roll‐out already or receiving it in the not too distant future. There are no plans on the part of either of the major carriers or indeed the cable consortiums to roll out any broadband interactive services or cable television to Hobart or Tasmania. If that in itself does not indicate a very significant level of disadvantage when you are wanting your kids to get on to the Internet, when you are wanting to learn, when you are wanting to entertain yourself, I do not know what does.

It is just another example of the extent to which Hobart, to use Senator O'Brien's term, is a mendicant state. There is a world of difference between Tasmania and Victoria or New South Wales, where you are close to capital cities which have world‐class telecommunications facilities, where there are enormous incentives by virtue of the population size for the carriers to keep on providing world best services. Those states and their citizens are immeasurably better off than those in a place like Tasmania where you are very lucky to even be able to make a phone call if you live in some parts of the west coast; even if you are in the capital city of that state you are very much a second‐class telecommunications citizen.

When we talk about treating all Australians the same it is a wonderful principle. You normally berate us for using that terminology because you immediately go on to say that not all citizens are in fact equal and that we ought to recognise particular disadvantaged groups. We do that and we do it particularly having regard to the fact that there are some states where the bulk of the population reside outside the capital cities and who are therefore almost by definition unlikely to get access to those services. That disadvantages them significantly.

We are not looking at any US gridlock type situation. This is I think a unique opportunity with the prospect of the proceeds of sale providing the funds that would not otherwise be there. That is why we went into the election campaign promising the best environmental package in history—but only because it could be afforded through the proceeds of the sale of Telstra. Otherwise you would be just plucking the money tree and the money is not there. You have heard us say ad nauseam that there was a budget deficit of the order of $8 billion. It turned out to be closer to $10 billion. The money simply was not there.

As much as you might wish to do it, you cannot simply act responsibly by contracting with the Australian people to spend another billion dollars when you do not have the money, when you are already in debt, when all the economic indicators suggest that you ought to be tightening your belt. It was a unique conjunction of events. It certainly is not US gridlock and in those circumstances it was reasonable for us to then explore further areas of particular disadvantage to see whether it might not be possible to address those in the same context; in other words, from the proceeds of the part sale of Telstra.

I come to another point. It is something that Senator Kernot has gone on about for quite a significant proportion of her contribution, that is the term `mandate'. Mandate usually gets a run when people say, `You didn't mention this before the election. You didn't tell us about this. You don't have a mandate.' That is how it is normally used. In other words, you have to put up a proposition. You have to argue for it before the election to have a mandate afterwards if you win.

Let us look at the Macquarie Dictionary, which has nine definitions of `mandate'. I am not about to use the one that says, `an order issued by the pope' much in all as I have great respect for what the pope has to say on many matters. There is one definition that particularly addresses politics. It says:
the instruction as to policy given or supposed to be given by electors to a legislative body or to one or more of its members.

In other words, by voters—not by respondents to polls. That is a fundamental difference. Otherwise you would have someone being elected to government and it would not matter which party it was. It would not matter who the individuals were. You would say, `Right. Just sit there for a moment. I will tell you what your mandate is. I will call up the computer. I will work out what all the majority positions were on any issue you like to name and that is your mandate.'

Even though we might have won the election, you say to me, `Look, here it is. The population is in favour of a return to capital punishment. They are sick to death of all that is going on. They want capital punishment.' We say, `We were opposed to that.' Senator Kernot says, `I'm sorry. The mandate means you have to reintroduce capital punishment.'

We say, `We believe migrants have a role to play. They make a significant contribution to Australia.' You happen to dig up a research poll that shows that the majority of the population does not want any more migrants so you simply say to us, `Sorry, sport. You haven't got a mandate. You've got to do what you're told. The polls tell you.' We are not poll driven, Senator Kernot. If you think the role of a government is to simply do what the polls tell you to do then you have a very different concept of democracy from the one that I have.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did John Howard say about mandate?
—If you want to argue that there is no such thing as a mandate, that is a separate argument.
—No. What did John Howard say about mandate?

—The quote that you are referring to says that there is no such thing as a mandate. But that is not what Senator Kernot is talking about. She has a very different definition of mandate. She claims there is such a thing as a mandate. For example, she does not say, as Senator Harradine might say, `You did have a mandate on IR but I have an issue of principle that I believe overrides that.' At least that is conceding a mandate, but you diverged from it. You do not do that. You do not accept that we have a mandate on anything unless it suits you. Yet I noticed quite extraordinarily that if it were a small issue that was tucked away, if it were one of the lesser policies, we could have a mandate on that. It defies logic. Nonetheless, that is the proposition that is being put.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I just get to this other major issue—that somehow selling one-third means you inevitably sell the lot? Just for your information, NTT, Nippon Telephone and Telegraph, sold 35 per cent in 1984. They have not gone further since that time. There is no inevitability about anything in this life or in this field. The fact is that unless you somehow think this parliament is about to change beyond recognition, and I do not think it is, it would mean that the Democrats or the Labor Party would have to change their position in order to repeal a provision of this very bill that is before us because this bill does not allow the parliament to go beyond the sale of one-third of Telstra. That is a fact. You know our commitment.

If you are about to propose that, I would be very surprised. I have not seen any sign of it. You can run that argument as much as you like, but the fact is that there is no inevitability about it at all. It would require a conscious vote in favour by a majority of both houses of parliament. I do not see that in the Senate in the foreseeable future, and I do not think you do either.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's the foreseeable future?

—The foreseeable future for me would probably be six years—probably longer than you and I will be here, Senator Kernot. Nonetheless, if you are still here, you can make absolutely sure that the Democrats do not change their minds on the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not talking down Telstra, as Senator Ray suggested. We have always made it clear that Telstra has to make decisions in a competitive environment. Telstra does that irrespective of privatisation. It does that in order to compete. The benefits to consumers are very real. It is not for the benefit of institutions or major players; it is for the benefit of ordinary consumers.

BREAK.PARA: I am not happy with our having virtually the highest local call charges in the world. You might be, but I am not happy with it. I am not happy with consistent reports of declining quality of service. Austel reports declining quality of service in rural areas. No-one seems to appreciate this. I heard a number of contributions to the effect that somehow things are not all that bad in the bush. Let me tell you what Austel said:

In general, the more remote parts of Australia have benefited last from the introduction of all types of new technology, and telecommunications has been no exception. Rural consumers in several parts of Australia have expressed concern that their services will not keep pace with improvements—

TALK.START.PARA: —Was Tasmania named as one of them?

—Tasmania is the classic case. Tasmania is the economic basket case. Why don't you accept that? Why don't you stand up for Tasmania? Senator Sherry stood here for 15 minutes and did not mention the benefits to Tasmania.

BREAK.PARA: There was criticism of maximum allowable waiting time for new telephone connections from the TIO, the Isolated Children's Parents Association and the Aboriginal Central Land Council. I can go on and on. The fact is that Austel have consistently handed down reports about the poor quality of service in rural areas vis-a-vis metropolitan areas, and we do not accept that that is good enough. We are not prepared to simply stand by and allow that to happen.

If you want to know why it is that Telstra does find it necessary to reduce the work force, you only have to ask the unions. They gave evidence to the Senate committee. Colin Cooper, Ian McLean and all these blokes were there saying that technology is forcing—

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't say 22,000 jobs.

—No, but they accepted that technology was inexorably leading in this direction. You ask what level of job reduction is needed? What they said about 18 months ago when they released their annual report was that they were 30 per cent off world's best practice. It was necessary to achieve that improvement over a two-year period. That is what they are doing.

BREAK.PARA: They are doing it unrelated to privatisation. Senator Harradine is absolutely right. It is purely and simply designed to ensure that they are competitive. After 1 July once that regime comes into place—not the one that Senator Lundy thinks we are introducing; the regime that you committed us to and which you supported: in other words, full and open competition from next year—and once players with much lower cost structures than Telstra who do not have the work practices that you lot think are terrific come in, they will cream Telstra unless it is efficient. And we will not reap the benefits. What we want is a Telstra that can compete, that can undercut, that can deliver the goods, that can have lower prices and better quality of service. So that is what that is all about. It has nothing to do with privatisation.

It was suggested that somehow the National Party was salivating at the prospect of funds for National Party electorates. The fact is that anyone who represents a country electorate would appreciate the very great importance of proposals that provide very significant benefits through the fund. That is why I was a bit surprised, to say the least, to hear Senator Reynolds suggesting that she had people ringing her up—I presume complaining; she would not be telling us that they were cheering her on.

She said that Queensland has a large proportion of the population outside the capital cities and that we ought to be able to make special arrangements or take that into account. Well we have. Fifty‐four per cent of the state population is outside the capital cities. As a result, Queensland will get 23 per cent of the fund—$53.1 million. That is a very substantial sum of money that recognises the fact that Queensland is the second most decentralised state in the federation. That is precisely why it gets that sum of money. Yet Senator Reynolds somehow decries the fact that we are providing that money in the fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Tasmania gets more and it has about one‐quarter of the population.
—Tasmania has 59 per cent of its population outside the capital cities.
—What's the population figure, Richard?

—Don't you blokes realise that Tasmania is so economically disadvantaged that its prospects of getting onto the superhighway are absolutely zilch. Unless you make the special effort and unless you create a fund to provide those incentives then you really do not give a damn about Tasmania. That is the tragedy of this. Tasmania is not going to have access to high fibre coaxial cables. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I was hoping that Minister Alston would answer the specific questions that a number of us have raised. I know that he only had 15 minutes and, under the rules, if I speak for a couple of minutes he will be able to get up again. So we will give him one more chance. I want to remind the minister that in my remarks alone I asked a whole series of questions about how the calculations were made.
—Give the man a chance.

—All right. I just want to remind him, Senator Harradine. First of all, how was the break‐up of the $250 million calculated for the various states in raw terms before you looked at the percentage figures of the numbers of people living outside capital cities? Does the minister have a comment on the quite extraordinary results in terms of per capita? If you look at the ACT, with $4 million it ends up on a per capita basis of around $10,000 funding for those living outside the Canberra area. That is what is creating some concern. There is $4 million for the ACT, and our advice today is that there are only about 400 to 800 people living outside the urban area of Canberra. If you make that calculation, you end up with $10,000 per capita.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that was being raised by Senator Reynolds and other senators—which again I want to emphasise, Senator Alston—is the disparity in the per capita arrangement. Senator West, for example, pointed out that in far western New South Wales the average, on your figures, will be $16 per resident. Yet those in the outback of New South Wales, just as do those in the outback of South Australia, have very difficult problems with telecommunications. We would like information on how the allocation within the state will work.

We would also like to know—and I asked this when speaking on two occasions—how the money is to be spent. Will it be spent on subsidising charges, or will it be spent on providing equipment? Additionally, if it is to provide subsidies for charges, will that mean that everybody will get subsidies or will only some institutions, some type of local residents or particular business? You imply in your statement that educational institutions will be singled out. That is commendable but, if that is to occur, does that mean that other people will then miss out? So far, those things have not been answered by the minister.

There are even questions associated with equipment. What sort of equipment will this fund be able to provide if over five years it is $250 million, or $50 million a year over five years, when in that same period—as I have remarked before—Telstra's capital works program alone for five years is $20 billion? It is an extraordinary comparison: Telstra, irrespective of the $250 million over five years you have collected, will spend $20 billion. In that $20 billion, are they themselves, irrespective of any pressure from you, going to cover and provide services to regional and rural Australia? I have to say that $20 billion over five years is much more attractive to look at than $250 million over five years or $50 million a year. I have raised the point before.

I think perhaps Senator Harradine did not realise what the minister may have done. I want an answer to this: what have you taken out of the business plan for the next three years, that was put before you in the last month or so, of the $250 million? Did you take something out, or were they already going to take something out of it? Then there is another question that I have raised: will the $50 million be paid overwhelmingly to Telstra anyway because they are the ones who provide the service to rural areas; and is that amount to be added on to the universal service obligation so that they have to pay less on the cross-subsidy?

These are questions we just do not know the answers to. Before this bill comes out of the committee, even if it will take us a long number of hours—and I do not want to delay the Senate—these are reasonable questions to be answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two hours ago you said that.

—And I am just saying it again. The minister has made his polemic in his first 15 minutes—and I accept that. But now let us get down to the specifics. I will stop here now. I have given him half a dozen questions again that I think ought to be answered. If they are not satisfactorily answered, we will keep asking them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to matters that Senator Schacht has raised. I say to him that the $250 million is not out of Telstra's corporate plan. Indeed, as I understand it, whilst my department may well have received the corporate plan, I have not even looked at it. So in that context, this fund certainly does not—
—You have not seen it yet?
—I have not personally seen it, no.
—Is there a deadline for that? I thought it had been around for about two months.

—I do not think that is right. But it may be that the board signed off on it and provided it to the department. However, I have not received a briefing on it. So the short answer to your question is that these moneys are over and above any capital expenditure program that Telstra might have in place over the next three years. Indeed, this is a five-year program; Telstra's is a three-year program.

SPEECH.PARA: Telstra will not be running the fund. Indeed, Telstra will not be automatically asked to undertake any of this work. It will be a matter for identifying the most effective and cheapest means of delivering service. To the extent that that involves putting it out to tender, that will be a matter of decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the communications department will run the fund?

—The mechanics of it will be announced later. But essentially it will be administered by the department; that is so. It certainly will not be the plaything of Telstra; it certainly will not be in substitution for any of its current or future planning proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: It will not affect the universal service obligation. As you know, the USO is a separate exercise of providing the standard telephone service—in other words, a minimum level of services that are required to be provided on a reasonably accessible basis to all Australians. The cost of that is assessed annually, and Telstra currently is the nominated universal service provider. It is our intention to broaden the choice so that, once the service itself is identified, that could be put out to tender. So there could well be others, apart from Telstra, who would put it into effect. But the universal service fund will remain intact as it is now. I think it is clause 8CM which reaffirms current arrangements.

Despite the fact that a lot of people in the chamber seem to think that somehow this will all change with privatisation, the fact is—as I know Senator Schacht understands—the world changed back in 1991. Since that time the board has had an obligation to act in the best interests of all shareholders. It is required to act commercially.

To the extent that you want to superimpose social obligations, you do not do it by asking Telstra to somehow do the right thing; you do it by legislation and by imposing social obligations. In part, they are contained in the CSO arrangement of USOs. They are just as much contained in untimed local calls and all those other non-economic—if you could call them that—or non-profitable concepts that are enshrined in legislation, just as they are in many other countries around the world where telecommunications carriers have never been publicly owned. I would have thought that is what gives the lie to the suggestion that somehow we are going down the American path.

The fact is that the Americans invented the USO. They have the fund; they have had it for years. They have the levy; we have simply mirrored it; and they have had it against the background of fully privately‐owned telecommunications companies. They have been able to live with it for all those years. We would live with it simply because, if for no other reason, the public would not have it any other way—and we would not either because we think that it is necessary to ensure a continuation of that arrangement. Carriers will play by the rules of the game. If they can continue to make decent profits, they will simply accept that the government sets the legislative environment.

As far as the priorities of the fund are concerned, it is an infrastructure fund. So we are prepared to commit $250 million to create a regional telecommunications infrastructure fund to improve the quality of telecommunication services and to enhance employment opportunities in regional areas. The fund will directly improve the quality of telecommunications infrastructure in rural and regional areas, including the expansion of mobile phone coverage. It will create employment opportunities in areas of high rural unemployment by assisting the establishment of customer call centres. It will assist community managed profit and non-profit communications projects in regional areas and establish additional Internet points of presence in regional areas to reduce or eliminate the STD charges associated with Internet access. In other words, these are all matters that will be available to be pursued via the fund mechanism.

There will be people presumably all around Australia who will have their own priorities and who will therefore make applications to the fund. It will be a matter of judgment as to what those priorities ought to be. But they can cover a whole range of infrastructure proposals that would not otherwise be available in rural and remote areas. That is why this is such an important initiative, because particularly in places like Tasmania you would be whistling dixie for years to come. The USO would not deliver the goods because the USO simply delivers the standard telephone service. If you want to go over and above that, then as far as Tasmania is concerned there will be $58 million available to address those special needs. Because Tasmania has a large proportion of its population outside the capital city, it is clearly a deserving case and it therefore will have a significant sum of money available to address those telecommunications needs.

I think I have dealt with this issue of mandates. Let me make it perfectly clear that, in the absence of legislation as before this chamber, none of these moneys would be available. So, when it is suggested by some that this is at the expense of Australian workers, it is in fact going to be very much to the advantage of those people in regional areas who would not otherwise have access to these services at all. Of course, inevitably there will be very significant employment created by those sorts of projects. So it has a double benefit to rural areas. It provides access to services that would not otherwise be available and it delivers very significant job creation opportunities. None of those would be there in the absence of the fund.

So there is no question of whether or not Australian workers are going to benefit or that somehow they are going to suffer, as was suggested. The fact is that those in areas where there is particular disadvantage will be significant winners and it will not be at the expense of anyone. It will be funded from the proceeds of that sale of one-third of Telstra. So those who are prepared to buy the shares will be making funds available out of their own pockets. They choose to invest. They will be putting the money on the table and part of that money will then be available to provide these benefits. I do not think I need to say any more about that.

Senator Mackay said that there was no guarantee the cross-subsidies will remain. As I have said time and again, no-one on our side of the chamber is proposing to dismantle universal service obligations. I would be very surprised if anyone in this chamber is proposing to. They work very well in other countries where they have fully privatised regimes. It was said that subsidies will disappear because of the vagaries of the market, as happened in the US. This is just mythology; it simply is not the case.

The issue of timed local calls was raised. Again, the legislation does not allow you to remove the option of an untimed local call. In fact we are extending that to businesses in the telecommunications package. Once again, no-one has ever argued that you should not have the option of a timed local call if you want it. But you have the right to retain an untimed local call, and that will be there in legislation. Who would want to repeal it? Say Telstra, or Optus or anyone else, thought that they would love to have it repealed. I suppose they all have their wish list, but who is going to accede to that? It would not stand the light of day. So there is absolutely no reason for suggesting that a partial privatisation puts these things at risk.

Senator Cooney asked about consumer protection. The fact is that the legislation does provide for the ability to recover damages for non-compliance with performance standards. But that is designed to act as a last resort. In other words, we would be very disappointed, and we would probably take corrective action to deal with it, if we found the carriers thumbing their noses at consumers and saying, `Sure, we're supposed to connect you within three days; but it's only going to cost us X dollars, so we'll cough up the money. Better still, take us to court and we'll put you through your hoops.' We would not take a favourable view of that. If it does prove costly or complex to enforce your rights, then I would certainly be very interested in improving the legislation.

It is not correct to say that you can recover the funds only by way of a credit or otherwise. Clause 87E does provide for a recovery of money by way of judgment, but it also allows the additional option of discharging that liability by credit or other arrangements. So you have all of the choices on the table—subclause 87F(4). Senator Cooney also asked what would happen if, despite the legislation, those issuing the prospectus and, I presume, Telstra and others colluded in what would be a clear act of illegality. The answer is that anyone who bought shares in a company on that basis would do so at their peril. Any agreement that they entered into would be void against public policy, and ultimately, of course, there is the ability to obtain an injunction to restrain the breach.

It is just not real life. What you are really suggesting is that one of Australia's largest companies is going to flout the will of the parliament—it is going to act illegally. I do not think anyone would tolerate that for very long, and I cannot imagine in my wildest dreams why any company would want to even attempt to do that. No broker, no investment house and no mercantile institution would want a bar of that sort of conduct. They would all be very much at risk of being sued. They would have all sorts of legal problems. As I say, it is just not real life. If that is the greatest of Senator Cooney's concerns, I can assure him that it is simply not going to happen.

There was a suggestion that New South Wales is not getting a fair deal. I simply say that, if New South Wales has 38 per cent of its population outside rural areas, it therefore gets 16.24 per cent on a pro rata basis and it gets $37.4 million. That is a very good deal that it would not otherwise get. It is, I think it is also fair to say, one of the more prosperous states of the federation, if not the most prosperous. In its capital city there are very many people who can afford to be part of a state government regime that addresses issues outside the capital cities. I do not think the same could be said of Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were the Illawarra, the Hunter Valley and Newcastle counted as the metropolitan area?

—No. They are outside the capital cities, so they would all be eligible. But the fact is that this fund is particularly designed to address regional disadvantage and, to the extent that a large proportion of the population is outside the capitals, then the fund makes it clear what the entitlement is. There is no room for discretion if a state is automatically entitled to a certain amount of money.

BREAK.PARA: But I come back to the point that anyone who has been to Tasmania—I think everyone here would have gone there a number of times—knows instinctively that Tasmania does feel very put upon that it is, in Senator O'Brien's terms, a mendicant state, that it does not have access to a lot of those services—
Opposition senator interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, was it? My apologies. I do not think it detracts from the point. I would not have thought WA was claiming to be a mendicant state these days, but certainly Tassie would have to be the prime example of it. Once you appreciate that instinctively, I think you ought to understand why the fund is designed in the way that it is. It is just not acceptable in this day and age in a federation to be basically waving goodbye to a proportion of the population and saying to them, `We really don't care whether you are part of the technology have‐nots. We don't really mind if you do not get the services that everyone else is going to get.'

BREAK.PARA: Just in passing, Senator Cook asked about the Howard‐Court agreement. As I understand it, the Premier of Western Australia has made a request and that is as far as it has gone.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what his letter said, I have to say, Minister. He actually said you'd reached agreement.
—I am telling you the extent of my information on the matter.
—So the $300 million is not coming out of the $1.1 billion environment fund?
—I have no knowledge of that, no. (Time expired)

—Senator, you started to give me some answers. I tried to scribble them down as you read them out, but part of it was rather quick. Many questions that I had previously asked are yet to be answered. First of all, is the arrangement for the $250 million fund to be established by legislation?
—No.

—It will not be. It will be administered by the department, then, responsible to you. Will it be a one‐line operation in the appropriation bill? I will take these points one by one. I think that is a better way to do this, Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I short‐circuit these point by point comments by saying that we will announce in due course the details of the fund and the way in which it is to operate. But bear this in mind: we are very keen to see it in place and it will be in place, I would imagine, well before any proceeds are available from the partial sale of Telstra. On that basis, there will be every opportunity to scrutinise the application of funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I have to say you really are putting the cart before the horse here. You are asking the parliament to vote on one of the most significant pieces of legislation in a couple of decades—the sale of Australia's biggest publicly owned enterprise. You speak of the moneys from that sale, which is an irretrievable sale under the way this legislation is put through, and then you say that we should take you on trust that at some stage in the near future you will make a statement or you will give us details of how the $250 million will be administered and allocated.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not for me to suggest to the government how it could improve its businesses or its chances, but it might be useful if, by the time we come back to the committee stage of this bill tomorrow afternoon—we are not going to finish this bill tonight—you and your advisers could provide us with a few more details about the administrative structure of the fund. When you do have a timetable for its announcement, is it going to be simply the head of the department collecting every application? Do you call for applications once a year and people write in and say, `Listen, I wouldn't mind a new telephone exchange at Coonabarabran,' and away we go or whatever and then you sit down and make a judgment about the long list that has been submitted in accordance with each state allocation and say, `Coonabarabran gets this, Cobar gets that and Walgett misses out'? I remember the present government in opposition was extremely critical of the way the sports facilities fund was administered by Mrs Kelly.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can call it `sports rorts' if you like.

—You were very critical of it, and it became a matter of considerable controversy. But you are saying to us that you are setting up a fund to be administered almost in the same way—no detail, no advisory body. I thought you would have suggested to us that at the very least there would be an advisory body made up of people with the appropriate expertise and experience in telecommunications and from regional Australia to look at the applications each year to allocate funds.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what you have partially set up as far as the Natural Heritage Trust is concerned, although last week you did reject the committee's recommendation that a specialist advisory board be set up to advise the two ministers on how the funds should be spent in that area. I put it to you, Minister, that it would not be unreasonable for us to get information in the next 24 hours of a similar structure. Otherwise, this is just a wide‐open slush fund. You will give a nudge and a wink and a nod to the head of your department or to some officer in DOCA, who will have a long list—that will probably stack up about a foot high—of applications each year for the $250 million broken down into states, and away it goes.

I suspect that Senators Harradine and Colston would be a bit further up the queue than the rest of us, because they were the ones who did the deal to get it done. It is extraordinary that since your announcement last Thursday we have had no further detail on how this fund is going to be structured and administered. I might talk to my colleagues overnight and tomorrow morning and we may want to move an amendment to the bill to actually put in a bit of structure. This is not going to be a travelling magic pudding slush fund for you or somebody else to hand around.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the Goon Show .

—Yes, of course; the Goon Show is a wonderful description of this minister and his department. I am waiting for Bluebottle and Eccles to appear because, Senator Harradine, I reckon that the way they have structured this fund is down at the Bluebottle and Eccles level.
—The Magic Pudding .

—It is like the Magic Pudding ; it never seems to disappear. You can eat as much as you like and then have a bit more. That is how the government is treating the sale of Telstra: it is a magic pudding to provide funds. By the time we come back to this bill tomorrow, the opposition would like more detail—decent detail—on how this is going to be administered.

SPEECH.PARA: We would also appreciate information on how you arrived at the figure of $250 million. That seems like a very round neat figure, give or take a bit here and there. It was as if you threw a dart and it landed on $250 million and then you worked backwards and divvyed it up amongst the states. You worked out a formula that meant Tasmania in one way or the other could be justified in getting a very large amount. Was the figure set after discussions with Telstra or was it set after discussions with your own department or any other advisory body in telecommunications? Why was it not made $500 million? No‐one is going to convince me that $250 million over five years is going to bring all rural telecommunication services up to the same standard as for cities. That is just preposterous! And Telstra is spending in the same period $20 billion. It is just a drop in the ocean.

In particular, I want to ask about Tasmania. Telstra and Optus have no roll‐out plans for Tasmania. I know Senator Harradine has raised this issue publicly before. It is one of his concerns. Will the $58 million allocated for Tasmania be used to subsidise Telstra or Optus in rolling out a broadband cable, because it seems that they have no plan to do so at the moment? If that is the case, will that be eligible for USO or is it just going to be a straight subsidy to those two carriers or to any carrier? Does that guarantee that, by the middle of the next decade, Tasmania will have the same level of access to broadband services as Sydney or Melbourne? Well, of course it won't! If you put the whole $58 million into one joint cable, it would not provide broadband services to Hobart and Launceston, let alone to the rest of Tasmania, compared with the cable now going out in Sydney and Melbourne, irrespective of the other argument that people do not like the cable hanging on poles.

That is a question that we would like answered: can the money be used anywhere, not only in Hobart or Tasmania? You say, `We are going to pay the carrier to do this.' Why don't you put it on the carrier to do it in the USO? In regard to the consideration of the post‐1997 regulatory model, there are already recommendations to upgrade what the USO should be, away from being the standard telephone handset. Our Telstra committee recommended to you in July or August that it be 64 kilobytes per second of capacity as a minimum as a universal service obligation. Isn't that a relevant thing that this money could be used for? Or is that going to happen anyway? Or does it mean that, no matter what you give Tasmania, it will not achieve what Senator Harradine claims he wants and that is that Tasmania not be the `arse end' of the Victoria Telstra regional area?

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't use those words.

—On television, you did, Senator—not actually in the chamber. I am a bit more robust, I suppose, about where I use the words. I have to say that I was rather startled, Senator Harradine, that a gentleman of your standing used the phrase. But I thought it was effectively put. Again, Minister, these are very serious questions about how that money is going to be used—the $58 million for Tasmania. It will not give Tasmania equality in broadband services or as up‐to‐date telecommunications as Sydney or Melbourne. It just will not happen out of $58 million over five years.

SPEECH.PARA: Then you talked about the priorities of the fund. You said that it would help employment in regional areas. Is this employment in telecommunications or employment generally? If it is employment in telecommunications, does this mean that you will subsidise Telstra, Optus and the other carrier to establish work depots or whatever they may be, or is the money going to be used to retrain displaced telecommunications workers in the regional areas? What happens when the money runs out and they still do not have a job? There is no answer to that.

You mentioned—I think I have this right from my quick notes—that the money will be used to create customer call centres for Telstra. Is this not a subsidy to Telstra that you are paying them? Are you are directing them or have you lent on them in the business plan in one form or another? I hope I got the word correct, but in those remarks about the infrastructure fund, you said you would create customer call centres for Telstra, or customer call centres for a carrier. Again, how do you achieve that? Do you ask Telstra, Optus, Vodafone or anybody else to make an application and say, `Well, here's a way we can get a quick quid for ourselves; we'll use it to establish one of these centres'?

Are any of these centres that you have mentioned—Senator Harradine got one off you for Tasmania and Senator Colston has one in Queensland in Toowoomba—being funded or subsidised out of this fund for Telstra to go and put those operating centres in Launceston, Burnie, Hobart and Toowoomba? Is that out of the $250 million or have you lent on Telstra or Optus to go and do it? If they are doing that, was that actually an official direction from yourself? Did you lean on them and suggest that if they did not play ball, you might sack another director or something? What level of communication did you have with Telstra to make that decision that these particular places were established?

It seems to me an extraordinary activity for you to be encouraging Telstra to have a particular number of centres at the operational level. We do not know whether you have bribed them by giving them access to the $250 million, whether you have threatened them in another way or whether they have suddenly fronted up to you and said, `Lo and behold, Minister; hallelujah, you are saved. After getting the figures wrong for employment in Tasmania in the last month or so, here we have something for you; it is Burnie, Launceston, Hobart and Toowoomba.'

I asked in my first remarks whether any of these jobs are being transferred from any other regional centre—there was an implication in your remarks that they were new extra jobs—or whether they are being transferred from somewhere else. If they are being transferred from somewhere else, where from? Secondly, I asked: how long do they last for? You keep telling all of us that telecommunications is changing so rapidly with technology. How can you guarantee that in two years time those jobs are still going to be there?

What guarantee have you given Senator Harradine and Senator Colston about these jobs? How long will they last for? Once this bill is through—there is nothing written in the legislation about the deal with Senator Harradine and Senator Colston—they do not have a leg to stand on. There is nothing they can do to ensure that the deal stands.

Because there is no legislation, each year in the appropriation you can change this figure of $250 million and reduce it to $150 million. You can say that it is all going to go to Western Australia next year—they have a bad election coming up—or it is all going to go to Queensland and your old mate Borbidge. You can change this fund any time you like each year in the budget because there is nothing in the legislation to say how the money must be spent and in what proportion.

I just wonder what the deal is. How did you convince Senator Harradine—who, in my view, has been so loose and friendly towards you—to let this money be in a pot that can be changed each year in the appropriation because there is no legislation? There is not even a guarantee apparently; it is a one line in the appropriation. It is administered by you and your department.

So next year or the year after the magic pudding shifts around a bit further. It may be helping out the National Party government in Queensland or your mate Jeff Kennett in Victoria. How do you give a guarantee to Senator Colston and Senator Harradine that for the next five years this money, as laid out here, will stay the way it is if it is not going to be in legislation? There is no way you can guarantee it. You might give it to them personally but you have just indicated that you may not be a minister in six years time. That is another range of questions. I hope I can get a few more answers. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In addition to the questions that were asked by Senator Schacht, I would like the minister to indicate, wherever the funds come from in relation to Telstra, whether any minister would be able to direct Telstra how they should spend it? Even if they provided it to Telstra and gave it to them in a package with a bow on top, would any minister, considering the nature of the bill that the government is hoping to put through, actually be able to instruct and require Telstra to spend it in a certain way, to move their personnel in a certain way and to roll out infrastructure in a certain area rather than another after this bill goes through?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing to be said is that this bill does not contain provisions in relation to a fund. So all that you are pursuing are really matters that are extraneous to this bill. I am happy to provide a number of answers, because I think there is a national interest involved. In view of your implacable opposition to this bill, I would have thought that nothing we might say or do in relation to details of the fund—
—That is true—I agree with you absolutely. We will only know on the third reading. We would like to know the details of the deal you have done.

—I would like to think that Senator Kernot would have the same degree of frank honesty. The fact is that we are providing more than adequate information in relation to the fund. I will come to the detail of that in a moment. I am simply making the point that if we are in the committee stage of a bill and there is nothing in this bill dealing with the fund, let us not pretend that this is anything other than a fishing expedition.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me address some of these matters. The purpose of the fund—and this will be made perfectly plain in guidelines that will be publicly announced and put in place so that there is a fully transparent process—is to deliver moneys to regional Australia in the proportions that we have indicated. So there is absolutely no way in which Queensland can get any more or any less than $53.1 million. It is not a question of there being any ministerial discretion to somehow vary that arrangement. That will all be provided for in the guidelines and arrangements that will be put in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Guidelines change; it is not even legislation.

—If you are telling me that you have never heard of funds being applied than other by legislation, then you do not know anything about appropriations to the Minister for Finance or any other mechanism of government administration.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not talking here about it being at the whim of the minister. The minister will not be making these decisions. The minister does not have an interest in doing anything other than putting in place a structure that will allow decisions to be made at arms length on the basis of applications that will be put before the fund administration by all those people who have a genuine interest in seeing regional Australia benefit. Let me come to some of the matters that Senator Schacht managed to cover.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a start tell us who the fund administrators are.
—Bluebottle and Eccles.
—Apart from Eccles and Bluebottle. Is Neville Stevens on it?

—Your way of doing business is quite different to ours. We have no interest in somehow controlling this fund covertly; all we want to see is people in those areas getting a fair deal. There will be a transparent arrangement.
—Is it Mr Morris from the Prime Minister's office?

—No, and nor will there be anyone else there who has a vested interest, political or otherwise. This will be designed entirely to ensure that those funds go to people in need, based on the quality of the applications before the administrators, not, as you might do, based on what electorate they happen to be residing in at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: When it is suggested that we are not going to bring all regional services up to the cities' services, that is the very point. I think Senator Harradine has made this point a number of times. I do not pretend for a moment that this fund is going to be able to provide you with the best broadband services in the nation simply because you live in Tasmania. In many ways it is compensation to Tasmania for not getting those services, at least in the short term.

I still live in hope that, come 1 July next year, commercial opportunities will make themselves available and either existing players or new players will come into the market. I recall reading a press release by Austar not so long ago which said that Tasmania was on its agenda.

The problem you face is that you know that the current cable operators are committed to rolling out every other capital city and that they are not committed to Hobart. That, by itself, provides a very significant disadvantage. We are not talking about this fund somehow enabling them to get all of those services. In many ways it is compensation for the fact that they may not get them, at least in the short term.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will they get for their $58 million?
—That will be a matter of identifying the needs in the first instance and then the fund administrators determining the priorities.
—Who are the administrators?
—It is irrelevant.
—No, it is not.

—No, it is, because the people who will make the decisions will make them on the merits. They will not be making them depending upon whether they happen to fit your political persuasion or mine; they will be making them at arms length.
—Who are these wonderfully mythical people?

—I have just said to you that the names of individuals do not matter. We do not have names of individuals in mind. You put in place a structure that ensures that, whether or not the personnel change, there are guidelines in place that guarantee that the fund is administered on a proper and transparent basis.

SPEECH.PARA: You suggested, for example, that Telstra would be spending $20 billion. I do not know whether that is an even remotely plausible figure, but the fact is that Telstra's priorities are quite different.
Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It may or may not be, it will be a matter for commercial determination by the company, in the same way it will be for Optus. Their interest is not in saying, `There are some places that really deserve a bit of a handout, so we will start to roll out some of our facilities just to help those people.' They will operate commercially, as they have been required to do ever since 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether it is spending $2 billion a year, $4 billion a year or whatever, it will not necessarily deliver the sorts of social goods and social outcomes that we might think are important. That is precisely the Hobart and Tasmania problem. They are out there spending $3 billion or $4 billion each over the next few years and they do not have Tasmania in their plans. So how do you address that disadvantage? You do it via a fund.

The fund is not a substitute for the universal service obligation. That is designed to ensure that moneys are available to deliver minimum services; in other words, the standard telephone service. You can argue that that can be upgraded in various ways. I think it can be upgraded in terms of quality, but I will be getting a report on 20 December that will give us some specialist advice on the issue. But it will not go to providing such things as ISDN on a mandatory minimum basis. That is your 64 kilobits per second. That is the ISDN approach.

We take the view that that ought to be demand driven and that exchanges ought to be ISDN capable. If you want it and if you are prepared to pay for it, you can have it. But it should not be mandatorily available to every citizen. I think it was Senator O'Brien who said, `Why would people want ISDN services?' He may well be quite right, but he proved the point that you simply would not want to build it into the standard telephone service and impose obligations of many millions of dollars, perhaps quite unnecessarily if the demand is not there.

So the concept of the universal service obligation is to do with a standard telephone service as a bare minimum. It has nothing to with providing funds over and above the USO, over and above the carriers commercial cap ex plans to ensure that a range of other services are available that might not otherwise be there. So you provide the infrastructure to develop those services. The matters I mentioned earlier were simply examples of the ways in which those sorts of services might be selected.

When we talk about customer call centres, we are not necessarily talking about telecommunications carriers at all—let alone Telstra or Optus. In other words, Ansett has recently established a customer call centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are picking winners.

—We are not picking winners at all. It is the locals who decide what they regard as an important facility in their area. If they think that having a commercial call centre for an insurance company or a bank or any other commercial institution is their top priority in telecommunications infrastructure, so be it. These are all choices that will be made, in the first instance, by the applicants and, ultimately, by the fund administrators in determining how those moneys ought to be spent.

SPEECH.PARA: But let's make it crystal clear. I have no interest, and nor do any of my political colleagues, in somehow being involved in the day-to-day administration of the fund. My department will accept responsibility for servicing it, but that is an entirely different proposition. The decisions will be made at arms length.

BREAK.PARA: So in terms of employment in telecommunications to deliver infrastructure, it ought to follow that—if you are committed to putting in place something like $140 million outside Queensland and Tasmania, for example, in infrastructure projects—you do not just click your fingers. You need real people to install them, to put those in place. That is what creates the jobs and that is why it is such a very big step forward and addresses two of the major problems: lack of services and lack of jobs in regional Australia.
It was suggested that somehow Hobart, Burnie and Toowoomba would be funded out of the $250 million fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I asked whether they would be.

—I will respond in terms of it being your question to me. The answer is no. Those are matters that Telstra has addressed in the context of its current three-year corporate plan. Consistent with its broad national planning—
—But you told me you haven't seen the corporate plan.
—I am just explaining it to you. Telstra has indicated that it recognises that customer call connect—a new service for ordinary telephones as opposed to mobiles, where they already have them—
—What is the charge?
—I do not know. Someone said 70c to $1.
—That's right.
—That is right, I think.
—So you agree with that?

—So? This is a matter of choice. If people want to pay for the service, they will pay for it. The issue is where those centres ought to be located. These are new jobs. This is a new demand that is being catered for. It therefore requires new centres. What Telstra have indicated is they are prepared to locate those centres where they already have operator assisted services in Burnie and Hobart in Tasmania, and they will locate a new centre in Toowoomba.

BREAK.PARA: So it has nothing to do with the fund. These are simply matters that Telstra has addressed in the context of its corporate plan. There have been no threats on my part to sack directors. There has been no official or unofficial direction—indeed, I do not think there has ever been an official direction to Telstra under section 9.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who came up with the recommendation for those three sites?
—As I have indicated, I relayed certain concerns expressed to me and Telstra made its decisions. There was no arm twisting on my part.
—Whose recommendation?
—Not my recommendation. I am simply telling you that I relayed concerns. Telstra indicated—
—Other members of parliament?
—I relayed concerns to Telstra. Telstra announced what I put in that press release. I said:

BREAK.PARA: "Over the past few weeks I have been working with Telstra to identify some of the implications of their current three year business plan for Tasmania and Queensland."

TALK.START.PARA: —And how many other sites were considered?

—I am just explaining to you that discussions with Telstra were on the basis of relaying concerns about jobs in areas.
