The decision that Telstra has announced is not only that it will be providing those additional jobs in those areas but that, in relation to Tasmania, ISDN services will achieve 70 per cent customer penetration by June 1997 and 90 per cent by December 1997, creating an additional 30 jobs. They have also given details of GSM, which is digital mobile coverage, in Tasmania and a commitment that local call access to the Internet will be provided for all Tasmanians. Tasmania will benefit from an Internet for schools package to be offered nationally early next year.
—Who made the decision and what was the process?
—Telstra made that decision in the context of its existing corporate plan. As I have said, this is not—
—Can you guarantee the professionalism and the objectivity of the process?

—I am simply telling you, as I have already said, that representations made to me were passed on to Telstra. Telstra gave that assurance, and that is contained in the announcement that we made last Thursday.

BREAK.PARA: Let me be crystal clear. It has nothing to do with the $250 million. That will be available quite separately, on application, administered at arms length to ensure that people in regional Australia get services and infrastructure that they would not otherwise be likely to get. They are not going to be out there wanting to subsidise Telstra to do something. That would just encourage Telstra not to do certain things and then to dip into the fund. That is not our intention, and I would not have thought it would be the intention of people applying for these funds. They will be identifying services that they do not expect would be otherwise available on a commercial basis. They will be looking to have new infrastructure put in place in those regional areas to provide the telecommunications benefit and, ancillary to that, the jobs that flow from putting those services in place.

You ask: how long will the jobs last? It is in the context of Telstra's current three-year corporate plan that the decisions it has announced are in place. No-one can take you much beyond that any more than you can in any other area of industry. In this parliament—maybe you are a bit fortunate if you are in this chamber and you have a six-year term, but you are very much out of the ordinary if you are—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —As it has unfolded over the last half hour, as it dribbled out about this fund, it really is getting more extraordinary. Earlier I asked the minister whether he had seen—
—Prised out.
—Prised out, dribbled out, kicked out.
—You are prising it out, and he is dribbling it out.

—That is right. I asked the minister whether he had seen the draft business plan for the next three years, and the minister said no. Now in the recent range of words that have just come about how these three centres were arrived at, the minister said, `Well, they were in the business plan.' It was not clear whether they were in the old business plan, but then they were in the business plan for the next three years.

SPEECH.PARA: So at some stage or other it seems quite clear that either the minister or his advisers have had access to the business plan. What they have done is found within that business plan that there were three centres. Whether someone in Telstra read the tea-leaves pretty well over the last couple of months and said, `Gee, we might be able to help the minister out here by helping him with his negotiations with the two critical votes in the chamber. Here is something for Toowoomba that Senator Colston might be interested in. Here is something for Burnie, here is something for Hobart or Launceston—help them out.' They may have put it in. The minister said, `Oh, aren't I lucky. It is in here' and his adviser said, `Minister, you have been talking to Telstra.' Telstra says, `Look, Minister, we have it here for you.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Surprise, surprise!

—Surprise, surprise! But the extraordinary thing is, I have to say to Senator Harradine, that if you take the minister at his word about this, these things were going to happen anyway. They were in the business plan. They were not in there because you were successful in negotiating. At best, you might have actually indirectly encouraged a Telstra official to put them in the business plan over the last couple of months or the minister has been able to use his influence on your behalf or—the other way round—there was no influence; they were already there and you have been given something as a deal that was already going to happen.

PARA.BREAK: It seems to me to be extraordinary that you would agree to sell one‐third of Telstra—which you say you are ideologically opposed to—for 140 jobs in Tasmania in two of these operator centres. There are 14 actually, be cause the minister has admitted that he got 126 wrong the other day. There are 14 jobs altogether. You sold a vote to sell a third of Telstra for $80 billion plus. You set it on the road to inevitable full privatisation for something that was going to happen in Tasmania anyway. If that is not what was going to happen, the minister has contradicted himself already by saying, `I didn't have any influence over the business plan.' If he didn't have any influence over it, you were going to get it anyway. If you did have influence over it, the minister has interfered in the business plan and put pressure on Telstra. Either way, it seems that either one bloke got diddled or the other fiddled. That seems to me to be what we have got here. It really is a very strange arrangement. I think at the very least—

TALK.START.PARA: —All care and no responsibility.

—Yes, all care and no responsibility. It might well be Eccles and Bluebottle from the Goons show running loose here, as mentioned earlier. But, Minister, I have to say that, every time you give us more information, what you are doing here becomes more unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: You said in your remarks that this bill does not have an amendment in it establishing the trust fund for the telecommunications infrastructure fund. But at least on the other side in environment there is a fund. There is another separate piece of legislation. At the very least one would have thought you would now be giving notice to us that you would bring in, under legislation, the equivalent of the Heritage Trust Fund. Your government has trumpeted about that for the last nine months. How the money would be disbursed is on the list to be debated this week in the Senate. There is a structure about how that money would be disbursed.

Why haven't you at least given us an indication that you will parallel that structure for the Natural Heritage Trust Fund with a national infrastructure fund? No, not this minister. He wants to get, by one way or the other, his hot little hands on the $250 million to be disbursed at his desire, at his initiative—wink, nudge, nod—down to someone in the department. He can't even give us an indication about who the administrator will be. It is supposed to be some mythical person who will not in any way be susceptible to influence.

Are you trying to tell us that, once this fund is established, every National Party member and every Liberal member in a rural area of Australia will not be out there telling their local council or their local regional development board, `Here's the slush fund. I can talk to Richard tomorrow. I'll give him a ring. We'll put our submission in. I'll give him a bit of a kick along in the communications committee room and we'll get it?' If anyone suggests to us that that won't happen, that there will not be that lobbying by members of parliament, they are deluding themselves. The minister has had more than enough strife with his own party's communications committee over cabling issues. They are running all over him. He has had to change his plans three times. Finally, the Prime Minister had to come in and go over the top of him again.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's a doormat.

—A doormat—of course. Does he suggest to us that there is not going to be consistent lobbying once his backbench finds out that there is a fund of $250 million which is separate from legislation, has no legislative independence and is administered by some mythical administrator responsible to the minister? As I said before, he hasn't answered the question. Each year the money from this fund can be shifted around between the states. The only way you can stop that, Minister, is to put it in legislation; put it in legislation so that the parliament can keep you honest. That is what you have got to do to stop any suggestion that, from year to year, you will change the relativities to different states to suit a political purpose. You have given us no information that that won't happen.

SPEECH.PARA: As Kim Beazley very perceptively said last Thursday, this is a slush fund. This is going to be shifted around Australia to suit the political whim of the minister and to buy favours for his state and federal political friends. It is a disgraceful effort for the minister to come in here and try to duck and weave away from this. It is just simple good administration. We still do not know, after several hours of debate, the details of the arrangement between Senator Harradine, Senator Colston and this government. It is a disgraceful arrangement. Of course the people of Australia now have every right to say, `This is a dirty sneaky deal.' There is no evidence to the contrary. There is no transparency about it. It has been a buy off. We know it. Unless the minister can actually give us some details of how it is going to be administered right from the very beginning, this is a dirty deal.
Progress reported.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to address the new funding arrangements for women's groups recently announced by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Newman). There appears to be a number of misconceptions concerning this funding, which is a great pity. These initiatives represent real and palpable gains for women. I believe the initiatives are very good news.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that women and women's groups do not fall for misleading information and half‐truths about what these arrangements entail. In essence, what is proposed is that, firstly, funding of up to $50,000 will be made available for core groups of national non-government women's organisations. The criteria for selection will be announced in the new year. Applications will be called for in March and will be processed, to be taken up on 1 July 1997. Groups receiving core funding will have certainty and continuity, and the drip‐feed will be over.

Secondly, the national agenda for women's grants program—currently funding only 22 groups which share $1 million—will cease at the end of the month and be replaced next financial year by a different approach. The majority of women's organisations will be encouraged to apply to individual departments, to statutory bodies and to any other government departments which reflect the area of interest to the particular group. For example, women's health groups would apply to the department of health instead of to the grants program; women's sporting groups would apply to the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories; and Australian women in agriculture would apply to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, and so on.

While we can recognise the value the grants program had in the past in identifying areas of need for women, the time has come when women's issues no longer occupy special interest areas. They no longer are areas of special need, niche areas or of marginal relevance. Women's issues are mainstream. Women's issues are entitled to access the whole gamut of possible assistance in a relevant portfolio area.

A major component of the shift in approach—one that has been either deliberately misrepresented or carelessly overlooked; I do not know which—is the transitional arrangements—namely, the government will be extending interim funding to women's organisations currently in receipt of operational support grants until the new arrangements commence from July next year.

Let me say this slowly, and I hope it sinks in: interim funding will be available for six months from 1 January 1997 to 30 June 1997. There is no suggestion of these groups being cut off at the knees. Claims that women's groups will have to fight to survive till next March is fanciful nonsense. In fact, they are more likely to survive as a recognised, legitimate mainstream provider of services for women dealing with ordinary portfolios, and portfolios that are aware of and respond to women's needs, than they are if they lurch from year to year jostling and fighting for a slice of a centrally administered and limited fund.

The mainstreaming of funding for women's groups has other advantages. It heightens awareness of women's issues across portfolios. It provides Australian women with more points of contact between federal governments and women's groups. It has the potential to deliver more money in a more focused and targeted way from more sources than if administered from a central pool. It provides a better opportunity to reflect the broad impact of women's issues across government.

The initiatives also include opening up for women the channels of communication with the federal government. The minister has announced a range of special measures to assist in this way. The new consultative measures that have been announced include an annual two‐day meeting of national women's groups with the minister, to be known as the Australian women's round table. That two‐day dialogue will take place in Parliament House on 26 and 27 August next year. Of course, it will deal with a vast number of issues of critical relevance to women, including domestic violence, censorship, balancing paid work and family responsibilities and dealing with women in decision making.

It will also publish an annual report of the achievements of national women's groups. This is something that is very important. It will promote the valuable work which national women's organisations are doing to raise the status of Australian women. You just have to think for a moment of the sorts of groups that will be affected—nursing mothers, older women, sportswomen, business women, rural women, women from a culturally diverse background, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women, women in education and women in a myriad of other areas of Australian society.

They have their interests represented in a number of non-government organisations at present. In fact, there are currently about 65 national women's NGOs in Australia. Rarely is the work of these groups—important though it is—recognised beyond their immediate constituency. To highlight the work of these groups, the government will compile and publish the annual report of the achievements of national non-government women's organisations. It will provide a very useful window to the work community organisations are doing in order to help improve the quality of life for Australian women in almost all sectors of our society.

Another initiative is the operation of a communications network between non-government women's organisations, which will be paid for by government and selected by competitive tender. This initiative is to recognise that women's organisations also play a productive role in promoting interest and debate on important issues. The federal government will shortly call for tenders for the operation of a communication network to provide information electronically to national non-government women's organisations. The government will look to putting together a communications package to help facilitate dialogue between women's groups on a number of important issues and to let women share properly their information, ideas, contacts and experiences.

Yet another initiative is the establishment by the minister of an advisory group, comprising a parliamentary representative from each state and territory, to provide feedback to the minister on Commonwealth issues affecting women in their respective states. I am very proud to say that I am the New South Wales representative on that advisory group. Having represented women's interests for some 20 years, I am not about to sell them down the river. This advisory group will be very important to facilitate ideas, to facilitate contact and to be a conduit for women to be able to voice their concerns and to have a say in policy.

Another initiative is the release of Getting the message through, an information booklet aimed at assisting women's organisations. It is a step in an effort to assist women to gain greater access to the parliament and the parliamentary committee system. An interesting thing about this booklet is its totally non-partisan nature. Every single woman in parliament, irrespective of whether she is an Independent, from the Labor Party, a Green or from the Liberal Party, is listed in this booklet. It is an even-handed attempt to allow the public to access women in parliament.

These initiatives are ones to which the women of Australia ought to look forward. The initiatives include opening up channels of communication in a way that has never quite been done before. They have allowed women to be regarded as mainstream. Women no longer have to be regarded as just marginal, just off in the Office of the Status of Women. Women will now be able to access portfolios just like any other relevant group in the community requiring assistance.

Women have no need to have any great concerns with this government. The initiatives taken and announced a couple of days ago will ensure not only that the needs and interests of women are adequately heard and adequately represented but also that there will be appropriate responses to these needs through this range of initiatives. Certainly, women no longer need be concerned that their funding will just be cut off, because the interim funding very clearly is to tide the organisations over. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 23 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: For each year in the period 1985-86 to 1995-96, in relation to individual mining companies which have received an amount exceeding $500,000 in any one year under the diesel fuel rebate scheme what was: (a) the name of the company; (b) the mineral mined; and (c) the amount of diesel fuel rebate received; please list the companies in descending order by amount of rebate received in each year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: After discussion with Senator Brown's office, the following information is provided on disk to meet the Senator's request. The information is provided for each of the years 1992-93 to 1995-96 for claimants that received an amount exceeding $500,000 in any one year under the mining category of the diesel fuel rebate scheme in descending order of amount of rebate received each year:
(a) the name and location of the claimant; (b) the date the claimant first registered for rebate; and (c) the amount of rebate paid.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 25 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the 1996‐97 Budget measure to limit psychiatric services to 50 sessions per year:
(1) Was psychoanalysis deemed by the Minister to be a rort, in Hansard on 11 September 1996, contrary to the views of expert medical opinion; if so, on what grounds.
(2) What is the legal basis by which the Minister can force doctors to provide treatments that are only subject to payment through the Commonwealth Medical Benefits Schedule (CMBS).
(3) What is the legal basis by which the Minister can discriminate between different groups of psychiatric patients.

(4) If doctors cannot provide necessary treatment (for example, psychoanalytic treatment for patients with chronic symptoms associated with developmental personality abnormalities) under Medicare, what are they to advise patients to do, given that general practitioners and public sector psychiatry cannot or do not provide this treatment.

(5)(a) Can the Minister confirm whether the patient, quoted in Hansard on 11 September 1996, who claimed 747 consultations with a psychiatrist in a year was not submitting forged claims to Medicare; (b) is it the case that this is not psychoanalysis which has 150 to 250 consultations per year; (c) has the Minister investigated the case; (d) can the Minister confirm that this is a real case.

(6) If a patient sees psychiatrist A for 50 sessions and then consults psychiatrist B without telling him or her about A, can doctor B be charged with giving false CMBS item numbers; and (b) what are the second doctor's professional and legal responsibilities to patients who have lied in this way during their assessment.
(7) Why is it that individual psychoanalytic treatment is limited to 50 sessions, but group analysis and family therapy are exempted, given that the latter is still drawn from psychoanalysis.

(8) Is the Minister aware that psychiatrist psychoanalysts have undergone a further 4 to 8 years of formal clinical and theoretical training to master psychoanalysis at considerable expense and at low incomes.

(9)(a) Is the Minister aware that Appendix I of the McKay report states that the most unsatisfactory type of psychiatric service to consumers is the short session super clinic psychiatry which the 50 session limit will promote; and (b) how can the Government promote services deemed unsatisfactory by clients.
(10) Why is intensive psychiatric treatment of some patients being targeted when they are the most disadvantaged and other treatments have perhaps not worked for them.
(11) Has the Government evaluated the impact of the 50 session limit to an average psychoanalytic practice; if so, what is the average impact.

(12)(a) Does the Minister support a situation where only rich ill people will be able to pay for psychiatric services; and (b) does the Government support the mass servicing of individual clients in an inadequate fashion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Psychoanalysis itself is not considered to be a rort, but the unlimited coverage under Medicare can lead to rorts and excessive numbers of services.

(2) The Commonwealth has no control over the services doctors provide. Doctors are free to provide services which are not included in the Medicare Benefits Schedule—and do so (eg cosmetic surgery), however there are no Medicare benefits payable for these services.

(3) There is no discrimination between different groups of psychiatric patients. The measures apply across all the psychiatric attendance items and not just to particular illnesses or diseases or to particular patients.

(4) Psychiatrists will be able to continue to provide as many out‐of‐hospital psychiatric consultations as they consider to be clinically necessary, only the Medicare rebate will be reduced for the fifty‐first and any additional consultations in a twelve month period.
(5)(a) There is no reason to believe that forged claims are being submitted.
(b) The type of treatment provided during the consultation is not known.
(c) Yes. The case has been investigated by the Health Insurance Commission.
(d) Yes. The case is a real case.
(6) Doctors will not be charged for inadvertently billing patients under the wrong item numbers, however the level of benefit paid to the patient will be adjusted accordingly.
(7) The Government does not have any significant concerns regarding access to these services or regarding the pattern of usage of the Group therapy items.
(8) The Minister is aware that psychiatric psychoanalysts undergo additional post‐graduate training in the chosen field, as do many other practitioners.
(9) It is hard to envision that 50 services, usually between 45 and 75 minutes in length, a year (which is the pattern for many patients) constitutes "short session super clinic psychiatry".
(10) The intensive psychiatric treatment of certain patients is not being targeted:

PARA.TAB: the measures apply across all the psychiatric attendance items and not just to particular illnesses or diseases or to particular patients;
there is no restriction on the number of out‐of‐hospital psychiatric consultations for which Medicare benefits are payable.

ANSWER.PARA: (11) The Government has not analysed the impact of the measure on particular psychiatric practices. The impact will depend on factors such as their current billing practices and whether practitioners reduce their fees. However it is expected, following the introduction of a price signal, practitioners and patients will review their treatment plans and that the price signal will provide a greater incentive for private psychiatrists to widen their lists to more patients, thereby increasing access to private psychiatric services to new patients.

(12)(a) No. However as it stands, the majority of patients currently having over 50 out‐of‐hospital consultations in a year are clustered in just the seven electorates around the Eastern suburbs of Melbourne and North Eastern suburbs of Sydney. These 7 electorates have a median income of $41,126 or 20% above the national average.

At the other end of the spectrum, there are 22 electorates with no patients having more than 50 out‐of‐hospital psychiatric consultations a year. These 22 electorates have a median income of $27,913, or 19% below the national average.
Thus, under the system as it exists, people from wealthy electorates already appear to have disproportionate access to these services.
(b) No.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Margetts

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 4 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to an agreement between the Agrifood Council, the Meat Industry Council and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to provide funding for a trial of company meat inspection in export abattoirs which is known as `Project 2':
(1) Was funding for this trial partly provided by the Agrifood Council.

(2)(a) Is it a fact that a condition precedent to the continuation of funding for this project was the securing of agreement from the United States of America that project participants would be allowed to retain access to United States (US) markets for the duration of the trial; and (b) can a copy be provided of the agreement between the Agrifood Council, the Meat Industry Council and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

(3) If the stated condition precedent exists in the funding agreement, has the Agrifood Council obtained written confirmation from US authorities that continued market access will be allowed for the duration of the trial; if so, can copies of any agreements or correspondence in that regard be tabled; if written confirmation has not been obtained, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Agri-Food Council was the food industry consultative body of the former government. Further, the Minister's Department is unaware of any contract or agreement between the Agri-Food Council, the Meat Industry Council and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for funding a trial of company meat inspection. However, under the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism's Food Quality Program, the Meat Industry Council was successful in a grant application which led to an agreement between the Department and the Meat Industry Council for a Food Quality Project known colloquially as MIC2 or the MIC2 Project.
(2)(a) (b) The content of the agreement between DIST and the Meat Industry Council is commercial-in-confidence.
(3) Refer to answers (1) and (2) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the Minister's media release, dated 21 October 1996, in which it was stated that there are a small number of rural phone users, estimated at less than 20,000, who currently receive an Analogue Mobile Phone Service (AMPS) but would not necessarily be within the radius of Global Systems for Mobile (GSM) coverage: where are these rural phone users located.
(2) Under proposed arrangements for analogue mobile phaseout, will these rural phone users be able to use their analogue handsets when they travel to the city.
(3) Has advice been obtained on the legal implications of retaining the AMPS spectrum in specified rural areas; if so, what are the legal implications.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) has advised that the carriers conducted joint studies to quantify the extent of the coverage deficiency. Telstra has advised that the estimate of 20,000 users who may not be covered by GSM when AMPS ceases is derived from broad knowledge of the extra coverage area of AMPS, the population density, and the take‐up (as a proportion of the total population) of the cellular service.
Telstra is currently working with the Spectrum Management Agency, on a case by case basis, to identify the particular locations of these rural phone users.

(2) Rural phone users would not be able to use their analogue handsets when travelling to the city after 1 January 2000. AMPS spectrum will only be retained in specified rural areas if a review in 1999 of rural planned services areas identifies areas that do not have mobile coverage from an alternative technology which is reasonably equivalent to AMPS coverage. The analogue service will be closed down in all other areas.
(3) I have obtained advice on the legal implications of retaining the AMPS operation in specified rural areas and those implications are as follows.

The AMPS phaseout policy is implemented through Optus' and Vodafone's Public Mobile licences which prohibit them from installing or operating an AMPS network; and a condition under the Telecommunications Act 1991, (Public Mobile Licence) Declaration (No. 1) of 1992 stating that:

PARA.TAB: no licensee would be permitted to install or operate an AMPS network after 1 January 2000, with the limited exception when:
the Minister and all mobile carriers agree in writing, or

the Minister agrees in writing after consultation with each mobile carriers, and determines that the installation or operation of the AMPS network will not erode unduly the practical value of a mobile carrier's rights.

ANSWER.PARA: Any retention of spectrum in specific rural areas would operate as a qualification to withdrawal of the last 2 x 5 MHz of spectrum on 31 December 1999. Any continued operation of an AMPS network would need to be in accordance with the provisions of Declaration 1/1992 cited above. The three carriers have given in principle consent to this aspect of the AMPS phaseout, and are discussing formalisation of this agreement.
